HEADLINE: Troopers' Case Ends, But the Talk Goes On 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
In a Trenton courtroom, the case that got the nation talking about racial profiling ended Monday as two state troopers pleaded guilty to reduced charges in the shooting of three unarmed men on the New Jersey Turnpike four years ago. But here in the streets and stores of North Jersey, the talk rolled on today -- a mix of anger, resignation and cynicism about the plea deal, and only meager signs of hope that profiling will cease.
 "You're damn right justice is blind, because they sure didn't see this one," said Lamont Gentry, who is black, 28 and unemployed. 
 Like many of the nearly two dozen people interviewed, he objected to the plea agreement, which cost the troopers their jobs but spared them jail or probation. "I would like to have seen them get some jail time, probation even," Mr. Gentry said. "It's just not right to just say, 'O.K., you can go away now.' " 
The two troopers, John Hogan and James Kenna, who are white, were allowed to plead guilty to misdemeanor charges of obstructing the investigation. Both were originally charged with aggravated assault, and Mr. Kenna had been charged with attempted murder. In the April 1998 incident, the two officers stopped a van carrying three black and Latino men, then opened fire on the vehicle after they said it started to back toward them. Two of the occupants were wounded in the incident, which shined a spotlight on allegations of widespread racial profiling by the state police.
Under the pleas entered Monday, the troopers will each pay a $280 fine and be barred from ever serving as New Jersey state troopers. 
Today, white and minority people alike seemed to agree that the charges and sentences were too light, though they differed in the intensity of those feelings. Some whites saw the plea bargain as an understandable consequence of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Some profiling is now generally seen as acceptable, they said, and juries may be more likely to see the police as heroes rather than criminals.
"This sentence doesn't appear to be right," said Bill Ryan, 38, a compliance analyst with Prudential who is white and lives in Monmouth Beach, as he ate lunch today at the Commerce Food Court here. "But a prosecutor might think that people would give a policeman more leeway after Sept. 11."
Patricia Smith, 49, who was recently laid off as a human resources specialist, had no patience with such explanations as she walked across the parking lot of a Pathmark supermarket in West Orange. Ms. Smith, who is black and lives in Irvington, said the police were no more heroic than "the secretary at her desk and the janitor cleaning the bathroom" in the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
"It has nothing to do with Sept. 11," she said. "Profiling is profiling, and it's wrong and these guys wouldn't be heroes if they went out today and shot someone. This is a big crime."
But Cynthia Lynn, 40, who is black and works as an Essex County corrections officer, did not think that all profiling was wrong, and said that "under certain specific circumstances" it was a reasonable practice. Racial profiling, she added, was a "systemwide practice," and the two troopers should not have had to bear the burden for that.
"They were singled out, and it's not fair," she said, echoing the contention of the troopers' lawyers, who blamed the officers' superiors for the practices that led to the shooting incident. "They didn't sit in some bar and decide that they were going to go out and do this. They were doing what they were told, and they have suffered enough."
James Toscano, 34, the owner of City Beans Coffee in the Gateway office complex here, said the investigation into the turnpike shooting had not implicated all those it should have. He said he feared that with the combination of the plea deal -- which he said "was not a good thing" -- and the aftermath of the terror attacks, people would move on and not address the problem of profiling.
"There is a very dark view out there across the board after Sept. 11 and a feeling that everybody is no good," said Mr. Toscano, who is white. "When something huge like that happens, people put other things on the back burner."
George Philbert, a 55-year-old real estate salesman, scoffed at the suggestion of some that the barring of the two men from ever serving as New Jersey state troopers was a serious punishment.
"They are white and they will be gainfully employed no matter what," said Mr. Philbert, who is black, as he left a Kmart in West Orange. "Ultimately, this plea and sentence shows an indifference to profiling and to black people's lives, and it sends no signal to anyone that profiling is wrong."
Stephen Pascual, 25, who is Hispanic and works at a Staples in West Orange, said the pleas and sentences left a "bad taste in my mouth," similar to the feelings he had after the many times he had been stopped by police because of what he considered racial profiling.
"There are a lot of rotten apples in the police department and I work hard and try to better myself, but they still only see what is on the outside and the color of my skin," he said. "You hope and you hope that things will change, but hope can die, too."

HEADLINE: Navigating New Jersey's Future 

 BODY:
New Jersey's new governor, James McGreevey, was sworn into office yesterday and delivered an inaugural address about austerity and recovery. It was a speech notably spare of new programs and promises, urging New Jerseyans to "tighten our belts -- not harden our hearts, but tighten our belts and live within our means." 
 Americans will be hearing a lot of that kind of talk from state capitals this year. New Jersey is far from alone in having slashed taxes during the financial boom only to find that there was not enough money to make ends meet when the economy turned sour. But the effects of Sept. 11 and the interest on debt piled up by former Gov. Christie Whitman makes Mr. McGreevey's challenge particularly difficult. He is faced with a budget gap that may be as large as $2.8 billion. To close it he will have to prune spending ruthlessly, slashing not only wasteful programs but desirable ones as well. 
 The new governor did recognize that some crucial needs could not be deferred. Encouragingly, he declared his top priority to be closing the achievement gap in early childhood education between affluent suburban districts and the troubled inner-city schools that the state is already under court order to improve. 
Two other exceptions need to be made from the overall budget-cutting. The state needs to find innovative ways to promote redevelopment in the struggling cities of Newark and Camden and rebuild the environmental enforcement programs gutted during the past eight years of Republican rule. Mr. McGreevey also needs to address several other policy issues that do not come with a big price tag, like rebuilding a more cooperative relationship with New York on regional development issues and eliminating the ugly culture of racial profiling among New Jersey's state police. 
Most of the new governor's first appointments have been encouraging, easing fears that he might use them to pay political debts to the Democratic Party bosses and labor unions that helped him to his easy election victory over the conservative Republican Bret Schundler last November. Instead Mr. McGreevey named a tough-minded outsider, Joseph Santiago, to run the state police, and recruited a nationally respected environmentalist, Bradley Campbell, to run the Department of Environmental Protection. He has also followed through on his campaign pledge to re-create the office of public advocate as an independent monitor of governmental performance.
Mr. McGreevey is undoubtedly conscious of what happened to New Jersey's last Democratic governor, Jim Florio, who also took office during an inherited fiscal emergency. To minimize spending cuts, Mr. Florio pushed through a large and unpopular increase in the state income tax. He never recovered from the ensuing backlash and was driven from office after a single term with most of his reform agenda unachieved. That sobering history has made New Jersey tax hikes virtually unthinkable. However, there has been no comparable test to see how the state's voters would react to deep cuts in critical services. Chances are they would respond with equal levels of hostility.
Mr. McGreevey is walking a narrow path between two political chasms, and he is going to have to figure out how to bring the state back to fiscal health without falling off on either side. So far, his appointments and priorities suggest he is starting on the right track.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REPAIR BILL; 
Kabul Needs $15 Billion, Official Says

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The interim government of Afghanistan needs an immediate infusion of money to keep operating, the head of the United Nations Development Program said today, adding that over the next 10 years, about $15 billion will be required to reconstruct the country.
 The figures outlining the financial needs for Afghanistan were prepared jointly by the United Nations Development Program, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. They were presented at a news conference today by the administrator of the development program, Mark Malloch Brown, as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and other foreign ministers prepared to attend a donors' conference next week in Tokyo to discuss Afghanistan's financial needs. 
 Responding to the plea for financial help, Secretary Powell said today that the United States should be able to help free up this week more than $200 million in frozen funds that could be used to pay government expenses.
On his way to a peacemaking mission in South Asia, a visit to the Afghan capital of Kabul and the conference in Tokyo, Secretary Powell told reporters aboard his plane that, "We're hard at work, and I hope I'll be able to give them some good news," when he meets later this week with the provisional Afghan leader, Hamid Karzai.
According to the financial report, Afghanistan will require $5 billion over the next two and a half years, another $5 billion in the following five years, and a total of $15 billion over 10 years. The high initial sum, Mr. Brown said, reflected the costs of providing security for the country, and the bankruptcy of the country.
"This government has quite literally empty coffers," Mr. Brown said. "There are central bank vaults which are quite empty, which are echo chambers."
Secretary Powell agreed, noting that the short-term money was "really just the beginning, though; they're going to need a lot of help."
"The simplest things are needed," he said, "in order to get this country up and running," from phone systems to security and other infrastructure. All of that is to be addressed at the international conference in Tokyo that will be attended by the United States, the European Union, Saudi Arabia and Japan.
United Nations officials have warned that the Afghan government faces possible collapse if it is unable in the coming days to pay more than 200,000 civil servants and police officers the salaries and back pay they are owed. Those immediate costs are separate from the country's long-term reconstruction needs.
Mr. Brown said it was "enormously important conceptually" for the new coalition administration to start delivering vital services quickly. An entire generation of Afghans, he said, had grown up with no memory of any government delivering any services, so that quickly rebuilding a basic social contract between the government and people was crucial for the long-term stability of the Afghan state.
For its part, the United States is expected to unfreeze $221 million in Afghan government assets frozen after the terror bombings of the American Embassies in Tanzania and Kenya.

HEADLINE: Misdirected Defense Dollars 

 BODY:
It's axiomatic that military budgets grow in wartime, and this year will be no exception. The Bush administration's planned $350 billion Pentagon budget for the next fiscal year is some $20 billion higher than current spending and a 6 percent increase over the rate of inflation. Events since Sept. 11 have clearly demonstrated the need for a highly flexible military force, adequately paid and housed, maintained in a high state of readiness and equipped with the appropriate high-tech tools of 21st-century warfare. 
 Unfortunately, the budget prepared by Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld shortchanges the Bush administration's earlier promises of a boldly transformed military. While some of the new budget money will go toward improved pay and modernization, the Pentagon is still spending too much on costly weapons systems designed for an earlier era, squandering funds that should be going to more rapid modernization. 
 Future phases of the war on terrorism, whether in the Middle East, Africa or Southeast Asia, are likely to bear a closer resemblance to the conflict in Afghanistan than to the cold-war clashes for which the latest generation of weapons systems were designed. Afghanistan highlighted the need for pilotless aircraft and long-range bombers that did not depend on the availability of nearby American air bases. It underscored the importance of light, mobile ground forces, special operations teams and Navy surface ships and submarines that can launch planes and cruise missiles.
Military planners must be ready to fight other kinds of wars as well, but the Pentagon ought to discard obsolete assumptions about the most likely enemies or battlefields. The Air Force, for example, remains committed to the F-22, a short-range tactical fighter designed for cold-war dogfights. America's existing fighter fleet of F-15's, F-16's and the newly approved Joint Strike Fighter already assure aerial supremacy over any conceivable foe for the next generation. Air Force dollars should go to unmanned reconnaissance and attack craft like the Predator, long-range bombers and the troop transport planes that are in chronic short supply. 
The Army should not be building its future around heavy weapons like the 70-ton Crusader howitzer system. The Crusader has many impressive battlefield features, but the Army's bulky equipment and lack of mobility have limited the service's role in Afghanistan and would have made many Army units unsuitable for action in Kosovo had allied ground troops been needed there.
The Navy and Marine Corps have been doing better at modernization, converting submarines to launch cruise missiles instead of nuclear missiles and delaying production of large and expensive stealth destroyers. Still, there is little justification for the Navy to build a new generation of attack submarines.
The Bush administration is right to press ahead with efforts to improve military pay, housing and health care. Those are dollars well spent. Another useful initiative was thwarted by Congress late last year. Secretary Rumsfeld tried to free more money for modernization through another round of base closings. Although about 25 percent of current bases are militarily obsolete, lawmakers postponed action until 2005. 
With the public in a mood to spend more on defense and the conflict in Afghanistan emphasizing the importance of military modernization, this year's budget offered an extraordinary opportunity for Mr. Rumsfeld to call on the various services to update their spending priorities. Instead, he largely bowed to the momentum of familiar weapons programs. It will now be up to Congress to press for more forward-looking budgeting.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Deficit Cloud on Horizon Grows to Ominous Size

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
HE got here by winning over every important Democratic constituency group and alienating none, by smiling and stroking and ingratiating his way across the state and up the ladder of politics.
 Now, New Jersey's new governor, James E. McGreevey, has the enviable title and the unenviable task -- the "joyful burden," he called it, like a priest describing his calling -- of closing a $2.8 billion budgetary hole, with no time to spare and but a single obvious tool at his disposal: the ax. 
 In his inaugural yesterday, Governor McGreevey suggested that restoring the state to fiscal health would take the kind of shared sacrifice seen after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. But whom will he ask first? Where will the blade land? How joyful will the reaction be of those who feel its cut? 
The $2.8 billion number keeps haunting New Jersey's leaders, like snake eyes. Over Mr. McGreevey's right shoulder was Jim Florio, who raised taxes by that amount in his first months as governor in 1990, hoping to fix the state's failing public schools in needy urban districts. Instead, he managed only to demonstrate convincingly that big tax increases are a sure-fire route to a single term.
Nowhere to be seen at the festivities was Christie Whitman, who borrowed $2.8 billion in 1997 in a complicated gamble that her Treasury could recover its costs, and more, by investing in the stock market. That looked prescient as long as the stock market was rising. Now it just looks like a load of debt.
During his campaign last fall, Mr. McGreevey tied his own hands, promising he would neither resort to borrowing nor increases in the sales or income tax. Yesterday, he reaffirmed, "The days of irresponsible borrowing and runaway spending are over."
But the financial challenge he expected during the campaign is now taking on the dimensions of a mushroom cloud. In early December, the departing Republican treasurer put the shortfall in revenues at $700 million. In the space of a month, he revised it to $1.4 billion, then again to $2.4 billion. And that does not include the $400 million in spending added by Republican lawmakers on their way out the door. Next year, officials say, the gap could reach $5 billion.
Mr. McGreevey did not talk much about the ax yesterday. His advisers sound as if they are still holding out hope that a pile of money, or potential savings, will turn up once they get the keys to all the rooms in the State House's steam tunnels and sub-basements.
"We campaigned on eliminating waste and mismanagement," said Steve DeMicco, a media consultant, hinting of big news to come, "but we had no idea."
HIS day-old administration talks about other painless options. The state's Unemployment Insurance Fund, for example, is sitting on nearly $4 billion it didn't have to pay to people who didn't need it because they had jobs. But lawmakers balk, saying using that money to close a budget hole means it won't be there when it is needed by people once employed by Lucent or Ford or whichever company next announces layoffs.
What is more, the labor unions that were joined to Mr. McGreevey's hip throughout his campaign -- the governor thanked John Sweeney, president of the national A.F.L.-C.I.O., for showing up yesterday -- want that unemployment insurance money to be used for paid family leave. No state has such a program, Republicans say, and New Jersey can't afford it. Does Mr. Sweeney agree?
Sales and income taxes are still way, way off the table. But some taxes will rise. One ploy Mr. McGreevey is considering is cutting the property tax rebate known as New Jersey Saver. And the days of cheap gasoline may be numbered: every extra penny a gallon in tax brings in $50 million a year.
Spending will continue to climb, meanwhile, in many areas largely beyond Mr. McGreevey's control, like Medicaid benefits, prescription drug assistance for the elderly, and school aid tied to enrollment.
The schools in New Jersey's cities are still failing, by the way, despite Mr. Florio's efforts a decade ago. Waiting for Mr. McGreevey to show up for a Web chat with fourth graders yesterday, Dashawn Furqan, 9, of Trenton, said he thought that governor were in charge of "school supplies."
Mr. McGreevey had just promised to ensure that every third grader can read. Doing so will mean finding more money for school supplies like more and better teachers.
For the foreseeable future, freeing up that money will only lead the new governor back to the ax.

HEADLINE: Parents Vote Not to Reopen Public School Shut Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
An overwhelming majority of parents from Public School 89, which was shuttered after the World Trade Center attack, voted last night against a Board of Education plan to reopen the school building on Feb. 4.
 Although Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said last month that the school building, on Warren Street near West Street, was safe, and some parents are eager for their children to return, many parents have expressed skepticism, citing potential health issues and psychological harm. 
 "We don't send our children to school to rebuild downtown," said Jodi Carse, whose 6-year-old son and 8-year-old daughter attend the school. "We send them there to educate them." 
The school has already moved twice since the attack: first to a wing of P.S. 3 in Greenwich Village, and then, in October, to a building on the Lower East Side, where the students share a building owned by the Board of Education with a small alternative school. P.S. 89's enrollment has dwindled by almost half since Sept. 11, to 218 from 415.
Sharon Srague, co-chairwoman of the parent-teacher association, , fears that a third relocation in half a year would further depress enrollment. The students and teachers have adapted well to the Lower East Side building, she said, and it would be "inopportune" to disrupt their daily patterns yet again.
Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for the Board of Education, said tests conducted daily by a board contractor at Stuyvesant High School, which is also close to the trade center site, had showed no signs of asbestos since the beginning of December. The opening date for P.S. 89, along with two other schools in the neighborhood, Public Schools 234 and 150, is not negotiable, she said.
"We would not dream of opening any school anywhere if there is any hazard there," Ms. Marshall said. "Some parents want to return in March, some want to return in May, some want to return in September. No matter what we do, some parents are not going to be happy." 
Some members of the parent-teacher association said they would seek legal recourse if Mr. Levy refuses to negotiate. "If he doesn't want to do it, we will get a judge to tell him to do it," Ms. Carse said.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Intel Reports That Earnings For Quarter Beat Estimates

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
Ending its worst year on an upbeat note, the Intel Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded most expectations.
 Although unwilling to call an end to the chip industry's slump, Intel said its sales had jumped 7 percent from the third quarter to the fourth. The company, the world's largest chip maker, attributed the improvement to strong sales of its new flagship product, the Pentium 4 microprocessor for personal computers. 
 Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., became the latest high-technology bellwether to suggest that the troubles facing the industry last year abated somewhat toward the end of the year. Analysts and manufacturers like Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard had predicted dreary holiday sales of personal computers, but said recently that consumers had bought more PC's and other electronic devices than expected. 
"A year that began with economic decline ended on a note of stability," Andy D. Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer, said in a conference call with analysts.
But in a troubling sign for manufacturers of chip-making equipment, Intel cut its spending budget for 2002 by 25 percent, to $5.5 billion from $7.3 billion, a much sharper decline than the 15 percent cut expected by analysts. Mr. Bryant said Intel invested heavily last year in machines that make chips more efficiently, so the company would be able to meet demand for its products this year without spending as much. The news sent the price of shares in equipment makers like Applied Materials tumbling in after-hours trading.
Shares of Intel fell 16 cents, to $34.68, in regular trading, then fell further, to as low as $33.71 in after-hours trading.
For the fourth quarter, which ended Dec. 29, Intel reported earnings of $504 million, or 7 cents a share. The numbers declined sharply from the comparable period in 2000, when Intel turned a profit of $2.2 billion, or 32 cents a share.
After setting aside charges related to acquisitions, Intel earned $998 million, or 15 cents a share, beating estimates by 4 cents a share. Wall Street had expected earnings of 11 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
"There are not a lot of bad things to say here," said Jonathan J. Joseph, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "These guys are doing great."
Intel's smaller businesses continued to struggle, however. The networking division lost $129 million, and the division that makes chips for wireless devices broke even.
Over all, sales were $7 billion, higher than Intel's latest forecast of $6.7 billion to $6.9 billion but down from $8.7 billion in the fourth quarter the previous year.
For the current quarter, Intel predicted sales of $6.4 billion to $7 billion, following the usual pattern of flat or slightly lower revenue from the fourth quarter to the first.
"We haven't seen any evidence of an economic recovery," Mr. Bryant said. "What we have seen is a return to normal seasonal patterns off of a newer economic level."
After a record year in 2000, the bottom fell out of the chip market in the first quarter of 2001. As consumers and large corporations reduced spending on computers, PC makers stopped placing such large orders for chips. Intel and a rival, Advanced Micro Devices, cut prices throughout the year as demand waned.
But the two chip makers have had a small resurgence in demand in the fourth quarter. "There was a surprise upside in Q4 that I don't think anyone, including Intel, expected," said Dean McCarron, a principal analyst with Mercury Research. 
During its fourth-quarter conference call Wednesday, Advanced Micro is expected to post a narrower loss than was expected a few months ago and to say that it is finally able to raise prices on its chips after a year of falling demand.
Intel said today that its average selling prices declined, largely because Microsoft bought so many of Intel's older and less expensive microprocessor, the Pentium III, to power its new Xbox video-game console, which has sold 1.5 million units since its release in November. If not for the purchases by Microsoft, Intel said, its average prices would have been roughly flat.
Despite the declining prices, Intel said it profited from a low-double-digit increase in unit sales of microprocessors, as well as a 16 percent cut in operating expenses from the fourth quarter of 2000. The company said it reduced its work force last year by 7,000 employees, to 83,000, without major layoffs.
Intel said it would spend about half of its $5.5 billion capital expense budget on manufacturing equipment. Research and development costs are expected to increase to $4.1 billion, from $3.8 billion.

HEADLINE: McGREEVEY PLEADS FOR TRENTON UNITY 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan 15 

 BODY:
Declaring that the "days of irresponsible borrowing and runaway spending are over," James E. McGreevey was sworn in as New Jersey's 51st governor today and challenged state residents to help him improve their educational system and deter terrorism even while facing a spiraling fiscal crisis. 
 In an inaugural address notable for its absence of specific program proposals, Mr. McGreevey, 44, assured residents that budget problems need not dampen their ambitions, and must not prevent the state from fulfilling its obligation to provide children with a good education. Pointing to the outpouring of good will after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Mr. McGreevey said that New Jersey could emerge from the recession even stronger if state residents sought to sustain that sense of unity. 
 "So this is my call to action," he said. "In the days ahead, each citizen of New Jersey should demand more of me. That is your right. But you also must ask more of yourselves. That is your responsibility." 
When he took the oath of office at 12:20 p.m. -- flanked by his parents, his wife, Dina Matos, and their infant daughter, Jacqueline -- Mr. McGreevey completed a long and unlikely political journey. As the little-known mayor of Woodbridge, he nearly unseated Gov. Christie Whitman in 1997, and never really stopped campaigning afterward. After putting down several challenges within the party, he easily won victory in November, and his inauguration helped restore Democrats to power 10 years after voters banished them for enacting a $2.8 billion tax increase.
Despite their triumph, however, many Democrats seemed to be bracing for difficult decisions in the months to come as they wrestle with a $2.8 billion budget gap. The new governor and Democratic legislative leaders have vowed not to raise taxes, and Mr. McGreevey's inaugural reference to "irresponsible borrowing," which echoed his criticism of Republicans during the campaign, leaves few options other than deep program cuts or possibly laying off state workers. 
Whatever challenges might await him, Mr. McGreevey seemed determined to relish his day. After a morning prayer service in Princeton, he was greeted by rousing cheers at the War Memorial in Trenton, and took his place at the front of a stage crowded with his friends, family, state legislators, labor leaders, members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation and the former Democratic governors Jim Florio and Brendan T. Byrne. Mrs. Whitman, who stepped down last year to become administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, did not attend, but the three men who served as acting governor in her absence were seated on stage. 
Mr. McGreevey appeared so buoyant as he waited to take his oath that when the American Boys Choir performed the "Hallelujah" Chorus, he could be seen mouthing the words. 
During a 20-minute address that referred to John F. Kennedy, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. McGreevey also quoted from a speech Abraham Lincoln made to the New Jersey Senate in 1861, en route to his own inauguration. Lincoln, he said,marveled at the enormous hardships the Continental Army had endured to defeat the British in the Battle of Trenton in 1776. Lincoln remarked that they must have been inspired by the promise of a new nation.
"Together we must recapture that spirit of Trenton which Lincoln observed," the governor said. "If we can do that, no terrorists will prevail against us. No challenge will discourage us. No legitimate disagreement will cause us to be disagreeable. And no citizen, however humble, will be ignored." 
Virtually the only detailed policy goal Mr. McGreevey stated was a pledge to improve reading levels in grade schools. In some schools 30 percent of third graders read below grade level. Rather than presenting a list of initiatives, Mr. McGreevey instead offered a new approach to problem-solving and said he would reach out to New Jersey residents and institutions that had been excluded from the political process. 
"We need to change the way we think about our problems and change the way we solve them," he said. "We need universities actively engaged in the priorities of the state. We need public-private partnerships that transcend old barriers. We need cooperation between labor and business, Republicans and Democrats, between cities and suburbs." 
Some civil rights leaders were disappointed that the new governor did not mention racial profiling, which has dominated the state's politics since troopers shot three unarmed men during an April 1998 traffic stop on the New Jersey Turnpike. On Monday, the troopers were allowed to plea guilty to reduced charges that spared them jail time and probation, a move that angered many black and Latino New Jerseyans. 
"The governor mentioned Martin Luther King today because it's his birthday," said the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, executive director of the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey. "But Martin Luther King also said that peace isn't just the absence of tension; it's the presence of justice. And African-Americans are tired of being denied justice."
But most of the audience praised Mr. McGreevey for offering optimism without bogging down in detail. Mr. Byrne said Mr. McGreevey's address showed strong leadership because he did not duck tough issues. United States Senator Jon S. Corzine, a fellow Democrat, said he was encouraged that Mr. McGreevey had insisted that fiscal responsibility would be his top priority.
State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., Republican state chairman, said that while Mr. McGreevey's criticism of the state's increased debt during the Whitman administration was language better left to the campaign trail, he thought the speech was effective.
"He did a good job of laying out his priorities, setting his tone," Mr. Kyrillos said. "We've all got to work together because there are some serious issues ahead."
Even as Mr. McGreevey and legislators spoke of bipartisanship and unity, however, there were signs of difficult political battles to come. While Democrats now control the General Assembly, and the State Senate is split 20-20, the McGreevey administration has already spoken to one Republican senator, John Mattheussen, about possibly joining the administration as the commissioner of transportation.
Senator Mattheussen said he had not been formally offered the position and he was not certain he would accept. If he were to join the administration, however, his departure would grant Democrats control of both houses of the Legislature.
And while the inaugural parade was still marching past the State House, the State Senate Judiciary Committee released a letter requesting more information before it would consider confirming Mr. McGreevey's nominee for state police superintendent. The nominee, Joseph Santiago, Newark's police chief, was twice convicted for disorderly conduct, although one conviction was later overturned.
Mr. McGreevey's spokesman, Paul Aronsohn, said the new governor was aware of the incidents and was still convinced that Mr. Santiago was the best candidate.
As he prepared for his inaugural ball, however, Mr. McGreevey spent the day basking in congratulations rather than mapping political strategy. At 4 p.m., when 30 people threw an impromptu rally on the steps of the State House, he invited the entire crowd into his new office.
Mr. McGreevey, to applause, then made his first entrance into the State House as governor.
At the inaugural ball about 9 last night, at the Raritan Center in Edison, Mr. McGreevey gave warm thanks to all who had supported him, and a word of advice to his staff: "All cabinet members, tomorrow morning, governor's office, 8 a.m. Now go and get some sleep."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 19, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the inauguration of James E. McGreevey as governor of New Jersey misstated the name of a choir that performed. It is the American Boychoir, not Boys Choir.
An article about the celebratory mood among Trenton Democrats misstated the uniqueness of Mr. McGreevey's inaugural parade. It was the state's first inaugural parade since Gov. Jim Florio's, in 1990, not the first ever.

PERSON: Clyde Williams 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Clinton Loyalist Puts Faith in a Fortified Harlem

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
CLYDE WILLIAMS, the domestic policy adviser to Bill Clinton, is heading to a bakery down Lenox Avenue in Harlem, a few blocks from Mr. Clinton's new penthouse office. But it's not just any bakery. He opens the door of an elegant new establishment, Settepani, owned by an Eritrean woman who greets him warmly.
 "They got empowerment zone money," points out Mr. Williams, slipping his lean frame behind an Italian marble table for a pot of tea. "And who created the empowerment zones? Clinton. He's had an impact in helping to improve the community already." 
 Mr. Williams, a 39-year-old Washington transplant, has this way of embedding nuggets about his boss's accomplishments during a long chat. He's the loyal lieutenant.
Mr. Williams arrived in Harlem last summer to work for the former president at 55 West 125th Street. Wearing a gray Hugo Boss suit on a recent morning, he reminds you of one of those high-powered types on "The West Wing," the TV show about a fictional White House. He's smart and amiable, yet careful about what he says. His mind seems to work overtime imagining how things will be spun.
So what exactly does a domestic policy adviser do for a former president? Funny that you should ask. Basically, anything the ex-president wants.
For the moment, Mr. Williams's job description extends to the international. He's helping to organize a Jan. 24 conference that Mr. Clinton is sponsoring at New York University, called "Islam and America in a Global World." Mr. Williams says Mr. Clinton wants to keep a dialogue going about religious reconciliation and racial diversity.
But Mr. Williams says they're keeping a close eye on Harlem, too.
"Harlem is the president's home," says Mr. Williams, leaning back. A crisp shirt sleeve reveals silver cuff links shaped like trumpets. (He's a big jazz fan and bought them when Miles Davis died.) "If we can make things work here, we will attempt to replicate them in other places." 
Mr. Williams says his office is developing partnerships to deliver after-school programs and economic education in the public schools, and to provide technical assistance to small Harlem businesses. "He wants to do things to empower underserved communities," he says.
Earlier that morning, back at Mr. Clinton's headquarters, Mr. Williams allows a peek into Mr. Clinton's post-presidential sanctuary. He takes a shortcut through a window-lined conference room, pushing open a hidden door in a wood-paneled wall.
"The president comes out of here and it trips people out," Mr. Williams says with a boyish grin. "They think it's a wall."
Mr. Williams doesn't turn on the lights in the large, oblong office. It's tastefully appointed with paintings by famous black artists like Jacob Lawrence and Romare Bearden. There are family pictures, a photograph of Gandhi; books are everywhere. Mr. Clinton's desk is tidy, with a lone letter awaiting his attention. Mr. Williams steers a visitor away from a quick gander.
So where is the former leader of the free world? Mr. Williams says his boss is coming in later that day. He was in Mexico earlier in the week.
STANDING at the window, Mr. Williams comments on the panoramic view. You can see Central Park and beyond the Triborough Bridge. He's asked if he thinks this view beats the one at Carnegie Hall Tower. Mr. Clinton had considered moving there but abandoned the idea after a barrage of criticism about the high Midtown rent. Mr. Williams says he never set foot in the place.
Next question.
A Howard University graduate, Mr. Williams worked in the Clinton administration as deputy chief of staff for Daniel R. Glickman, the secretary of agriculture. Before that, he was deputy director of presidential scheduling in the White House.
Born and bred in Washington, Mr. Williams is the son of a public school teacher, now retired, in the District of Columbia. His father died of a heart attack when he was 3. He got interested in politics as a teenager because a friend's father, Harry Thomas Sr., was a City Council member. 
"People naturally gravitate toward things they find interesting; I'm a doer," he says.
When he talks about his hometown, he sounds a bit wistful. He says it defined him. "It's such a political city." He's also a newlywed. His wife, Mona Sutphen, the vice president of a consulting company run by the former national security adviser Sandy Berger, still lives there. He rents a small Harlem apartment.
For the last few months, Mr. Williams has been ushering a steady stream of Harlem leaders and residents into his office to get the lay of the land. In Mr. Clinton's office of 13 staff members, Mr. Williams answers only to Maggie Williams, the chief of staff, who is no relation, and the president.
Some Harlem insiders do not envy Mr. Williams his task of managing the expectations of a community that has embraced Mr. Clinton, and quite frankly hopes for something in return. Lloyd Williams, president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, says he, for one, is impatient with Mr. Clinton's pace.
But Clyde Williams is upbeat, saying that he sees only challenges. "The challenges are trying to get things done with a lot less," he says. "When President Clinton was president, it was a lot easier to implement things. You had the resources of the federal government. Now, it's not as easy. Yet I think he will find a way to get things done that are important to him."

HEADLINE: A Moment to Seize in Kashmir 

BYLINE:  By Ayesha Siddiqa-Agha; Ayesha Siddiqa-Agha, author of "Pakistan's Arms Procurement and Military Buildup, 1979-99," is former director of naval research for the Pakistan Navy and a defense analyst.

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan 

 BODY:
The national address by President Pervez Musharraf on Saturday has been praised both in Pakistan and internationally, but it has also generated debate on the real intent behind it. While setting a new agenda of arresting Islamic militants in de-escalating the immediate tension with India, the speech fell short of announcing any major changes in Pakistan's support for Kashmir's struggle to become part of Pakistan. The Indian government appeared less impressed than the international press precisely because the speech did not indicate any fundamental policy change. In fact General Musharraf reiterated that the Kashmir issue "runs in our Pakistani blood."
 Yet in Islamabad the discussion is whether it was entirely India's belligerence that motivated General Musharraf's stronger antiterrorist measures. Most people here view his objective as staving off an attack from India or, more pragmatically, making possible the demobilization of Pakistani forces on the Indian border, which would reduce the burden on Pakistan's military, currently also mobilized on the Afghan border. 
 Many analysts in Pakistan were also worried about the security of its nuclear assets. The fear was that any escalation of the conflict might lead the United States to use special forces to eliminate Islamabad's nuclear arsenal, perhaps in joint action with the Indians, to avoid the risk of a nuclear war. This fear helped justify the decision by General Musharraf to announce measures that would appease Washington and New Delhi.
A general perception in Pakistan is that both the escalation of tension and now its de-escalation came out of increased American involvement in the region. The view is that Washington used New Delhi to put pressure on Pakistan to rein in the militants who were operating on multiple fronts in Afghanistan and Kashmir -- and that without America's tacit support, India would not have resorted to this kind of mobilization of forces. At the same time, many also remain certain that Washington would have worked to avoid an actual outbreak of conflict. Interestingly, a segment of Islamabad's policy makers believe that a prolonged American presence in the region can be an effective deterrent against the outbreak of hostilities. They also welcome American presence as an opportunity for future economic development.
A reversal of Islamabad's policy on Kashmiri militancy benefits Washington's interests and New Delhi's -- and in the long term, Islamabad's interests as well. None of this would be possible without the new American strategic interest and presence in the region.
From the American standpoint, curbing Pakistani militancy is part of addressing the greater problem of eliminating international terrorist networks. From the Indian perspective, reining in the militants would reduce the violent struggle inside Indian-occupied Kashmir and provide an indirect advantage to Indian forces in that area. Even a temporary weakening of Islamabad's policy on Kashmiri militancy would help in breaking the momentum that the struggle to break from India had gained inside the Kashmir valley.
These changes are not easily embraced by Islamabad. But they become more acceptable if they open the door to finding a solution to this territorial dispute, ideally through multilateral means. Pakistan has always been interested in having a third party, preferably America, involved in negotiating a resolution. General Musharraf hinted at allowing the Kashmiris to choose a third option -- an independent Kashmir -- as a possible solution.
India should take advantage of General Musharraf's conciliatory measures in controlling the militants. The fact is that his team of senior generals will not simply allow the Kashmir issue to die down. That is why India needs to see this moment as an opportunity -- made possible by international pressures on Pakistan -- to solve the Kashmir question permanently.
Still, much will depend on Washington's taking an active role. Before the attack on the Indian Parliament in December, the American ambassador in Pakistan had been discussing the possibility of turning the line of control between India and Pakistan in Kashmir into an international boundary. Such a change would give legitimacy to both countries' control of their parts of Kashmir. The Musharraf regime, in risking domestic opposition by its crackdown on Islamic militants, would want a better solution than this.
The question is whether the United States can persuade India to accept a different type of deal. A solution may not be found in the next six months. But the present moment offers the South Asian rivals a chance to establish the terms of negotiations that might lead to a solution in the next two to three years.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Citigroup Names New President Amid Talk of More Acquisitions

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Citigroup filled the long-vacant job of president yesterday amid talk that its chief executive, Sanford I. Weill, is preparing to go on the acquisition trail yet again.
 Robert B. Willumstad, who has overseen the company's vast and highly profitable consumer business, becomes president, a position unfilled since the departure of James Dimon in November 1998. 
 Analysts said yesterday that the appointment appeared to place Mr. Willumstad, 56, as the leading candidate to succeed Mr. Weill, 68, and reinforces the importance of the consumer operation, which accounts for half of Citigroup's profits. "We think it's a great business," Mr. Weill said in an interview yesterday. 
Some bankers and investors expect Mr. Weill to make further acquisitions in consumer banking after receiving an estimated $5 billion in proceeds later this year from the spinoff of the property and casualty insurance business. A likely target, these bankers and investors say, is FleetBoston Financial, the Boston-based company that is confronting large losses from its banking business in Argentina.
Mr. Weill met with Terrence Murray, the chairman of Fleet, last summer, according to executives close to the conversation. Mr. Murray stepped down as chief executive at the end of the year and was replaced by Charles K. Gifford, previously president of the bank and before that chief executive of BankBoston, which merged with Fleet in October 1999.
The meeting was social, an executive close to the conversation said. At least three executives said the topic of a merger was broached. While nothing came of the conversation, the investment bankers and investors said the two banks would fit well together. "He sold his bank once before," one banker said of Mr. Gifford, referring to the merger of Bank of Boston and Fleet. "He will make the decision that is right for shareholders."
The question is whether Mr. Gifford will want to sell now. Fleet's stock has fallen 15 percent over the last year, partly because of its business in recession-plagued Argentina, as well as poor performance in its corporate banking and venture capital businesses.
James Mahoney, a spokesman for Fleet, denied that a merger was in the works. "Chad has just taken the reins," Mr. Mahoney said. "The strategy is in place to grow the franchise, and we're optimistic about 2002." Mr. Weill declined to specifically discuss Fleet or comment at all about how he anticipated using the proceeds from the spinoff. "We don't even have that money yet," he said. 
Though a partnership might have to wait for Fleet's stock to recover some, analysts said a pairing could make sense.
"Citigroup is the biggest financial services conglomerate in the country, but in terms of retail banking deposits, they aren't the largest," said Thomas Goggins, manager of the John Hancock Financial Industries Fund. "Certainly having a bigger footprint in the United States may not be a bad idea."
The consumer deposit business is strong right now, as investors burned by the stock market over the last two years seek the safe haven of bank accounts. Citigroup acquired European-American Bank last year for $1.6 billion.
Citigroup ranks sixth in terms of United States retail deposits, according to SNL Securities, a data concern focused on the banking industry. Citigroup had $121 billion in United States deposits as of Sept. 30, compared with $314 billion for the leader, Bank of America. 
Citigroup and Fleet overlap in New York, Connecticut, New Jersey and Florida, according to SNL, but Citigroup has no presence in several New England states where Fleet is a dominant presence, including Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire and Rhode Island.
A purchase of Fleet would also win Citigroup an expanded presence in Latin America, where Citigroup has been expanding. Citigroup acquired Mexico's second largest bank, Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, in August. Although Fleet's Argentina business does not look too attractive now, the company also has a presence in Brazil. Latin America accounted for 3 percent of Fleet's earnings last year; the region accounted for about 12 percent of Citigroup's profits in the third quarter, stock analysts said.
"The rumor about Citigroup and Fleet has been around for a long time," said Ronald Mandle, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein. A retail banking acquisition could make sense, he said, but Citigroup might prefer a bank with branches in faster growing states, like Florida, California or Texas.
Citigroup's consumer business, which includes credit cards, consumer deposits and loans, has been quite profitable. The third quarter was a tough one for Citigroup and other banks because of the economic disruption of the September terrorist attacks, but the company's global consumer business reported a 26 percent increase in earnings before nonrecurring charges.
The performance helped Mr. Willumstad get the nod from Mr. Weill, who has worked with him since 1987. That year, Mr. Willumstad joined Commercial Credit, a finance company Mr. Weill then ran and a predecessor to Citigroup. He went on to run the consumer lending businesses as Mr. Weill's empire expanded. He will continue to run Citigroup's consumer group, as well as oversee the company's financial and human resource functions, the company said.
"I have had the opportunity to see the company grow, and I have seen Sandy's management style and attention to detail," Mr. Willumstad said.
"He and Sandy go way back," said Richard Strauss, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, about Mr. Willumstad. "Like Sandy, Bob is focused on the bottom line and on expense controls."
The appointment may also ease investors' fears about the lack of a successor for Mr. Weill. There has been uncertainty on the matter ever since the departure of Mr. Dimon, now the chief executive of Bank One Corporation. Mr. Dimon was fired abruptly after rumors that Mr. Weill was unhappy with the way Mr. Dimon had treated Mr. Weill's daughter, who earlier had run the mutual fund business of Salomon Smith Barney.
"Succession has been on a lot of investors' minds," said Henry Dickson, a stock analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Still, analysts and Mr. Weill noted that he had no plans to leave soon and could still anoint someone else. "This is not about that," Mr. Weill said. "I'm a pretty straightforward person, and if that's what I wanted to signal, that's what I would have said. At the time it's appropriate for Citigroup to name a successor, we will name a successor."

HEADLINE: Excess State Spending 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Our Wretched States," by Paul Krugman (column, Jan. 11): 
 Tax cuts did not cause the current fiscal crisis in the states. 
A report we recently released found that states spent two of every three surplus dollars on new government programs.
Mr. Krugman acknowledges that states spent a lot of money in the past decade but dismisses this by suggesting that state spending was at "about" the same level, as a percentage of gross domestic product, at the end of the decade as it was at the beginning. That state spending remained constant as a share of G.D.P. in a growing economy proves that the state governments were growing too big and too fat.
Higher state spending always means higher taxes, and the faster our state policy makers understand this, the faster our economy will resume its upward course.

CHRIS ATKINS
Washington, Jan. 11, 2002

The writer is director of the tax and fiscal policy task force, American Legislative Exchange Council.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
'Cheese!' To 'Print,' In One Step

BYLINE:  By David Pogue 

 BODY:
THE digital age has done wonders for photography. Once you had to take your film to the mall for developing. But today you can eliminate all that expensive hassle with little more than a $600 digital camera, a $300 printer and a $1,000 computer. Just connect the camera to the computer with a U.S.B. cable; copy your multimegabyte JPEG files to the hard drive; open the photos in an image-processing program; rotate and crop each one, adjusting the color; calculate the pixel density and desired output dimensions -- and then click on Print. What could be simpler?
 If you're among the millions of Americans who don't have a computer -- and even if you're not -- the answer may well be "Almost anything." 
 But times are changing. Canon, Hewlett-Packard and Epson have recently hit upon a clever invention that vastly simplifies the route from camera to paper: direct-print photo printers. 
In most regards, these machines look and work just as other color inkjets do. If you have a Macintosh or a PC, you can use them for everyday printing. But if not, you can insert a digital camera's memory card. At the press of a button, you get photos printed straight from the card, 100 percent computer-free. 
If your digital camera has enough resolution (use a two-megapixel camera for 4-by-6-inch prints, three or four megapixels for 8-by-10's), and if you print on premium, glossy photo paper (typically $20 for 25 8-by-10-inch sheets), the printouts are generally indistinguishable from film prints developed at drugstores. The colors are bright, saturated and even-toned, free of the pixel patterns that once gave away inkjet prints. 
Cutting the PC out of the loop, however, also means sacrificing its screen. The biggest problem the printer makers had to solve, then, was this: How do you indicate which photos you want to print?
Three options await. The best, and the most expensive, is to pay an extra $100 (or $200, in HP's case) to have your printer equipped with a compact two-inch screen of its own. This little display shows precisely what you'll get when you press Print -- a preview that's especially useful when you start getting fancy with your photo layouts, printing three or four pictures per page, for example.
The second, more economical method is to choose your pictures while they're still in the camera. Most modern digicams offer a feature called DPOF (digital print order format), a system of flagging pictures on the camera's screen. Then, when you transfer the memory card to the printer, you'll get just the shots you requested.
Finally, each printer can print out an index page filled with numbered, stamp-size miniatures of the photos on the memory card. After examining this gallery, you can use the printer's front panel to tap in the desired picture numbers.
If it's simplicity you crave, consider HP's PhotoSmart 1315 ($400), which offers a long list of exclusive, thoughtful touches. For starters, you don't have to specify what kind of paper you've inserted (plain, glossy or whatever), because a sensor determines the answer automatically. You won't have to fiddle with a card adapter to accommodate your camera's memory card, either, as you must on rival printers. The PhotoSmart has two card slots. Between them, almost any kind of card is covered: CompactFlash, Smart Media, I.B.M. Microdrive, Memory Stick and so on. 
Then there's the PhotoSmart 1315's built-in screen, which makes it simple to choose the pictures you want to print. (Its sibling the 1115 lacks the screen but costs $200 less.) If you're willing to push a couple of buttons, you can also use the screen to rotate, enlarge or crop your photos before you print -- another feature missing from the Canon and Epson models. And in times of trouble, the screen displays prose that could win the Pulitzer Prize for high-tech clarity: "Memory card in backwards. The front label should face you." (This printer should teach a master class in error-message writing to the programmers of Microsoft Windows.)
In fact, the PhotoSmart is so superbly designed and filled with pleasant surprises that it seems almost ungrateful to bring up its sole weakness: printing photos. 
The problem is HP's cartridge, which has only four colors of ink. This limited palette simply can't compete with the range and subtlety offered by the six-color cartridges from Canon and Epson. Worse, looking closely at the PhotoSmart's prints reveals, in spots, the tiny telltale patterns of an inkjet nozzle. The pictures are still very good, but don't expect them to pass the Neighbor Test, in which droppers-by mistake them for photo-lab prints.
Canon's S820D, available next month, and Epson's Stylus Photo 785EPX are more similar than they are different. Their six-color cartridges produce amazing-looking photos that if printed on premium paper and mounted under glass, the companies say, will remain colorfast for 25 years. (The inks don't run when wet, either -- good news for shutterbugs on the high seas.) 
Each company offers its own color-boosting technology that at your option makes colors brighter and slightly more saturated than they were in nature. (According to printer-company research, Americans tend to prefer this look in their photos.) And both machines can print all the way to the edge of the paper, making borderless photos that look exactly like photo-lab prints -- a feat that must leave HP's printer red, green and blue with envy.
These printers have only a single card slot each, which requires an appropriately shaped adapter for most camera cards. A CompactFlash adapter comes in the box. (If your camera uses some other format, Epson lets you trade in the included adapter for the one you need. With the Canon, buying a different adapter is left to you.)
But there's one big difference between these otherwise similar printers. At $400 (without screen), the Canon costs twice as much as the Epson. 
Canon explains the differential by pointing out some of the S820D's exclusive features. First, you can replace the printer's ink cartridges independently. On the Epson and HP machines, you have to throw out the entire color cartridge whenever one color runs out -- a distressing experience for anyone not in Oprah Winfrey's tax bracket. (Cartridges are expensive. Canon's color cartridges are $12 each and last for about 500 pages. Epson's is $18, good for 220 pages. HP's is $35, good for 450 pages. Note that these statistics are based on 15 percent coverage of each page. For photo printing, that percentage is a bit optimistic unless you do most of your shooting on an all-white glacier.) 
Canon also points out that you can connect its printer directly to a Canon PowerShot S30 or S40 camera, eliminating that transferring-the-memory-card ritual. The Canon is quieter and faster than the Epson, too, though even its speeds are nothing to write home about: 4.5 minutes per borderless 4-by-6-inch print versus 7.5 minutes on the Epson. (These are direct-from-card times. Printing from a computer is much faster.) 
Above all, Canon claims superior print quality, including finer resolution when printing from a memory card (1,200 dots per inch, like the HP, compared with Epson's 720). And sure enough, in my expanded, somewhat institutionalized version of the Neighbor Test, a panel of guest eyeballs rated most Canon prints marginally superior to Epson prints. 
But few said they saw $200 worth of difference. The Canon is the best direct-connect inkjet printer money can buy; it's just too bad you need so much money to buy it. At $200 (plus $100 for the screen, if you like), the Epson is a spectacular value. 
Both printers bring digital photography a quantum leap closer to Fotomat simplicity. With a digital camera and one of these printers, you may still occasionally want to visit the mall -- but it won't be to drop off film. It will be to spend the $1,000 you saved by not buying a computer.

HEADLINE: Lincoln Center's Future 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Possibilities of Lincoln Center" (editorial, Jan. 13): 
 The performing companies of Lincoln Center are far from "reeling" from the effects of Sept. 11 and the recession. 
Yes, subscriptions are down, box office is off and the fund-raising climate is tough. We're all struggling to achieve balanced budgets, but no one doubts that we will go on. 
Your reference to "protracted wrangling" of the resident companies as we consider the visionary changes for the public spaces does not describe our experience. We have engaged in passionate discussions about how best to accomplish the goals of making our buildings and the 16 acres on which they sit more inviting, inclusionary and functional. The process has brought us into a close and exhilarating collaboration unknown in the first 40 years of Lincoln Center.
Lincoln Center will renew and rebuild itself.

BERNARD GERSTEN
Executive Producer
Lincoln Center Theater
New York, Jan. 14, 2002

HEADLINE: Prices You Just Can't Believe 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

 BODY:
JVC'S Web site is extensive and easy to navigate. Descriptions of the company's merchandise are more than adequate; pictures are large and clear; each product is clearly linked to similar JVC devices for comparison.
 Only one thing is baffling: the manufacturer's suggested retail price often bears no relationship to what you would be charged by a retailer. 
 Take, for instance, the GR-DVL815U, a mini-digital video camcorder that doubles as a digital still camera. It has a color viewfinder, a special gadget that brightens the picture in low light, a U.S.B. terminal and a serial port. JVC suggests a retail price of $1,099.95. But this week Circuit City was selling it for $799.99. So, give or take a few cents, were BestBuy and CDW.com. At Amazon.com, it was $699.99. 
"And I assume you could get similar prices most anywhere else, too," said a JVC spokesman who said he wished to remain unidentified for fear of angering his bosses, his competitors and the big retailers. "The only thing I can say is that the list price, or M.S.R.P., or whatever you want to call it, is the highest-value price we give. It's a guideline for retailers, but we can't tell them what to charge. Pricing is about strategy, and we assume everyone has one." 
Compared with that of other consumer items, from clothing to cars to furniture to toothbrushes, the gap between the prices routinely quoted by manufacturer and retailer is large in consumer electronics. Manufacturers are reluctant to discuss why this is so, but analysts say the gap is likely to continue for a number of reasons. 
"The simplest thing to say is that we have trained the consumer electronics buyer to think he is getting 20 or 30 or 40 percent off," said Robert Atkins, a vice president at Mercer Management Consulting in Lexington, Mass. "What does that mean, anyway? Forty percent off what? Some unrealistic price? But once you get something like this going, it stays around." 
But if no one is going to pay the $1,100 that JVC says the GR-DVL815U is worth, why bother putting that price on a Web site? "I do find it amusing," said David Heim, managing editor of Consumer Reports. "It seems to take unmitigated gall for a company to put out a suggested retail price when there are these places like mySimon or CNET" -- comparison Web sites -- "where you can find what everyone is selling it for. But I think it comes back to our tradition that there has to be some benchmark. You can't have a discount until there is a price to discount it from." 
David J. Reibstein, a professor of marketing at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said that it would be a bit too harsh to describe manufacturers' list prices as a ruse.
"There is no question the intent of mentioning the M.S.R.P. from which a discount is offered is indeed to give the consumer the sense that they are getting a bargain," he said. "The retailers do want the manufacturers to specify a suggested price for them to discount from. If they are willing to take a lower margin than what the manufacturer is pushing, they at least would like the consumer to know it."
"Without the articulation of the M.S.R.P.," he said, "the consumer would not know there is any 'discounting' going on." 
Perhaps that accounts for the pricing of RCA's P61310, a 61-inch two-tuner picture-in-picture television set. The manufacturer suggests a price of $3,999, but RCA.com itself is selling the model for $3,499.
Sally Smith Clemens, product manager for the electronics manufacturer Olympus America, acknowledges that the official price is a moving target.
"Really, it is just a reference, a debarkation point, if you will, sort of the maximum value a consumer or retailer could place on an item," she said. "Sure, it is a psychological thing, too, so that people can see they are getting something of value for less than its top price. The consumer will feel much better about that. Still, we feel as manufacturers that it is important to establish some benchmark, if only to start talking about price." 
(An Olympus representative recently told Circuits that the "correct price" for one of its cameras was $899, although the list price was $100 higher. Because many products described in Circuits are just reaching stores and a prevailing retail price has not been established, list prices are generally cited as a benchmark.) 
Although every retailer from Bloomingdale's to Filene's Basement to the local luxury car dealership advertises sales, Robert Schindler, an associate professor of marketing at Rutgers University, said that consumer electronics items have a different kind of shelf space.
"Because consumer electronics are easily comparable products, it is simpler for a buyer to price-shop," Professor Schindler said. "Model 72C for a large-screen brand-name TV is the same whatever store you go to and pretty comparable to some other brand-name TV of similar size. In clothing, well, the fit may be different and you might like red or stripes or whatever." 
Electronics retailers say they decline to reveal their pricing strategies to avoid alerting competitors but that the list price is hardly something to which they pay attention. 
"When it comes to pricing, we have our own way of doing things," said Jim Babb, a marketing spokesman for Circuit City. "Manufacturers can put whatever price they want down, but we do what we think is best for our business." 
Lately, though, the discrepancy between list price and the prevailing retail price, or street price, seems even greater than usual. David Huether, the chief economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said that inventories of consumer electronics were unusually high over the last year and that both manufacturers and retailers had been successfully whittling them down through price breaks. In addition, he said, the strong dollar has made imported parts cheaper, giving the manufacturers wiggle room in wholesale prices, with the savings then passed on to consumers. 
And new products, or at least moderately different models, are coming out all the time. Mr. Huether said the product cycle for consumer electronics had accelerated in recent years. This winter's six-CD changer becomes the spring's seven-CD changer, so the old one is rapidly put on sale, though its list price remains the same. 
In any case, Professor Schindler said, to the extent that anyone refers to the list price, everyone winds up happy. 
"No one on the selling side is sad about this, I don't think," he said. "The manufacturer gets sales. The retailer gets the buyer to think he is getting a bargain. And the buyer gets the item he wants at a price he thinks is good." 
In the end, indeed, it all seems to come down to expectations. "Surveys have shown that when people are asked about the last expensive item they bought -- furniture or a big TV or whatever -- whether they bought it on sale, 75 percent say yes," Professor Schindler said. "But think about that. If 75 percent is bought on sale, then what is the real price and what is the sale price anyway?"

HEADLINE: TURF; 
Buyers Are at The Door Again

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THE winter apartment-hunting season in Manhattan, which began around Thanksgiving -- normally the deadest of times for co-op and condo sales -- is bursting with activity.
 Brokers say this traditionally moribund period has come alive with wheeling and dealing. Open houses, which allow apartment shoppers to browse without tying themselves down to one company or agent, have become a weekend pastime. Hundreds of New Yorkers, starved for a real estate fix after the bleak weeks in September and October, are swarming through studios and multiroom maisonettes alike. 
 And a significant number are buying. Jonathan J. Miller, president of Miller Samuel, a large Manhattan appraisal company, said that 174 clients signed contracts for cooperative apartments or condominiums between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15, an increase of 7.4 percent over the same period a year ago. Diane N. Ramirez, president of Halstead Property, said her company had 21 offers accepted by sellers the first two weeks in November, and 37 the first two weeks of this month. 
"There is definitely a pickup in the number of sales in the last two months," Mr. Miller said. "But the most noticeable thing is how busy the agents are. People are buying, but it takes many more showings. A year ago, it might take 35 or 40 showings before someone would purchase. Now it's 75 or 80." 
Prices, on average, are down about 10 percent from the heights they reached in March 2000, but deals are being made at a pace that agents call surprising: they were braced for a real estate recession, with plummeting prices and nobody showing up, even to look.
A smattering of serious buyers who were scared away after Sept. 11 -- some of whom dropped out of deals that they and the sellers had agreed upon -- have resumed bidding. One woman backed out of a deal for a $1.1 million co-op on East 75th Street, but when she tried to get back in, for $970,000 this time, she was too late. Another bidder got there first, paying the lower figure.
Her experience characterizes the current market, said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Associates. He said that, for New Yorkers, not shopping for co-ops has become unbearable. "People's gratification can only be delayed so long," he said.
Mr. Peters and other agents find a combination of reasons for the return of the real estate shopper: a willingness by sellers to set more realistic prices, the fall in interest rates and the belief that, barring another catastrophe, "the sky hasn't fallen in," said Barbara S. Fox, president of the Fox Residential Group.
Brokers had predicted that after the attacks, apartment owners would panic and rush to put their places on the market, creating a glut and causing prices to plummet. While almost 2,000 new listings did appear, brokers say that the market has not been flooded. Ms. Fox said steady buying is absorbing the post-Sept. 11 surplus. "The buyers now are certainly more wary, and afraid of overspending, but people are really stepping up to the plate to buy," she said.
Barbara Corcoran, chairwoman of the Corcoran Group, said many of her buyers had liquidated their stock portfolios and put the money into real estate. She said that since Sept. 11, an increasing number of customers had used cash, rather than mortgages, to cover 60 percent or more of the prices for co-ops and condos. (Co-ops in Manhattan require 25 percent cash, on average.)
"The floodgates have opened," she said. She also said that in the last six or seven weeks, she had seen more buyers from overseas. "We had a big billion-dollar international media campaign talking about how warm and cozy New York is, and what heroes we've got -- and it worked."
Although current activity won't be reflected in citywide statistics until quarterly reports are compiled by the real estate industry at the end of March, brokers say that more people are out there kicking baseboards and slamming doors. Mr. Peters said he had 27 accepted offers between Thanksgiving and Christmas, as against about 15 in the same period a year earlier. Not every company has had an increase, but brokers say the market has gathered momentum in the last month.
Lawrence Sicular, chief real estate analyst for Brown Harris Stevens, said prices remain surprisingly stable and may even be slightly higher than at summer's end, except at the highest levels. In the multimillion-dollar market, he said prices were "softening." (As has been reported, Manhattan rents are also softening: they have dropped by 10 to 30 percent since the attacks, agents say, partly because more people are turning away from renting and are buying instead.)
Agents are not so sanguine about sales downtown, the area that suffered most after the attacks. Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, a trade group, said that although the market appears healthy, she is awaiting statistics on that area. "We won't see those for another two months," she said.
But elsewhere in Manhattan, agents who were urging both buyers and sellers not to panic a month ago are now warning sellers against irrational exuberance.
"It would be irresponsible to paint a totally happy picture, as if 9/11 had never happened," said Paul Purcell, president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, the largest real estate company in the city. "Could real estate really be the only business that is going up? I don't think so." The number of accepted offers at his company is still down 10 to 15 percent from a year ago, he said.
Nevertheless, he is encouraged by the number of people out shopping. A year ago, in the midst of a hot market, a good turnout at an open house would have been 8 to 25, depending on the property.
Toni D. Haber, an agent at Douglas Elliman, reported that the weekend before last, 65 people showed up at 250 West 89th Street for an open house at a two-bedroom, two-bathroom "condop" (which has shares, like a co-op, but less restrictive rules, like a condominium). Two bidders are now competing for the apartment, which was listed at $680,000, Ms. Haber said. Another open house that weekend drew 100 sightseers, though no offers have been made yet.
Last weekend, a studio at 67 East 11th Street, listed at $214,000, had 43 visitors and two offers. (That number of visitors is rare for a studio, especially at such a high price.) 
An advertisement for an open house at a one-bedroom co-op at 311 West 82nd Street drew two offers, Mr. Purcell said, even though it gave an incorrect telephone number for the broker and misstated the price. (It did get the address right.)
"It feels like we have a horse race again," he said.
Ms. Ramirez, of Halstead, agreed. "The open houses are a phenomenon," she said. "My brokers are telling me 50 people came to this one, 60 to that."
The bounce-back in Manhattan's sales market is turning brokers into psychiatrists, Ms. Ramirez said. "We're all trying to figure out why it's happening." She said she thinks people are pouring into open houses because they are "still not ready to commit to a broker." For some, open houses provide a certain distance: they can look and shop without being interrogated by a broker about their income or intentions. Working with a broker is like going steady, while cruising open houses is more like dating around.
"Now they've got a taste of freedom after being squeezed by the ridiculously high prices" of 1999 and 2000, Ms. Ramirez said. "They do want to buy, but they don't want to feel they're being put in a corner."
When the price is right, buyers are not averse to engaging in bidding wars. "The sellers were pushing for the escalation of prices," Ms. Ramirez said. "They just didn't get that the market was leveling off, even before Sept. 11. But they're starting to get it, and they're either reducing their prices or putting their places on the market for reasonable amounts.
"We thought during December, things would be dead in the water, but our brokers were out there pounding the pavement Christmas week."
