HEADLINE: Argentine Peso Sinks to New Lows as CrisisContinues 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
The Argentine peso plunged to new lows today as the Argentine central bank tried for a second time to stabilize its value by selling dollars. 
 In four days of official trading since the official peg of the peso at parity to the dollar was broken, the Argentine currency has lost nearly half its value. It closed today at 1.85 to the dollar, with some trades at 2.2 to the dollar reported before the central bank's intervention. 
 Demonstrations and rioting continued across the country over the economic crisis and over continuing restrictions on Argentines' access to their bank accounts. But the embattled new government of Eduardo Duhalde won a bit of breathing space today when the International Monetary Fund announced in Washington that it would postpone for a year a debt of $993 million that Argentina was due to pay it on Thursday. 
Still, economists say the peso will go on sliding until the government puts in place credible fiscal and monetary policies that can begin to rebuild confidence in the country's sputtering economy.
"They probably have a couple of weeks to create these policies," said Daniel Artana, chief economist at the Foundation for Latin American Economic Research. "The economic indicators are very bad, and companies are being squeezed. We are already starting to see complications."
New currency and banking regulations are being announced and revised every day. Confusion and mistrust are rampant, and each new rumor sends people running to exchange houses.
The central bank did not say how many dollars it injected into the market today. On Tuesday it sold $8.8 million of its dwindling foreign reserves to currency exchange houses when the peso slipped below the psychologically important level of 2 to 1. One-quarter of the nation's foreign-currency reserves have leaked away in the last three months as bank depositors, fearful of devaluation, put their savings under the mattress or sent them abroad; about $14.8 billion is reportedly left.
Restrictions imposed last month to head off a run on the nation's banks were tightened last week when the government ordered all checking accounts with balances of more than $10,000 and all savings accounts of more than $3,000 converted into certificates of deposit that cannot be redeemed until various dates next year. More than one-third of Argentines' $67 billion in savings were frozen. The government had already put limits on cash withdrawals from all accounts, and on various kinds of transfers, and the banks and exchange houses were closed for days.
The freezing of the banking system also means that securities trades cannot be cleared, so the stock market remains closed.
The restrictions have dragged the already stumbling economy to a halt, complicating the government's attempts to balance its budget. The government said today that it would send a finished budget to Congress next week. Mr. Duhalde promised to ease the banking freeze this week, but he has several times put off an announcement for further study.
Economists inside and outside the government say the rules have put the government in a bind. Depositors, they say, are sure to react to any easing by withdrawing as much money as they can and racing to turn it into dollars, causing the peso to plummet. Or they might spend it, perhaps igniting hyperinflation.
But the government fears that keeping the restrictions in place -- or converting all deposits to pesos, as the banks favor -- would inflame social unrest beyond what the authorities can contain.
Only with international backing, analysts said, can sweeping changes be made that will rebuild public confidence in the financial system and in basic property rights.
"The only thing that can create a big change in expectations sufficient for people to start going on with their normal lives, consuming and investing and so on," said Miguel Braun, director of fiscal policy at a local public policy research group, Cippec, "is if they see that from now on Argentina is going to be a different place from what it has been in the past few months."
The president of the central bank in neighboring Brazil, Arminio Fraga, who successfully restored confidence after that country's currency devaluation in 1999, has been in Buenos Aires for the last two days sharing his experiences with Argentina's central bankers.

HEADLINE: The Twain You'll Meet 

BYLINE:  By Roy Blount Jr.; Roy Blount Jr.'s most recent book is "Am I Pig Enough for You Yet?"

DATELINE: MILL RIVER, Mass. 

 BODY:
In Mark Twain's first best seller, "Innocents Abroad," a rhapsodic Italian guide exposes him and his traveling companions to a bust of "Christopher Columbo." The Americans drive the guide to distraction by refusing to be impressed -- by professing, in fact, never to have heard of the gentleman. "Which is the bust and which is the pedestal?" they ask (a distinction that needs clarifying with regard to so many works of art), and "Is -- is he dead?"
 Mark Twain himself has been dead now, in the narrowest sense, for 97 years. He is, if anything, more solidly empedestaled than Columbus. Somehow, though, he is alive and kicking. Having become, this week, a Ken Burns television series, Mark Twain stands preserved beside the Civil War, baseball and jazz. Among these institutions, he was least in need of mixed-media restoration. He is still fresh. 
 "I think we never become really and genuinely our entire and honest selves," he said, "until we are dead -- and then not until we have been dead years and years. People ought to start dead and then they would be honest so much earlier."
Ralph Waldo Emerson seemed determined to produce an aphorism in every sentence, and today his sentences are beaded with sweat. Twain's float. Like the best-turned bits of Scripture, his observations (including many that he never in fact made) are quotable by most everyone to most any purpose.
He also survives visually, as a distinct white-suited image on the sentimental cultural retina. A great self-marketer he was, and still is. His characters and some of his novels are irresistibly, if seldom satisfactorily, adaptable to the screen. His life and his place in history -- he discovered a great deal more of America than Columbus did -- continue to energize scholars and popular biographers.
But you could strip him down to his words on the page, and he would still be "full of animation," like the aforementioned Italian guide, who "fidgeted about as if he had swallowed a spring mattress." In part this is because Mark Twain was so meticulous in his choice of words. Long before Ezra Pound described poetic language as "the precision that creates movement," Mark Twain wrote that the "intensely right word" has an effect that is "physical as well as spiritual, and electrically prompt."
Prompt -- electrically prompt: The phrase itself is the effect it describes. "My usual style of ciphering out the merits of poetry," Mark Twain wrote, ". . . is to read a line or two near the top, a verse near the bottom and then strike an average."
But how many passages of even good poetry can match the pith and savor of Mark Twain's best flights of prose? "Probably there is nothing in the world so suggestive of serene contentment and perfect bliss as the spectacle of a calf chewing a dishrag, but the nearest approach to it is your reedy tenor, standing apart, in sickly attitude, with head thrown back and eyes uplifted to the moon, piping his distressing solo." Nothing, yet everything, reedy and distressing in that.
In his day Mark Twain made Sigmund Freud, Ulysses S. Grant and Rudyard Kipling laugh, and presumably, because he was friendly with them, Frederick Douglass, Helen Keller and the president of Standard Oil. His jokes still make both highly and lowly literate people chuckle and whoop. And ponder. And protest. His micro-jokes are impeccable, his macro-jokes enduringly strange, conducive to consternation, open to argument. The prime example is "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," which will not settle down. It continues to be denounced as racist and sanctified as antiracist.
"Uncle Tom's Cabin," by Mark Twain's postbellum neighbor in Hartford, Harriet Beecher Stowe (who in her dotage would slip up behind him and let out a "war whoop"), provided an incisive analysis of the economics and horrors of slavery at a time when that peculiar institution was still legal. Stowe, the New England abolitionist, had the thing all figured out unimpeachably in then-radical terms, and there her now-archaic contribution sits.
Twain grew up in slave society and never got its taint, or the influence of African-American culture, out of his system. The rich, bitter joke of bondage in the land of the free, of palpable asymmetrical affection and heartlessness, persists in "Huckleberry Finn" to be read differently by each reader in every generation so far.
Who, in Mark Twain's works, is the innocent and who the culprit, who the trickster and who the tricked, who the enslaved and who (if anyone) the master? The culture-resistant Americans abroad, or the Europeans they subject to put-ons; the Connecticut Yankee, or King Arthur's Court? Conscience is a villain, young Satan is a hero, the Almighty is irresponsible, the funniest storytellers are the least humorous people, labor-saving devices are albatrosses, wealth is a boon that leaves its recipients spent.
Mark Twain's involvement in the national and international life of his time was both ebullient and ambivalent. He was often outspokenly in love with the prospect of easeful death. He seethed and erupted in work that danced and work that plodded, in celebration of what delighted him and to stave off bankruptcy and muddled personal despair. His corpus remains volatile, vulnerable, provocatively unstable -- jokes within jokes, which the author himself is not securely in on. The jokes are not entirely gettable, but readers keep trying to get at the heart of them. That heart is a pump that keeps juice going and coming around.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 18, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An Op-Ed article yesterday incorrectly said Mark Twain has been dead for 97 years. He died in 1910.
A Jan. 17 Op-Ed article about Mark Twain misattributed a phrase about poetic language as the "precision that creates movement." The author is E. E. Cummings.

HEADLINE: At Stuyvesant, Kudos for Scientific Creativity in the Shadow of Ruin 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
For a week after Nikita Rozenblyum witnessed the jet hurtling into the World Trade Center, he could not concentrate on his schoolwork, let alone the math research project he intended to submit for the Intel Science Talent Search.
 His classmate Philip Ernst, by contrast, deflected the world that had gone surreal with a dose of teenage bravado. He focused more single-mindedly on the computer science research paper he was submitting. 
 Yesterday, Mr. Rozenblyum and Mr. Ernst, both 17-year-old seniors at Stuyvesant High School, and 13 fellow Stuyvesant students found out that they were among 300 semifinalists in the annual Intel contest. 
Stuyvesant always does well in the competition, often leading the nation in the number of semifinalists and in the number of winners (40 will be chosen, and their names will be announced in two weeks).
But this round of competition is like no other. When the twin towers crumbled five blocks from Stuyvesant High, students were starting another intense semester, and the school's Intel competitors were entering the final months of a fierce race. When their school first closed for 10 school days and then reopened in classrooms borrowed from Brooklyn Technical High School, many students doubted that they could produce papers of quality on their research projects, some of which had begun a year earlier.
"It was a difficult time for my research because I couldn't get my surveys out," said Jukay Hsu, 17, another semifinalist, whose project on behavioral economics was based on his student surveys. 
The success of the Stuyvesant competitors this year is a testament not only to their grit but also to that of their adult mentors. 
For instance, Daniel Choy Boyar, 17, lived with his New York University mentor, a neuroscientist, for days when he was unable to return to his downtown apartment. Michael Zamansky, a science teacher at Stuyvesant, returned to the high school only days after the Sept. 11 attack to turn on the computer server so that the students could continue writing. Several mentors kept alive the students' cultures and biological specimens when they could not get to their labs.
The Intel competition has been the nation's most prestigious science research contest for high school students since its birth under the Westinghouse name in 1941. Five winners have gone on to win the Nobel Prize. 
More than 1,500 students entered the 2001 competition. Two other perennial high performers in the city, Bronx Science and Midwood High School in Brooklyn, had six semifinalists apiece, while in the competitive suburbs, Byram Hills High School in Armonk, N.Y., and Ward Melville High School in East Setauket, on Long Island, each claimed eight. Nationally, the school with the most semifinalists was Montgomery Blair High School in Maryland, with 17, followed by Stuyvesant, with 15. 
At Stuyvesant yesterday, students stressed that their mentors and teachers had helped them through. Daniel Turnbull, a professor of radiology and pathology at N.Y.U., welcomed Mr. Ernst to his lab every day that Stuyvesant was shut. 
Most of the Stuyvesant semifinalists are immigrants or children of immigrants. "Often, it is the immigrant children who have the drive and determination to complete the projects," said Anne de Sostoa Manwell, the coordinator of the independent research program at Stuyvesant.
Mr. Rozenblyum, who immigrated with his parents, a mathematician and a physician, from Belarus in 1992, could not stop beaming. "My parents came here so me and my brother could have a better future," he said, "and they are very proud today." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Brennan of the Intel Corp., left, presented a mockup of a check for $15,000 yesterday to Stanley Teitel, the principal of Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. The money represents $1,000 for each of Stuyvesant's 15 semifinalists in the Intel Science Talent Search. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: City Welfare Rolls Rise 

 BODY:
For the first time in six years, New York City's welfare rolls began to rise by several thousand people in the late fall, adding to growing concerns that the country's revamped welfare system may be caught short in the recession. Gov. George E. Pataki has joined other governors in seeking more federal aid for welfare.

PERSON: Michael A. Bilandic 

HEADLINE: Michael Bilandic, Daley Successor in Chicago, Dies at 78 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Michael A. Bilandic, who became mayor of Chicago after the death of Richard J. Daley, his mentor, only to see the Daley political machine sputter to a stop under his leadership, died on Tuesday in Chicago. He was 78.
 The cause was a heart rupture, said Dr. Dan Fintel of Northwestern Memorial Hospital. Mr. Bilandic was admitted after a heart attack on Friday and was scheduled for triple bypass surgery yesterday, but he died after the rupture. 
 When Mayor Daley died in his sixth term in 1976, his machine selected Mr. Bilandic as a temporary successor, and the new mayor immediately promised not to run in the election six months later to fill the remaining two years of Mr. Daley's term.
His deference reflected the careful personality of the corporate lawyer he had been for 28 years. Mike Royko, a columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, labeled him Mayor Bland.
But Mayor Bilandic quickly found himself in the rough and tumble of Chicago politics. Within months of taking office, he negotiated labor agreements involving gravediggers, butchers and members of the Chicago Lyric Opera orchestra. He brought together warring factions to end a 15-year impasse on building a crosstown expressway, releasing $1.5 billion in federal money.
His romance with Heather Morgan, the director of the Chicago Council on Fine Arts, added a dash of warmth to his image. They married shortly after he was elected mayor. He is survived by his wife and their son, Michael. 
He changed his mind about not running, explaining that he was responding to a groundswell of support. He emphasized his closeness to Mr. Daley, saying the mayor had given him the kind of education "you cannot get at Oxford, Cambridge, Harvard or Stanford." He went so far as to imitate Mr. Daley's speech patterns, with a distinctive grammar and syntax and a seeming preference for commas over periods in his orations. 
The result was victory in the Democratic primary in a city where that was tantamount to victory in the general election. Several months later, he delightedly quoted the remark of a child at an elementary school in the Bridgeport neighborhood, where Mr. Bilandic, like the four mayors before him, lived.
Someone had asked the child if he knew who the visiting Mayor Bilandic was.
"Yes, that's the new Mayor Daley," the boy chirped.
But Mr. Bilandic demonstrated that he lacked the iron control of Mr. Daley. First, Jane M. Byrne, his commissioner of consumer sales, accused him of being in cahoots with the city's taxi companies to raise their fares. Though he fired her, their highly visible fight -- both passed lie detector tests -- differed markedly from the discipline of the Daley City Hall.
Second, it snowed, more than seven feet, the most ever recorded in a season Chicago. The city's snow removal was so terrible that people guessed Mayor Daley must have taken the snowplows with him; a former deputy mayor was found to have received a $90,000 consultant's contract for snow removal.
A joke circulated. First man to second: "If Mayor Daley was alive, all this wouldn't have happened."
Second to first: "If Mayor Bilandic was alive, it wouldn't have, either."
The result was that in March 1979, Ms. Byrne, at first viewed as a quixotic candidate for mayor, beat Mr. Bilandic, ending 48 years of machine domination of city politics.
Michael Anthony Bilandic, the son of Croatian immigrants, was born on Feb. 13, 1923, in Bridgeport, on Chicago's southwest side. It is called Back of the Yards because of its proximity to the stockyards that were once the economic backbone of the area.
Like Mayor Daley, he attended De La Salle High School, graduated from De Paul University Law School and got into politics by hanging around the 11th Ward Democratic Headquarters.
He served for four years in the Marine Corps in the South Pacific and then earned his undergraduate degree from Notre Dame University. He began as a $25-a-week law clerk at the Chicago firm of Anixter, Delaney, Bilandic & Piggott, and worked his way to senior partner.
He resumed his political activity, canvassing the 11th Ward for Mr. Daley, a neighbor, during his first race for mayor in 1955. For the next decade he was an active, if inconspicuous, figure in ward politics.
At Mayor Daley's invitation, he ran for City Council in 1969, and the next year was named to its powerful finance committee. In 1974, after the indictment of the committee's chairman on fraud charges, he was named chairman.
In 1972, Mr. Bilandic stood in for Mayor Daley at the Democratic National Convention in denouncing the seating of anti-Daley delegates led by the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
After his defeat, Mr. Bilandic returned to private practice, then started a new career as judge. He was elected to the First District Appellate Court in 1984 and, six years later, to the Illinois Supreme Court, the highest in the state. He was chief justice for the last three years of his 10-year term.
Last September, he was chosen to break the tie on a committee redrawing Congressional and state legislative districts. His name was drawn from a replica of a stovepipe hat owned by Abraham Lincoln. The state Constitution calls for such a random selection when the eight-member body, split evenly between parties, cannot agree.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 23, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of former Mayor Michael A. Bilandic of Chicago on Thursday misidentified the college from which he graduated. It was St. Mary's College, now known as St. Mary's University of Minnesota. (He also attended the University of Notre Dame, without graduating.)

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Love and a Special Stroller Are All This Girl Needs

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Desiree Torres reclined in her wheelchair, on top of one rag doll and next to another, all of them under a pink blanket with bunnies on it. A cast covered Desiree's right leg, a result of an operation in November to correct the structure of her hip.
 Desiree, 11, has severe cerebral palsy, and, said her social worker, Katie Fredericks, was placed in the foster care system shortly after birth by her mother, who could not manage her severe medical needs. She has been cared for by her adoptive mother, Nelly Torres, since she was 3 months old. 
 "I love the baby," Ms. Torres said, cupping her hand on Desiree's face and making her smile. "She needs a place to live."
Desiree lives with Ms. Torres, who is unemployed, in the Bronx River Houses public housing project. But since November, she has been staying at St. Mary's Hospital for Children in Bayside, Queens, recovering from her hip surgery.
"She was born premature and has had multiple operations," said Desiree's nurse, Lois Weston. "Now she's in a cast. All of that has been very difficult for her."
Ms. Torres, 58, has plenty of love for Desiree, but not much money. She depends on her 37-year-old daughter, Carmen Argueta, who lives in Manhattan, to pay her rent and bills.
Ms. Torres used to receive welfare, but earlier this year she withdrew from it when she was asked to work in a welfare employment program.
"They were sending me to work," Ms. Torres said. "I couldn't go to work because I had to stay home to be with Desiree."
As a result of her limited income, Ms. Torres, who also cares for an active 9-year-old foster daughter named Luisa, could not afford a stroller that she needed to transport Desiree, who cannot walk on her own because of cerebral palsy.
Last summer, Ms. Torres saw that a friend traveled easily by putting the disabled child she cared for in a stroller. Ms. Torres told Ms. Fredericks, who helps her take care of Desiree, that she wanted a similar one to replace the unwieldy wheelchair she had been using.
Ms. Fredericks, who works for New Alternatives for Children, a nonprofit agency that helps parents care for chronically ill and disabled children, helped Ms. Torres pick out the stroller from a catalog.
She paid for it with $2,200 from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund after receiving a 10 percent discount from the manufacturer. New Alternatives is a member of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the seven local charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund.
The stroller, a pink Convaid Cruiser, has various attachments, like foot rests and straps to keep the head and torso upright. "It improves her quality of life because it enables Nelly to take her outside," Ms. Fredericks said.
"They can go more places easier, they can do more things together as a family. In the past it was harder, because the wheelchair was much harder to manipulate and the other child would be running off to play."
Desiree is 4 feet 3 inches tall and weighs about 45 pounds. Her mother said she had responded well to the special stroller, and was looking forward to the day she can go home and begin using it again. 
Ms. Fredericks said that the design of the stroller is flexible enough so that Desiree, who is not expected to grow much more, could use it into adulthood.
That is exactly how long Ms. Torres plans on caring for Desiree. The only limit on the length of their relationship, she said, would be the length of her own life. "I'm still in good shape myself," Ms. Torres said with a smile. "I'm going to keep my daughter for good."
Though Desiree cannot speak, she understands English and Spanish, her mother said. Ms. Torres said she had always known what Desiree needed.
Desiree rarely cries, Ms. Torres said, and only does so when the two must part company. As Ms. Torres said this, in a common room at St. Mary's Hospital on Tuesday, Desiree began to shed two small tears, one out of each eye, as if she thought that Ms. Torres was leaving at that very moment.
A few minutes later, at noon, it was time for Desiree to go to lunch. She began to cry, not with short sniffles but with long, slow wails and quick gasps for air. Eating could come later. For now, Desiree just wanted to spend more time with her mother, who stroked her cheeks, trying with limited success to comfort her.
"You can tell when a child has been in a loving home environment just by how they interact," Ms. Weston, the nurse, said shortly after. "You can tell she's been well cared for and loved by her family."

Contributions Set a Record
The total contributed to the Neediest Cases Fund as of Tuesday was $8,197,366.01, a record, which exceeds the total in the 2000-2001 campaign, $8,033,582.22, also a record.

HEADLINE: Welfare Rolls Grew in City Late Last Year 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ and NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
For the first time in six years, New York City's welfare rolls began to rise by several thousand people in the late fall, adding to growing concerns among government officials nationwide that the country's revamped welfare system may be caught short in the recession. 
 A new study, to be issued today by the Independent Budget Office, shows that the number of people receiving welfare was up by a total of 5,000, or about 1 percent, in October and November, to 469,000 -- the first time since 1995 that the rolls increased two months in a row. 
 Moreover, thousands of families who were cut from the rolls in December, as they neared their five-year federal time limits, could be back within months on state-financed Safety Net Assistance, the analysis cautioned. The study also projects that unemployment could drive the number of public assistance recipients up 14 percent by next fall. 
With tax revenue declining because of the faltering economy and unemployment rates rising, Gov. George E. Pataki has joined governors from around the country in seeking increased federal aid for welfare assistance. The governors are planning to ask Congress to provide emergency financing, in addition to the block grants now awarded, to states with high unemployment. 
Nationally, the situation is shaping up as a test of the welfare program that Congress created in 1996, when it ended the decades-old federal guarantee of coverage for the poor and no longer tied the amount of money spent on welfare to the number of people on the rolls. The governors are timing their request as Congress considers reauthorization of that law, which comes up this year. 
The governors are likely to meet resistance in Washington, where lawmakers are warning that the arrival of budget deficits will make it nearly impossible for them to meet the broad array of needs nationally, from health care to domestic security.
The National Governors' Association points to some troubling signs already: Thirty-three states reported caseload increases between March and September, including Connecticut (1.5 percent), Massachusetts (5.7 percent), Arizona (11 percent), Indiana (16 percent) and Nevada (24 percent).
In New York City, where a 60 percent decline in the welfare rolls since 1995 was one of the hallmarks of the Giuliani administration, the caseload increases in October and November were followed by a drop to 462,595 in December.
But the Independent Budget Office notes that thousands of eligible families lost aid temporarily that month during a switch to state-financed aid, and adds that "despite the ostensible drop, the December welfare numbers indicate that the underlying caseload trend continues upward."
Under the nation's 1996 welfare overhaul, the federal government provides each state a fixed sum to run its own welfare program. But the overhaul was passed when the nation was enjoying a prosperity that created an abundance of entry-level jobs.
Now, the governors are worried that states might be shortchanged under the block-grant approach, given that public-assistance rolls are climbing for the first time in years.
"When we took the block grant, we took the economic risk in all this," the executive director of the governors' association, Raymond C. Scheppach, said. "What we're saying now is that we are still willing to do that, except when there is huge economic disruption."
John Madden, a spokesman for the New York State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, echoed that sentiment. "The states took the risk with the block grant premise and we shouldn't be left holding the bag when the national economy slows and people need help," he said.
In New York City alone, today's report projects, the caseload can be expected to rise by 66,000 by September, reaching 530,000 and leaving the current budget for grants short by $40 million. 
The projection assumes that the city, which suffered a net loss of nearly 100,000 jobs in October and November, will lose a total of 130,000 jobs before its economy picks up again in the summer.
For every 10 jobs lost in the city, the analysis calculates, 5 people, including children, will be added to the rolls -- a rate chosen to reflect today's increased hurdles to receiving public assistance. The rate was actually higher in the city's last recession, between 1989 and 1993, when the welfare rolls grew by 8 recipients for every 10 jobs lost.
The welfare overhaul of 1996 did create a contingency fund to hedge against an economic downturn. But state officials and the governors' association contend that the fund is too small and, more important, virtually impossible to tap because of requirements established by the 1996 law.
The governors may also ask Congress to approve an increase in block grant money states receive -- a total of roughly $16 billion -- if only to help them keep pace with inflation.
Some champions of the overhaul are more optimistic about its sticking power under pressure. A study released in July by the conservative Manhattan Institute, for example, predicted that even a downturn that increased unemployment to 1993 levels -- 6.9 percent in the nation and 10.4 percent in the city -- would increase the welfare participation rate of single mothers by no more than 5 percent. 
No one is arguing that the welfare rolls will swell to the levels of six years ago, when there were 12.9 million recipients nationwide, 7.5 million more than there are now, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.
But states say they will have difficulty coping with surging caseloads, particularly now that large portions of their welfare grants pay for the kind of welfare-to-work antipoverty programs envisioned by the framers of 1996 welfare overhaul.
Those programs -- intended to help welfare recipients land jobs and keep them -- range from job placement and child care to intensified case management.
A welfare policy analyst for the governors' association, Gretchen Odegard, said the federal government must make emergency funds available if states are going to continue to run the new programs while addressing the needs of the newly unemployed.
"There's pressure to meet an increasing demand for cash assistance," she said. "There needs to be a mechanism in place for states to turn to the federal government in times of economic hardship."
New York's situation illustrates the degree to which states have reordered spending priorities and focused on antipoverty programs instead of simply providing cash aid.
In 1997, about 20 percent of the state's welfare dollars were spent on such programs, with most of the rest going to traditional cash benefits. Today, that situation is almost reversed, according to state social service officials. Nearly 70 percent of the state's welfare dollars is spent on antipoverty programs.
"The challenge today is not just getting people off the welfare rolls," Mr. Madden said. "It's helping them even after they get a job. That's why we need a commitment from the federal government to support us when the economy falters like this and people turn to the states for help."
The states argue that Washington itself is partly to blame for the bind they are facing, pointing out that Congress made it harder for states to accumulate welfare surpluses to use in an economic downturn.
When many states tried to carry over unspent portions of their welfare grants from one year to the next, to set up so-called rainy day funds, lawmakers in Washington responded with a stern use-it-or-lose-it warning, according to Douglas E. Howard, director of Michigan's Family Independence Agency, as well as other state officials.
Mr. Howard urged Congress not to make that mistake again. "Congress should create incentives for states to save funds so that they are better equipped to deal with economic downturns," he said.
The large surpluses of welfare dollars that states were reporting a few years ago -- before Congress cracked down -- have dwindled. The governors' association reported that the states have less than 10 percent of the roughly $80 billion the federal government has provided over the last five years.
Reports from the field are deepening state officials' concerns. The governors' association provided figures showing caseload increases between March and September of last year in, among other states, Mississippi (11 percent), South Carolina (10 percent), Florida (4 percent), Georgia (5 percent), Kansas (6 percent) and Michigan (3 percent).
In New York State, the rolls declined 6.5 percent during that period, before a reversal in October. In the city, which lost thousands of jobs in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the shift has been abrupt. 
"It is not clear whether the city's policies, designed to reduce the welfare caseload and cut city expenditures on public assistance, can succeed during an economic downturn," the Independent Budget Office report said. "But we are about to find out."

HEADLINE: Scattered Signs of Improvement in a Weak Economy 

 BODY:
 A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve Board's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.

Minneapolis: Economic conditions were mixed. Consumer spending grew but energy and mining were down.

Chicago: The region's economy was soft. Home building showed improvement.
Retail sales disappointed.

Cleveland: Demand for construction services remained unexpectedly strong. Warm weather boosted auto sales.

Boston: The regional economy remained weak but some bright spots were visible. Holiday retail sales were disappointing.

New York: The economy has shown continued signs of rebounding. Holiday retail sales were average.

Philadelphia: Business activity remained sluggish. Manufacturers reported continuing declines in shipments and orders.

Richmond, Va.: Manufacturing production declined as did retail sales. Service businesses reported a moderate growth in sales.

Atlanta: Retail sales were mediocre. The housing market was solid but commercial real estate remained weak.

St. Louis: The regional economy continued to be weak, particularly in manufacturing. Retail sales were buoyed by extended hours.

Kansas City, Mo.: The economy remained weak. Manufacturing, construction, real estate, and the energy industry all declined.

Dallas: Economic activity continued to decline in the area. Many businesses did not expect much improvement until the second quarter at the earliest.

San Francisco: Holiday sales were lackluster. Inflation was in check. Farmers reported low crop prices. Businesses reported steady or declining prices.
(Source: Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Inflation Falls In Region 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 A steep drop in energy prices helped reduce the regional inflation rate to 1.7 percent last year, from 3.1 percent in 2000, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday. 
The rate measures inflation in New York City and its northern suburbs, Long Island, and parts of New Jersey and Connecticut. Gasoline prices have dropped by about a third since peaking in June, the bureau reported. But owner-occupied housing costs rose by 6.6 percent, far more than the 2.4 percent increase in 2000. Rental costs rose only slightly, to 4.1 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Owners Give Approval To Sale of the Red Sox

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
With the threat of another legal headache behind them, Major League Baseball owners approved the $660 million sale of the Boston Red Sox today to a group led by John Henry. But they passed up the opportunity to execute an unprecedented triple play involving teams in three cities and two countries.
 The owners had also been expected to approve two other transactions, but they put off those actions until later this month. 
 Henry, who has owned the Florida Marlins the past three years, will sell that team for $158 million to Jeffrey Loria, who has been the managing partner of the Montreal Expos the past two years, and Major League Baseball will pay Loria $120 million and operate the Expos, one of the teams Commissioner Bud Selig wants to eliminate in the owners' stalled contraction plan. 
Those transactions did not come up for a vote, David Samson, executive vice president of the Expos, said, because the Marlins, the seller, did not present the deal to the executive council, which met before the owners did at the Arizona Biltmore. "We haven't worked out all of the details," said Lucinda Treat, Henry's lawyer.
Until the Marlins' sale is approved, Henry, a commodities trader and hedge fund manager in Florida, will own pieces of three teams. That status certainly is unprecedented for the major leagues. Besides the Marlins and the Red Sox, Henry owns 1 percent of the Yankees, a share he is in the process of selling to Al Neuharth, founder of USA Today.
The Yankees were the only one of 30 clubs that did not vote in favor of the Red Sox sale. The Yankees abstained, a person who attended the meeting said, because Henry has not sold his 1 percent. One view is that Henry has held up the sale because he wants Neuharth, a close friend of George Steinbrenner's, to pay more for it than he has offered. Another is that Neuharth wants a foundation he is involved in to be the buyer, an idea Steinbrenner opposes.
When Henry was asked at a news conference about owning pieces of three teams, Selig jumped in and said, "I've told these gentlemen -- and it involves San Diego, the New York Yankees, Florida and obviously Boston -- that all these deals are to be completed before the closing date of the Red Sox. They've all said that is not a problem."
Selig said he expected the closing to be in the latter half of next month.
Henry, meanwhile, is not expected to make any trades with himself in the 10 days or two weeks he will be viewed as the owner of the Marlins and the Red Sox. Technically, his group will not take control of the Red Sox until the closing.
The owners' vote on the Red Sox sale came only a couple of hours after the Massachusetts attorney general, Thomas Reilly, reached agreement with John Harrington, the Red Sox chief executive officer, and the Henry group on changes Reilly had requested involving the Jean R. Yawkey Trust.
The owners would very likely have approved the sale without Reilly's blessing, but they have had enough problems with lawsuits and were not looking for another one. In this instance, Reilly wasn't either.
"In the end we had to make a decision," Reilly said by telephone from Boston. "We looked at two years of litigation. Whenever you're in litigation you don't know how it's going to turn out. Two years of litigation would have turned this franchise upside down and may never have resulted in additional benefits to the charities."
In the end, Reilly added, he became convinced that "nothing had changed on the Major League Baseball level" regarding the higher bids from Charles F. Dolan ($750 million), chairman of Cablevision, and a group headed by Miles Prentice ($755 million), a New York lawyer. "There were going to be serious difficulties either for Prentice or Dolan."
But Reilly did not concede easily to the obvious desire of the owners to have the Henry group owning the Red Sox. This afternoon he sent a letter via fax to Selig asking him to delay approval of the sale until his issues were resolved or direct the Red Sox to reopen the bidding process. An hour or less later, Harrington and the Henry group agreed to Reilly's terms.
Under that agreement, the Henry group will establish another charitable foundation with $20 million, the Red Sox limited partners will give $10 million of the $250 million they will get from the new owners to the Yawkey trust, and Harrington agreed to add five people to the four-person board of the trust, whose $36 million base will grow by more than 11 times with $420 million from the Henry group and the departing limited partners. "The foundation now has the potential to do good for generations, well into the next century," Reilly said.
Dolan, for one, was not happy with the outcome. "We are deeply disappointed by today's events," he said in a statement. "We agree with the previous statement of the attorney general of Massachusetts that the bidding process for the Boston Red Sox was fatally flawed. All of those associated with the process clearly know that to be the case."
Dolan's offer would have given the Yawkey trust $490 million compared with the $420 million it will receive under the approved deal. Dolan, who has tried unsuccessfully to buy other teams, including the Yankees and the Mets, was particularly interested in the New England Sports Network, 80 percent of which the Red Sox own. The sale also included Fenway Park. 
Although the $660 million sale price included those other lucrative elements, no one has ever paid even half that much for a baseball team. The record price for a team until now was the $323 million that Larry Dolan, Charles's brother, paid for the Cleveland Indians two years ago. 
Among those joining Henry in the ownership are Tom Werner, former managing partner of the San Diego Padres; Larry Lucchino, former president of the Baltimore Orioles and the Padres; George Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader, who served on Selig's blue ribbon panel on baseball's economics; and The New York Times Company, owner of The Boston Globe as well as The Times.

HEADLINE: Enron And the Gramms 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
When Senator Phil Gramm and his wife Wendy danced, it was most often to Enron's tune.
 Mr. Gramm, a Texas Republican, is one of the top recipients of Enron largess in the Senate. And he is a demon for deregulation. In December 2000 Mr. Gramm was one of the ringleaders who engineered the stealthlike approval of a bill that exempted energy commodity trading from government regulation and public disclosure. It was a gift tied with a bright ribbon for Enron. 
 Wendy Gramm has been influential in her own right. She, too, is a demon for deregulation. She headed the presidential Task Force on Regulatory Relief in the Reagan administration. And she was chairwoman of the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission from 1988 until 1993.
In her final days with the commission she helped push through a ruling that exempted many energy futures contracts from regulation, a move that had been sought by Enron. Five weeks later, after resigning from the commission, Wendy Gramm was appointed to Enron's board of directors. 
According to a report by Public Citizen, a watchdog group in Washington, "Enron paid her between $915,000 and $1.85 million in salary, attendance fees, stock options and dividends from 1993 to 2001."
As a board member, Ms. Gramm has served on Enron's audit committee, but her eyesight wasn't any better than that of the folks at Arthur Andersen. The one thing Enron did not pay big bucks for was vigilance.
There's a lot more you can say about the Gramms and Enron, and not much of it good. But Phil and Wendy Gramm are just convenient symptoms of the problem that has contributed so mightily to the Enron debacle and other major scandals of our time, from the savings and loan disaster to the Firestone tires fiasco. That problem is the obsession with deregulation that has had such a hold on the Republican Party and corporate America. 
An article in yesterday's Times noted the extensive links between Enron and the powerful Texas congressman Tom DeLay. Mr. DeLay became unhappy when Enron wooed a Democrat -- a senior treasury official in the Clinton administration -- to run its Washington office. "Still," the article said, "whatever the tensions last year, Mr. DeLay and Enron had a natural alliance. In his days in the Texas Capitol, Mr. DeLay was called Dereg by some because of his support of business. And in Congress he has been a longtime proponent of energy deregulation, an issue dear to Enron."
Enron exploited the deregulation mania to the max, and the result has been economic ruin for thousands upon thousands of hard-working families. As Public Citizen put it, "Enron developed mutually beneficial relationships with federal regulators and lawmakers to support policies that significantly curtailed government oversight of its operations." 
The kind of madness that went on at Enron could only have flourished in the dark. Arthur Andersen was supposed to have been looking at the books, but the vast shadows cast by the ideology of deregulation allowed that company to escape effective scrutiny as well. So you have revolving-door abuses and pernicious financial arrangements between companies like Enron and auditors like Andersen that are similar to those between private companies and government agencies.
Who's left to look out for the small fry?
If the deregulation zealots had their way, we'd be left with tainted food, unsafe cars, bridges collapsing into rivers, children's pajamas bursting into flames and a host of corporations far more rapacious and unscrupulous than they are now.
Enron manipulated the energy markets and cooked its own books in ways that would not have been possible if its operations had had a reasonable degree of transparency. But Enron operated in what has been widely characterized as a "black hole" that left competitors and others asking such basic questions as how the company made its money.
How long will it take? How many decades and how many scandals have to come and go before we catch on? We're human. We're self-interested. And when left to our own devices, some of us will do the wrong thing. 
Some perspective is needed. Unchecked deregulation is an express route to chaos and tragedy. Where the public interest is involved, a certain amount of oversight -- effective oversight -- is essential.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE OVERVIEW; 
AUDITOR RECEIVED WARNING ON ENRON FIVE MONTHS AGO

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Enron's auditors knew in mid-August of a senior Enron employee's concerns about improprieties in the energy company's accounting practices, Congressional investigators studying Enron's collapse said today.
 Officials of the auditing company, Arthur Andersen, sought guidance from their lawyers then about how to respond, according to the investigators. The disclosure raised fresh questions about Andersen's decision to stand by Enron's financial reports until early November, when the accountants forced the company -- by then under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission -- to restate five years of results and erase almost $600 million in reported profits. 
 Also, a February 2001 Andersen e-mail message obtained by Congressional investigators indicates that some senior Andersen officials discussed dropping Enron as a client nearly one year ago because of concerns about Enron's accounting, the investigators said. An Andersen spokesman tonight declined to comment on the message. 
In Washington today, the White House disclosed that Lawrence B. Lindsey, who is President Bush's top economic adviser and head of the National Economic Council, had overseen a study in mid-October of how a collapse of Enron would affect the economy.
According to Congressional investigators, the Enron employee, Sherron S. Watkins, called a former colleague at Andersen on Aug. 20 and told him of her concerns about the energy company's accounting. About the same time, Ms. Watkins also laid out her doubts in a letter to Enron's chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, disclosed earlier this week by a Congressional committee, that warned that the company might be revealed as an "elaborate accounting hoax."
Ms. Watkins's letter pointed to new questions about Enron's web of partnerships and raised the possibility that the company might have to reduce past earnings by $1.3 billion more than it already has. Business Day, Page C1. 
In an internal Andersen memorandum obtained by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Ms. Watkins's former colleague at Andersen wrote that "based on our discussion I told her she appeared to have some good questions."
On the next day, Aug. 21, four Andersen officials met to discuss Ms. Watkins's concerns, investigators said. They included David B. Duncan, the lead partner on the Enron account, whom Andersen fired this week after saying he ordered the destruction of Enron documents while the company's accounting was under investigation by the S.E.C. 
The officials then "agreed to consult with our firm's legal adviser about what actions to take in response to Sherron's discussion of potential accounting and disclosure issues," according to the memo.
Investigators say Andersen began the destruction of Enron documents in September and that an e-mail message from an Andersen lawyer on Oct. 12 re-emphasized Andersen's policy on destroying documents and encouraged the activity in the firm's Houston office.
Mr. Duncan, who is cooperating with authorities, spent hours in Washington today with government officials who are investigating the failure of Enron, the Houston company that pioneered energy deregulation and grew to be the nation's seventh-largest company before seeking bankruptcy protection last fall. 
He met for the second time this week with officials from the Justice Department, which is conducting a criminal investigation of Enron's collapse. On Monday -- the day before Andersen fired him -- Mr. Duncan met with Justice Department officials as well as staff members from the S.E.C. and agents from the F.B.I., according to people close to the inquiries.
This afternoon, he spent more than four hours answering questions from eight investigators for the House Energy and Commerce Committee, one of several panels in Congress reviewing Enron's demise. Flanked by his lawyers, Mr. Duncan was not sworn, but he was warned not to give false statements to Congress. There was no discussion of giving him immunity for his testimony, investigators said.
"He answered our questions and provided us with some valuable information, which we are pursuing," said Ken Johnson, a spokesman for Representative Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Republican and chairman of the committee. Mr. Johnson declined to comment in detail about the interview but said that Andersen's shredding of documents and handling of the Enron account were discussed.
Sullivan & Cromwell, the law firm representing Mr. Duncan, released a statement that said he was "continuing to cooperate with all investigations of this matter, and he looks forward to full disclosure of the truth."
Laura Sheehan, the spokeswoman for the energy panel's Democratic members, said that investigators had hoped to learn more from Mr. Duncan. "Our investigators were disappointed by the limited nature of Mr. Duncan's memory," she said. "We expect documents and other witnesses to fill in the blanks."
Mr. Johnson said that the Andersen memo about Ms. Watkins's concerns suggested that the firm was well aware that Enron's accounting was suspect long before the company had disclosed its problems. 
"It's clear now to us that key players at both Enron and Andersen knew of the problems months before the company imploded," Mr. Johnson said.
Representative James C. Greenwood, a Republican from Pennsylvania who heads the committee's oversight and investigation subcommittee, said the internal Andersen memo "raises additional concerns about Andersen's knowledge of potential accounting irregularities and the subsequent destruction of Enron-related documents."
A spokesman for Andersen, Charlie Leonard, said he did not know who was contacted at Andersen, which is based in Chicago, by officials in the firm's Houston office after their meeting about Ms. Watkins's concerns. He said the firm had contacted Mr. Lay and Enron's general counsel, James Derrick, about the matter. Andersen was told that Vinson & Elkins, a Houston law firm that represents Enron, was being brought in to review Ms. Watkins's concerns. 
The law firm, in reporting its findings to Enron, noted that it had been directed by the company to avoid "second-guessing the accounting advice and treatment" provided by Andersen. A lawyer for Enron said this week that the direction was meant to produce a quicker examination by Vinson & Elkins of Ms. Watkins's concerns.
Mr. Leonard said he did not know who at Andersen, other than Mr. Duncan, had participated in the Aug. 21 meeting. In addition to firing Mr. Duncan, Andersen this week placed on leave three other partners who worked on the Enron account, and the firm took away management responsibilities from four other partners in the Houston office. 
According to a person close to the case, Mr. Duncan told investigators that he disposed of documents in keeping with the Oct. 12 e-mail message from an Andersen lawyer in Chicago and that the destruction stopped when the lawyer left a voice mail message at the Houston office on Nov. 9. 
Andersen said on Tuesday that Mr. Duncan had ordered "an expedited effort to destroy documents" on Oct. 23, the day after Enron disclosed that the S.E.C. had begun its inquiry. The firm said the destruction apparently did not end until Mr. Duncan's assistant sent an e-mail message to other secretaries on Nov. 9 that said "stop the shredding."
Much of Mr. Duncan's discussion with investigators focused on the documents that were destroyed and on Enron's restatement of earnings in early November, the person close to the case said.
Also today, a senior Treasury Department official said that the nation's accounting and corporate disclosure rules needed to be strengthened. Speaking to a gathering of the American Council of Life Insurers in Boca Raton, Fla., Peter R. Fisher, the Treasury under secretary for domestic finance, alluded to Enron's collapse and cited "the failure of our financial accounting and disclosure practices to keep pace with the rapid evolution of our capital markets and corporate finance."
The Treasury Department disclosed last week that Enron's president repeatedly called Mr. Fisher in late October and early November seeking his help arranging bank loans as Enron scrambled to avoid collapse. Mr. Fisher -- who also was called by Robert E. Rubin, a former Treasury secretary whose current company, Citigroup, was one of Enron's lead bankers -- has said that he took no action on the company's behalf.
Two senior Democratic lawmakers, meanwhile, raised concerns about possible conflicts of interest at the Justice Department in the Enron investigation.
Representative John Conyers of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, suggested that Deputy Attorney General Larry Thompson -- who is ultimately in charge of the criminal investigation -- could have a conflict because his former law firm, King & Spalding, had represented Enron. 
Also, Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, questioned whether a conflict existed because Andersen was also working on an F.B.I. reorganization.
Mr. Thompson told reporters that while his old firm had done work for Enron, he never had. He also said the Andersen unit doing the F.B.I. review was separate from Andersen's accounting business. Last week, Attorney General John Ashcroft, who received campaign contributions from Enron while serving in the Senate, recused himself from the case.
New details also emerged today concerning Enron workers' losses in their 401(k) plans. A lawyer for employees suing over the 401(k) losses released two internal Enron e-mail messages detailing the timing of a "lockdown" during October and November, during which employees could not sell Enron shares in their accounts.
Enron has maintained that the lockdown did not begin until Oct. 29 and lasted only 10 trading days -- a period in which the stock fell $3.83. Enron has also said that employees were notified of these dates in an Oct. 4 mailing to their homes.
But the e-mail messages released by Eli Gottesdiener, a lawyer in Washington, who represents some employees, include a Sept. 27 message to all employees that the lockdown would begin on Oct. 19 and last about a month. A second message, dated Oct. 25, said that the lockdown would last from Oct. 26 to Nov. 20 and acknowledged employees' fears about the company's deteriorating condition. 
Mr. Gottesdiener argued that the e-mail also showed that many employees were misled to believe the lockdown started a week before it actually did -- leading them not to sell shares in a week in which the stock fell $10.65. Enron shares, which were above $90 in August 2000, are now worth less than $1.
On average, Enron employees had more than 60 percent of their 401(k) plans invested in Enron stock, and many have lost their savings in the wake of the company's collapse. Several lawmakers say the company improperly forced workers to hold their stock as the company faltered and have proposed legislative changes to restrict such lockdowns. 
Meanwhile, Joe Dunn, a Democratic California state senator leading an investigation of possible electricity-price manipulation during the state's energy crisis last year said some documents destroyed by Andersen were possibly subject to a subpoena issued last summer by his legislative committee. Tonight, Andersen said the firm had no reason to believe that anything related to the California subpoena was destroyed.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DRUGS; 
Afghanistan Issues Order Taking Hard Line on Opium Production

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
Afghanistan's interim leader issued a decree yesterday banning the cultivation of opium poppies, reviving a struggle previously waged by the Taliban against Afghanistan's most lucrative crop, United Nations officials reported.
 "All countrymen, especially peasants and farmers, are informed that from now on, the cultivation, manufacturing, processing, impermissible use, smuggle and trafficking of opium poppy and all its derivatives is declared illegal," said the order issued by Hamid Karzai, the chairman of the interim administration in Kabul. "Violators will be dealt with severely." 
 Without an army or police force, it was unlikely that Mr. Karzai would be able to enforce the decree in a serious way. But the order came just days before donor countries were to gather in Tokyo to pledge reconstruction aid to Afghanistan, which may amount to $15 billion over the next decade. There, Mr. Karzai is expected to seek help for crop-substitution programs to encourage farmers to abandon poppies. 
During the war with the Soviet Union in the 1980's, and in the first years under the Taliban, with little governmental control over independent warlords and farmers, Afghanistan developed into the world's largest producer of opium, producing a record 4,950 tons in 1999. 
In 2000, the Taliban cracked down hard on the growers, and production plummeted. But Bernard Frahi, who represents the United Nations International Drug Control Program in Afghanistan and Pakistan, said the Taliban never took steps to destroy opium stockpiles or laboratories that produced heroin from the opium.
With the collapse of the stern fundamentalist regime, production and exports rapidly resumed, much of it heading north across the porous borders with Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and south into Pakistan. Mr. Frahi said much of this represented efforts by traffickers to move stocks to more secure places in other countries..
In recent weeks, Pakistan has announced the interception of several huge shipments of drugs. Last week, the Pakistani police said they seized 1,390 pounds of heroin in southwestern Pakistan.

PERSON: Edwin McCammon Martin 

HEADLINE: Edwin Martin, 93, a Voice In 60's Latin America Policy 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Edwin McCammon Martin, who was assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs during the Cuban missile crisis in late 1962, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 93.
 The cause was pneumonia, his family said. 
 Mr. Martin was a career diplomat who attained the rank of career ambassador.
An expert on economics, he was appointed to the inter-American affairs post in March 1962. In choosing him, the Kennedy administration was seen as moving to reinforce the Alliance for Progress, a United States aid program for Latin America. 
But by late April 1962, the indications were that he had become the closest thing to an overall "boss" of Latin American policy that the Kennedy administration had had.
Before the missile crisis began, he coordinated American endeavors to cut Cuba off from other Western Hemisphere governments.
In addition, he said in an interview in August 1962: "We want to get rid of Castro and the Soviet Communist influence in Cuba -- not just Castro. I think the Soviet Communist influence is more serious than Castro."
In the summer of 1962, Nikita Khrushchev made a secret decision to put Soviet ballistic missiles in Cuba. Then American aerial reconnaissance showed that missile-launching sites were being secretly built on the island.
After President John F. Kennedy learned about the missiles, he formed a special group of advisers, including Mr. Martin, which came to be called the Executive Committee of the National Security Council, or ExCom. The group's mission, as Mr. Kennedy put it, was "to make a prompt and intensive survey of the dangers and all possible courses of action."
On Oct. 22, he publicly announced an American naval and air "quarantine" -- a blockade -- on the shipping of offensive military equipment to Cuba. He contended that the Soviet Union, breaking past promises, was building offensive missile bases and also bomber bases capable of nuclear attacks in a radius of up to 2,000 miles.
He also warned that the launching of a missile from Cuba would justify the United States mounting a large-scale attack against the Soviet Union in retaliation.
Besides helping advise Mr. Kennedy during the crisis, with negotiations going on about the Soviets' removing the missiles, Mr. Martin worked toward, and has been credited with bringing about, a pro-United States vote by the Organization of American States. The vote, which was unanimous, condemned the deployment of Soviet missiles in Cuba and approved the American blockade.
On Oct. 24, Soviet vessels transporting additional missiles to Cuba reversed their courses. On Oct. 28, Khrushchev gave his acquiescence to pulling the missiles out of Cuba and disassembling the missile sites.
On Nov. 4, Mr. Martin said on television that reconnaissance had shown that the dismantling activity on the Soviet missile sites "looks good." He added that on-site inspection would be needed to verify removal of the offensive weapons, including the Soviet bombers.
On Nov. 20, the American blockade ceased. By New Year's Day, the missiles and the bombers were gone from Cuban soil.
Mr. Martin's next post was ambassador to Argentina, from 1964 to 1968. 
Born in Dayton, Ohio, he received a bachelor's degree in 1929 from Northwestern University and did graduate work there. He joined the State Department in 1945 and had assignments in Washington, with NATO and in London before 1962.
Surviving are his wife, the former Margaret Milburn; a son, Edwin Jr. of Potomac, Md.; a daughter, Patricia Martin Sanjuan of Mount Vernon, N.Y.; nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edwin Martin (Associated Press, 1974)

HEADLINE: Bush Declares Free Markets Are Essential For Americas 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
President Bush invited Central American nations tonight to strike a separate trade accord with the United States and cautioned Argentina against using the country's economic crisis as an excuse to backtrack on free-market reforms or return to an era of protectionism.
 Mr. Bush's speech at the headquarters here of the Organization of American States was intended, his aides said, to demonstrate that despite making counterterrorism the new focus of his foreign policy, he has not turned back on the central foreign policy commitment he made last year: A new focus on the Western Hemisphere. 
 But Mr. Bush used the occasion to send a strong message to the new president of Argentina, Eduardo Duhalde, who more than once in the past two weeks has suggested that the American led "model" of economic development -- particularly rapid market openings and deregulation -- contributed to Argentina's economic crisis. 
Without naming Mr. Duhalde, save for a brief word of praise for the new president, Mr. Bush said that "Argentina -- and nationals throughout our hemisphere -- need to strengthen our commitment to market-based reform, not weaken it."
"Shortcuts to reform only lead to more trouble," he said. "Half-measures will not halve the pain, only prolong it."
Mr. Bush's economic and security advisers would not say this evening what "half-measures" he was referring to, but it seemed obvious.
While Argentina has abandoned pegging its currency to the dollar, a policy that kept inflation in check but badly hurt the competitiveness of Argentina's products -- Mr. Duhalde has created a two-tiered exchange rate that is designed to inflict pain on major banks and investors, not the public. It is unclear whether that is sustainable.
He has also declared a moratorium on the repayment of public debt, which is bound to scare away any investors who did not flee when the country was sinking deeper into trouble.
And while Mr. Duhalde has talked about the need for fiscal discipline, he has not yet said how he will deal with a huge budget deficit. Cutting government spending is likely to reignite rioting that has already been rampant through the crisis.
The International Monetary Fund agreed today to delay, for one year, a loan repayment of $933 million, due for repayment on Thursday. While the United States voted for the delay, and touted that as a sign of support for the country, the reality was that Argentina is in no position to pay the money, and has already defaulted on other loans.
When Mr. Bush met with Latin American leaders in Canada early last year, at one of the first big summit meetings of his presidency, there was little public questioning of the value of American-style economic reform measures. But tonight Mr. Bush felt that the pendulum had swung far enough that he had to note that "some are questioning the path to prosperity. Some wonder whether free market reforms are too painful to continue. Some question the fairness of free and open trade, holding out the false comfort of protectionism." 
But he argued that countries that "stay on the hard road of reform are rewarded," ticking off Chile's success in cutting poverty, and Mexico's recovery from the 1995 economic crisis. He noted that the United States had "made a mistaken and failed experiment with wage and price controls" in the 1970's, without mentioning that the plans had been devised by Republican presidents.
Mr. Bush also said that he would seek a free trade accord with the countries of Central America -- Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua. Because these are the smaller nations in the region, administration officials believe that they will be the easiest negotiating partners for an accord -- and that any regional agreement will prompt Argentina and Brazil, both much larger economies, to follow suit.
A new "Free Trade Area of the Americas" is scheduled to be negotiated by 2005, and if it is successful it would essentially extend NAFTA throughout the hemisphere.
But meeting that ambitious schedule may depend on Argentina's recovery. So far, Argentinian and Brazilian officials have said in recent weeks that they see relatively little potential benefit for their countries in a hemispheric accord.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Thanks, CNN, Mr. Pretzel And Jennifer

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
NEVER doubt the resilience of the American public. In some ways we will never be the same. But in other ways, it seems, we will never be different. The evidence is mounting that we have indeed returned to what passed for normal before the events of September, and have done so with the gusto of a lapsed dieter.
 This is, in its way, most comforting. 
 You question this rash judgment? Just look at the kinds of things that again preoccupy or at least distract us.
We worry about Jennifer Aniston's car accident in Hollywood. (Relax: the "beautiful blonde," the "stunner," as The New York Post called her in an article that required two bylines, one from each coast, escaped serious injury.) We anguish about portraits hanging in a borough hall, and about a statue honoring firefighters killed at the World Trade Center. We wonder if Larry King of CNN is earning as much as Katie Couric of NBC. We question whether labeling a television newswoman "a little sexy" undermines her professionalism -- a burning issue that has generated debate between those who object to the entire phrase versus those who find the qualifier demeaning. This is not a joke. To some.
What has become a joke is the matter of the presidential pretzels, a gift to comedians all, who were being painstakingly careful about our commander in chief for longer than his own advisers probably thought wise for his down-home image.
Then came the pretzel plop and by Monday night, David Letterman was nibbling on his own pretzel supply, thereby demonstrating not only his esophageal superiority, but the happy fact that, since he's teasing George Bush again, it must be all right to poke fun at anyone, must be all right for everyone to rag and disagree with everyone else.
They always did to some degree. But now it seems to be more the way it used to be, doesn't it?
The tussle over municipal art proves that. Should the statue of firefighters be symbolic or representational? The clay model of what is to be a bronze statue depicts one black, one Hispanic and one white firefighter raising the American flag at the World Trade Center site. In reality, three white men raised that flag. Hence the dispute. Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta, a man of peace, says he is hoping to find a compromise. 
The other artistic tiff is centered in Brooklyn. The borough's new president, Marty Markowitz, says the portraits hanging in Brooklyn's Borough Hall do not represent the diversity of his borough, so he has decided to move some, to make room for others. He said the portraits were of "old white men," one of whom happens to be George Washington, the father of our country.
A portrait of Washington still hangs in the entry gallery of Brooklyn Borough Hall, but Mr. Markowitz moved a similar painting from his private office to a second floor parlor, to the great disquiet of some New Yorkers, including the mayor. "I thought it was wrong, walking away from our history," Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Especially, he went on, a founding father. And this one led his troops to their first battle as Americans in August 1776, in Brooklyn, in the "Battle of Brooklyn" (sometimes called the Battle of Long Island).
BY yesterday, Mr. Markowitz was almost crying in frustration.
"This has gotten out of hand," he said. "I love our founding father, our first president. He will always be on prominent display in this building. I just want to try to make Borough Hall relevant to people who live in Brooklyn today, that's all. Was my choice of words poor? Perhaps. I don't know." He sighed. "For 20 years I was a state senator, nobody paid any attention to me."
Maybe nobody would have paid any attention a month ago. But now we somehow have time, and patience, for the frivolous and semi-serious.
We can, without apology, analyze the prospects of Julia Louis-Dreyfus's new television series. Will she succeed or fail, as did two other "Seinfeld" alumni? We can ask if CNN and Fox News will ever deliver more news than they make these days, as they steal each other's anchors and furiously self-promote.
And whither Regis?
The serious remains just as grave as ever. The city budget is out of balance. Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature approved a costly deal that gives munificent benefits to the large hospitals union and its powerful leader, Dennis Rivera. The recession continues, people struggle, mourning goes on.
But the leavening has begun. Some of it is downright silly. All of it is welcome.

HEADLINE: Kennedy Wants to Delay Tax Cuts to Pay for Programs 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Saying what many Democrats think but make a point of not saying, Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for postponing $300 billion worth of last year's tax cuts so the nation could afford a prescription drug program and better early childhood education and health care.
 While Republicans uniformly disagreed with his plan, some gleefully heaped praise on Mr. Kennedy. They said the senator, a Massachusetts Democrat, showed "courage" or "guts" in saying what others like Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, have not. 
 Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said, "Senator Kennedy has set the stage for an honest debate between those of us who oppose tax hikes and those who support Daschle-nomics." 
The White House said Mr. Kennedy's call showed that the Democratic leadership "in all times, good and bad, looks to raise taxes on the American people."
Mr. Daschle issued a statement giving no direct comment on Mr. Kennedy's suggestion, but recalling that his own recent speech on the economy "did not call for either the suspension or the delay of the tax cut passed last spring."
Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the Democrat who heads the Finance Committee and who faces a stiff race for re-election this year, said through a spokesman that it was inappropriate to "revisit the tax cut in the midst of a recession."
Mr. Kennedy proposed putting off some of the $1.35 billion in tax cuts enacted last year and scheduled to take effect in 2004, which he said would be "long after the economy emerges from the downturn." He said those cuts, including reductions in the estate tax, helped the rich.
"Whatever the merits or demerits of last year's tax bill, it was enacted in what now seems a very different and distant time," he said at the National Press Club. "We must think anew, and act responsibly.
"Future additional tax breaks for the wealthy do not deserve higher priority than strengthening education or covering prescription drugs under health care or meeting other urgent national priorities." 
Specifically, Mr. Kennedy called for delaying cuts in the tax rates of one percentage point scheduled for 2004 and 2006 for taxpayers with joint incomes of more than $130,000 a year. That would save $190 billion through 2011, he said. 
The estate tax, he added, should not be repealed, but the minimum subject to tax should be raised, to $1 million immediately and to $4 million by 2010. That would save $110 billion, he said, while subjecting less than 1 percent of estates to taxation. 
Other scheduled cuts, including those for people with incomes less than $130,000 and increases in the child tax credit and elimination of the so-called marriage penalty, would not be altered. 
Anticipating the Republican argument that he was calling for tax increases, Mr. Kennedy said, "No taxpayers would pay a higher tax rate than they pay now."
Most Democrats have avoided the issue of postponing or repealing tax cuts, although Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York said last month on "Meet the Press" on NBC News, "Given where we are now with the recession, with the war on terrorism, I just don't think it's in our best interest to go forward with the tax cuts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Edward M. Kennedy at the National Press Club. He urged delaying cuts in rates and raising the minimum subject to the estate tax. (Susan Raab for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Job Fair Scheduled 

BYLINE:  By Michael Cooper (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said another job fair would be held this month to try to match the growing ranks of jobless New Yorkers with employers. 
The three job fairs that the city has held since the attack on the World Trade Center attracted thousands of job seekers. The fair, called the Workforce Development Job Expo, will be held Jan. 29, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. City officials said yesterday that they hoped to draw 400 employers. Michael Cooper (NYT)
