HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE VULNERABLE; 
AGrowing Number of Potential Targets for Lawsuits

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
With each new report of possible misdeeds by professionals who worked for or with the Enron Corporation, the list of deep-pocketed potential targets of civil and criminal lawsuits resulting from the company's spectacular collapse grows longer. A variety of major companies might just end up paying damages to help compensate victims of Enron's implosion.
 Shareholders have already sued Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's chief executive; Jeffrey K. Skilling, its former chief executive; and members of the board, accusing them of selling stock on the basis of inside information while the company misled investors about the state of its financial health. 
 The recent revelations about Enron's auditor, Arthur Andersen, have added it to the list. 
Possibly Enron's lawyers and perhaps even its bankers and consultants could also be vulnerable, legal experts say -- on top of any possible criminal liability under investigation by Congress, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department.
"The closer you are to what the main problems here are going to be -- misleading investors, misleading employees, destroying evidence -- the more likely you are to be in the gunsights," said Michael J. Shepard, former chief of the special prosecutions division in the United States attorney's office in Chicago and now a partner at Heller Ehrman White & McAuliffe in San Francisco.
If someone knew that Enron executives were breaking the law -- which has not been shown, Mr. Shepard emphasized -- that person could be criminally liable for helping them, even if everything that person did was perfectly legal. Even the financial advisers who helped Enron set up the partnerships that were used to keep debt off its books could possibly be liable, he said.
"If it turns out that these little partnerships are not actually compliant with whatever accounting rules there are, and they've been set up to hide Enron's losses," Mr. Shepard said, "and the investment bankers knew that, then it could all be part of a fraud."
There has been no proof of wrongdoing by any of these individuals or companies, of course. But this week's release of a letter that Sherron S. Watkins, an Enron executive, sent to Mr. Lay in August suggests that he knew its accounting procedures were questionable long before the company restated results in October. Any such lack of prompt disclosure will very likely subject Mr. Lay to additional suits, lawyers say.
Andersen's announcement on Tuesday that it had fired the lead partner responsible for the Enron account because, the firm said, he organized the destruction of documents and e-mail messages hands a great opportunity to shareholders angry over their big losses when Enron's stock price plunged.
"Proof of document destruction can lead to a court denying a defendant the right to even contest allegations" by the other side, said Melvyn I. Weiss of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, a law firm that has already sued Andersen on behalf of shareholders. 
The St. Paul Companies, which provides liability coverage for Enron's directors and officers, could also be on the line -- for at most $19 million, the company says. But if fraud is proved, insurers may have to pay nothing, said Robert Hartwig, chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute in New York. "In general, material misrepresentation is grounds for nonpayment or at least dispute of a claim for payment," he said. 
Congressional investigators have disclosed that Enron's law firm, Vinson & Elkins, looked into Ms. Watkins's questions and concluded that Enron's practices did not merit further examination. After all, the law firm wrote, Andersen had reviewed Enron's accounting methods. Now the law firm may be subject to a suit, Mr. Weiss said.
Normally it is difficult to pull lawyers, accountants and other professionals into securities suits, said Michael Young, a lawyer at Willkie Farr & Gallagher in New York who has defended accounting firms in such suits. "The plaintiffs, whoever they are, have to prove that individuals deliberately falsified numbers reported to shareholders" or that they were reckless in releasing numbers, he said. "That's usually the major stumbling block."
But this case is not typical, other lawyers pointed out, with new information coming to light daily that might help a plaintiff argue that accountants, lawyers and others should pay for Enron's collapse. "All the facts that you know now are just the tip of the iceberg," said one lawyer involved in the company's bankruptcy.
Some of Enron's creditors are just beginning to consider suing Andersen and possibly others. The Samson Investment Company, a Tulsa oil and natural gas explorer and now an Enron creditor, sued Andersen yesterday, saying it relied on Andersen's audits in doing business with Enron. 
But with many details unknown, it is too early to know all the creditors' legal options, said one member of the creditors' committee in Enron's bankruptcy proceedings. 
"Everyone will gather all this information," he said, "and then there'll be a slew of claims."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Apple's Retail Stores Show Positive Data on Customers

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Apple Computer said yesterday that 40 percent of the people who bought computers at the 27 retail stores it has opened in recent months were first-time users of Macintosh machines. The figure, analysts say, is an encouraging sign for the company's strategy of trying to lure newcomers to Macintosh, whose users are loyal but less than 5 percent of all personal computer buyers.
 The optimistic signal came as Apple reported quarterly results that underlined the challenge the company faces. Apple reported earnings that were in line with Wall Street's consensus estimates, but its sales results were somewhat below analysts' expectations. 
 Given the recession and the steep fall in technology buying, Apple held up reasonably well. "Apple delivered a solid quarter and is one of the few companies making a profit in personal computers during these challenging times," said Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple.
Mr. Jobs has sought to make Apple the product and design innovator in the personal computer industry. As evidence, he pointed to the introduction in late October of its iPod, a white, pocket-sized device that plays digital music. In two months, more than 125,000 of the iPod devices have been sold, priced at $400 each.
For the three months ended in December, Apple's fiscal first quarter, the company reported a net profit of $38 million, or 11 cents a share, matching the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. In the comparable quarter a year earlier, when it took big charges to reduce inventories after its cube-shaped computer sold poorly, Apple recorded a loss of $195 million.
Apple's revenues for the most recent quarter were $1.38 billion. That represented an increase of 37 percent from the depressed quarter a year ago, but it fell below revenue estimates of $1.43 billion.
The revenue shortfall in the quarter, said Fred Anderson, Apple's chief financial officer, was attributable to weak sales of the company's iMac consumer desktop line. The iMac, introduced in 1998, was an aging model and personal computer sales were soft in the quarter.
In addition, potential buyers were holding off because of widespread speculation in the Apple community that the company was going to introduce a striking new model, which Mr. Jobs did last week at the Macworld conference in San Francisco.
The new iMac line features a flat-panel screen attached by a strut to a compact half-dome shaped computer. In the current quarter, Mr. Anderson said that Apple expected revenues to rise to $1.5 billion but that earnings would be essentially the same as the December quarter.
A key reason for the expectation of flat earnings is that Apple will air freight the machines from East Asia to the United States during the current quarter to try to meet the sizable backlog of orders. "It's an investment in our customers." Mr. Jobs said. "They have a right to expect products." There are 6 million current iMac owners, and 100,000 of the new model iMacs were ordered during the first week.
The Apple retail stores, which were opening rapidly in the December quarter, lost $8 million when all administrative and store-opening costs were included. But Mr. Anderson said that with the stores up and running -- more will be opened this year, but the company would not say how many -- the retail division should move to profitability.
The stores are crucial to Apple's future. Mr. Jobs is trying to position the Macintosh as the preferred computer for handling all kinds of digital media -- music, photos and video. Showing off Apple's special software to do all those things is essential to attracting first-time computer users or winning converts from the dominant standard, Microsoft's Windows.

HEADLINE: New Mayor, New Focus 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Just two weeks into his mayoralty, with most of his administration in place, Michael R. Bloomberg is now offering significant clues about where his policy priorities may differ from Rudolph W. Giuliani's, on such issues as services to the poor, human rights abuses and public health.
 While Mr. Bloomberg's many goals will inevitably be hampered by budget constraints, observers of municipal government already see an ideological shift at City Hall. "There is a coherence in what he is doing," said Douglas Muzzio, a professor of public affairs at Baruch College. "The guy is a social liberal and he makes no bones about it. His conception of quality of life is broader and more liberal in terms of the role of the state, because it includes more stakeholders in the game." 
 Mayor Bloomberg has expressed an interest in reinvigorating areas of government that were dormant under the Giuliani administration, like the city's Human Rights Commission, which is charged with investigating and prosecuting discrimination cases. And the mayor is expected to try to give broader authority to the Health Department, involving it in issues from children's health to insurance to lobbying the state for public health needs in the city. 
And even in pursuing Mr. Giuliani's goal of clamping down on quality-of-life crimes, Mr. Bloomberg has broadened the definition and the approaches of that enforcement, insisting, for instance that while the homeless may not sleep on the streets, the shelters they are diverted to must have more beds, have additional services and be safe. 
"What you're seeing is that Mayor Bloomberg is acting on the areas he has felt strongly about in the past," said William Cunningham, a key adviser to the mayor. "I think most city residents see in their cities part of themselves. In his case, that means making sure resources are employed for the benefit of the citizens that need it the most."
Further, while Mr. Bloomberg's appointees have yet to make any major decisions, a great many of the officials are Democrats, raising the hackles of the city's conservatives, as have the early signs of Mr. Bloomberg's policy proclivities.
"I was certainly concerned about his statement that he would not litigate as much," said Heather MacDonald, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute, referring to a position Mr. Bloomberg took right after being elected. "When the city is litigating, it is usually when they are a defendant in suits brought by advocates who want to preserve the status quo." 
In naming his new chairwoman of the Human Rights Commission, Patricia L. Gatling, a prosecutor in the Brooklyn district attorney's office, Mr. Bloomberg signaled that he would substantially raise the profile of the agency, which investigates and prosecutes cases of discrimination in housing, employment and public places. He called the appointment one of his most important. 
In 1991, the city's human rights laws were amended, giving authority to the commission to investigate patterns of discrimination in various areas of city life. Under the revisions, the city's Law Department was also authorized to start investigations and was given subpoena power. However, the Law Department never took a claim to court between 1998 and 2001, according to a report by the City Bar Association's Committee on Civil Rights. 
Mr. Giuliani, who said when he was first elected that he would like to see the commission abolished, opted instead to reduce its staff to 37 employees from 152. The agency took five cases to trial between 1998 and 2001, and its backlog of complaints grew. 
Under the Bloomberg administration, the new mayor's advisers say, this will change. "We are going to make this is a real law enforcement agency," Ms. Gatling said in an interview. "We will investigate, and we will be in the litigation posture."
Ms. Gatling's appointment has drawn the attention of policy and legal experts. "It is interesting that he appointed someone from the law enforcement side of things," said Craig Gurian, who co-wrote the 1991 revision in the civil rights laws. "There had been this terrific double standard in the previous administration, which found law enforcement very important, except civil rights law enforcement."
Another area of public policy that is expected to get a great deal of the mayor's attention is health. His interest in public health is longstanding -- because of his leadership and largesse, the school of public health at his alma mater, Johns Hopkins, is named after him -- and he outlined several plans to improve public health, many of them taken from the playbook of the city's advocates for children, the uninsured and the poor, during the campaign. 
Among his goals are building on the number of children enrolled in Child Health Plus, the state's insurance program for poor children whose families earn too much to qualify for Medicaid, and making sure that they stay enrolled. According to people in his administration, he would like to see the Health Department take a lead on keeping tabs on a variety of children's health issues, from primary care to asthma to insurance, things usually left to the state or nonprofit groups.
Mr. Giuliani became interested in the uninsured toward the end of his term but did not involve the Health Department, nor was he particularly interested in primary care and other clinical issues, outside of cancer research.
Mr. Bloomberg, who appointed Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, a medical officer for the World Health Organization, as the next health commissioner, plans to seek to give the department broader authority, using $1.6 million in federal money earmarked to guard against bioterrorism to beef up the agency's infrastructure, officials said. 
Mr. Bloomberg may fold the mayor's Office of Health Insurance Access, which was created during the Giuliani years to work with the state to enroll people in health care programs, into the Health Department. Doing so, officials said, would allow the department to have a central role in lobbying the state for changes to Medicaid laws. 
In some cases, Mr. Bloomberg is simply extending Mayor Giuliani's policy initiatives, with a twist, as in adding homeless shelter safety to his list of quality-of-life reforms. "I do not want anybody to say I don't want to go to a shelter because it is full, I don't want to go to a shelter because it's not safe," he said recently.
In many ways, the remark was as politically shrewd as anything else. "He is a very practical person," said Mr. Cunningham, the mayoral adviser. "If there is a perception or a reality that there is a crime spike in shelters, that is where you put resources. Then no one can make the bogus argument that people can't go to shelters because they are not safe." 
Given his focus on public safety, education and his promise not to raise taxes, Mr. Bloomberg may avoid the perception among Republicans, whose party he only recently joined, that he is too liberal, or fears among a broader swath of New Yorkers that he is moving the city back to a place where most do not want it to go. "His policies on the economic front are very heartening," said Ms. MacDonald, echoing other conservatives. "Maybe he can go beyond Mayor Giuliani, who I don't think had as strong a record on budgetary reform and radical tax cutting that the city needs. Or maybe that is just wishful thinking."

HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE REVIEW; 
White House Says Economics Adviser Saw Little Risk on Enron

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Bush's top economic adviser, who had served as a paid consultant to the Enron Corporation before joining the administration, had directed a review of the broad economic effects of a potential collapse of the company but concluded it posed little risk to the American economy.
 The adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, who heads the National Economic Council, has said recently that unlike Treasury officials, he never received phone calls from Enron executives seeking help. Mr. Lindsey was paid $50,000 in 2000 for work on an Enron advisory board. 
 The White House said Mr. Lindsey began his review of the potential impact of Enron's troubles in mid-October, based on news reports of the company's troubles. White House officials said the review began two weeks before the chairman of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay, called Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, and Donald L. Evans, the secretary of commerce, suggesting that any Enron collapse might ripple through the American and global economies. 
"The government did exactly what the government should do," the White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said tonight in a statement after being questioned about Mr. Lindsey's role at his afternoon news briefing.
Ordinarily, any official who served as a consultant or lawyer for a company observes a period of a year or more once entering the government during which he or she avoids making decisions involving the company. 
Mr. Fleischer said Mr. Lindsey's examination of Enron posed no conflict of interest. Until Mr. Fleischer's statements, however, the White House had given no indication it had conducted any review of Enron's troubles or the potential impact.
After Mr. Lay called Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Evans in late October, Treasury officials conducted a study, and it appears to have overlapped the review the White House says Mr. Lindsey had already begun. The Treasury study focused on whether an Enron collapse might create a global market upheaval like the failure of Long-Term Capital Management, a hedge fund, did in 1998.
Government ethics rules state that members of the executive branch are obligated to recuse themselves from a matter if they "determine that a reasonable person would question their impartiality."
Democratic strategists, who have criticized Mr. Lay's calls to Mr. Evans and Mr. O'Neill, pounced on the news, saying that Mr. Lindsey should not have conducted the inquiry so soon after working for Enron.
"This is very troubling," said Jennifer Palmieri, a Democratic National Committee spokeswoman. "It is a significant conflict of interest for the former Enron economic adviser to be doing an analysis about Enron as the president's economic adviser.
"Most importantly, it shows once again that the administration did a lot of thinking about the fact that the company was going to collapse but they did absolutely nothing to make sure that 50,000 Enron employees would not lose their life savings."
Tonight, Mr. Fleischer said that Mr. Lindsey and his aides at the National Economic Council focused on whether "natural gas disruptions could occur or the national economy could be harmed."
"They also looked at currency markets, equity markets, bond markets and other financial indicators to determine if there were indications of a shortage of liquidity that might signal a more widespread problem," Mr. Fleischer said in his statement.
At some point, Mr. Lindsey's office coordinated its work with the Treasury's study. But it was not clear whether Treasury officials told Mr. Lindsey that Mr. Lay had raised the prospect of a broader meltdown.
In his news briefing, Mr. Fleischer asked: "About whether Enron's collapse has implications for the economy, I think if the administration didn't look at that, you would be asking 'Why wouldn't you?' " 
Indeed, some Congressional Democrats have criticized the administration for inaction, arguing that Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Evans had an obligation to alert the public of Enron's situation once they learned of it.
Mr. Lindsey is one of several Bush administration and Republican officials with ties to Enron. Among others, Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative, served on an Enron advisory board in 2000; Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's senior White House political strategist, held more than 1,000 Enron shares before selling them in June; and Marc Racicot, the former Montana governor whom Mr. Bush picked to run the Republican National Committee, worked as an Enron lobbyist last year.
Paul Krugman, an editorial columnist for The New York Times, said he was also paid $50,000 to serve on an Enron advisory board in 1999. He disclosed his connection in a Jan. 24, 2001, column about Enron.
"This was an advisory panel that had no function that I was aware of," Mr. Krugman said today. "My later interpretation is that it was all part of the way they built an image. All in all, I was just another brick in the wall."

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
Old Masters In Their Prime
 Collectors, dealers and auction house experts have been grumbling for years about the scarcity of exceptional old master paintings and drawings. In these tough times, when the economy is shaky and fewer collectors are traveling to New York for the big auctions, there seems to be less top-quality work than ever to offer hungry collectors. But experts are keeping an eye on two interesting works going on sale next Friday. 
 Christie's is selling "Sheerness as Seen From the Nore," an early Turner that would never have been included in an old master painting sale years ago, but would probably have found its way into an auction of British paintings. Now it may become either the season's highest-priced painting or its biggest casualty. When it was first exhibited in London in 1808, this painting and another Turner view of the Thames were called "the finest sea pieces ever painted by a British artist." 
Some think the painting, which depicts ships on a turbulent sea, is overpriced: it is estimated to sell for $6 million to $8 million. It is less fashionable than Turner's late work, yet some experts say "Sheerness as Seen From the Nore" is a precursor to his mature style.
"Turner's fascination with light and atmosphere shows his admiration of Dutch 17th-century seascape painters and the work of Claude Lorrain," said Anthony Crichton-Stuart, head of Christie's old master paintings department in New York.
Turner sold the painting to Samuel Dobree, one of his early patrons, who sold it at Christie's in 1842. It then found its way into the Barings banking family, which sold it in 1848 to William Wells, an important collector of Dutch old master and contemporary British painters. He, in turn, sold it for what would be $547,314 today to Robert Lloyd Lindsay, the first Lord Wantage, a major paintings collector. It stayed in that family until it was sold in 1991 to an unidentified Japanese collector, who bought it through Julian Agnew, the London dealer, for nearly twice its current low estimate.
Another work that has received much attention is Rembrandt's "Buildings by the Diemerdijk," being auctioned at Sotheby's. The seller is A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's, who was convicted last month of conspiring with his counterpart at Christie's to fix fees charged to sellers. Mr. Taubman has been quietly selling portions of his art collection, both at Sotheby's and privately.
This Rembrandt drawing, which depicts some farm buildings by the dyke at Diemen, near Amsterdam, where the artist regularly walked, comes with a pristine provenance. In 1723 it was bought by the Duke of Devonshire for Chatsworth, his Derbyshire home, along with a group of other Rembrandt drawings, after the death of Nicolaes Anthonie Flinck, the son of Rembrandt's pupil Govaert Flinck and a director of the Dutch East India Company in Rotterdam.
The drawing, which became part of the celebrated Chatsworth collection, was sold at Christie's in 1984 and again at Sotheby's in 1989, when Mr. Taubman bought it. Sotheby's estimates it will sell for $1.8 million to $2.4 million. As always, Mr. Taubman is selling the drawing without being named in the catalog.

Deeply Dutch
While the name Anton C. R. Dreesmann probably won't mean much to collectors here, ask almost any European, who will instantly spout the name of Vroom & Dreesmann, the Netherlands' largest department store.
Dreesmann, who died two years ago at 77, was a member of the department store family. A passionate collector, he bought everything from Impressionist paintings and old master drawings to Chinese export porcelain and gold boxes. In April, Christie's will offer what it calls "the largest Dutch collection ever to come to auction" in a series of sales in London and Amsterdam. The collection is estimated at $20 million.
"The sheer number of fields he bought in is something you just don't see anymore," said Noel Annesley, deputy chairman of Christie's and worldwide head of its old master paintings and drawings department. "People will be especially intrigued by the range of drawings."
For sale are drawings by van Gogh, Degas and Monet, as well as old masters like Goya, Goltzius and Watteau. Highlights of the collection will be on view at Christie's Rockefeller Center headquarters from Feb. 1 to 5.

Brazil Beat Goes On
"Brazil: Body and Soul," which opened at the Guggenheim Museum in October, was to close on Jan. 27. But this week the museum announced that the show, which focuses on several important periods of artistic production in Brazil, has been extended through May 29.
Completing the installation was difficult after Sept. 11, said Lisa Dennison, the Guggenheim's chief curator and a deputy director. "Because attendance is down, we decided to slow our programming," she added. "That means less overall programming costs, and it gives more people a chance to see the exhibition."
A Matthew Barney retrospective was to open at the museum in early February but has been postponed for a year. Rather than opening first in New York and then traveling to Europe, the show is keeping its original European schedule, opening at the Ludwig Museum in Cologne, Germany, on May 31 and then at the Musee d'Art Moderne de la Ville in Paris on Oct. 10 before coming to New York.

At the Armory Again
Two more art and antiques shows are back in the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, at 67th Street.
When the armories in Manhattan were closed to nonmilitary use after Sept. 11, the Art Dealers Association of America planned to move its Art Show to the Jacob Javits Convention Center, but eight dealers were so upset about the location that they dropped out. Now the show is back at the armory, from Feb. 21 to 25.
The Wendy's Antiques Show, Feb. 6 to 10, will also be at the armory.

HEADLINE: The Chip On China's Shoulder 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

DATELINE: BEIJING 

 BODY:
As soon as the two planes hit the World Trade Center, Chinese Internet users logged into online chat rooms to discuss the terror attacks.
 "Just one word: cool!" says the first of 6,000 comments on the attacks in a chat room on Sina.com, a leading Chinese-language portal. "Now the day has come for the American dogs." 
 "Why not the White House?" asks another a moment later. The gleeful declarations continue in a rush: 
"Excellent!!!!!!!! But the hijacked planes didn't carry a nuclear bomb."
"Just great. Really fantastic. Serves 'em right."
"So cool to see America bombed. Guys, let's use the Internet to wage war on 'em as well. This is the perfect moment for it."
"I'm waiting for the third plane, the fourth plane, the fifth plane, the sixth plane. Ha, ha!"
Not until the 44th message is there a reproach: "Do you people here have no shame?" someone writes. "Do you have no morality?"
The messages are still sitting there in cyberspace on the Sina.com site. A few days ago, I logged on using a Chinese-language computer here in Beijing and read through these messages. To anyone who deeply loves China, as I do, it is devastating to see how the deaths of thousands of Americans left many people here chortling.
I asked Chinese friends whether these online comments were representative of public opinion. Not entirely, they said, but the stories they told left me pained.
One friend who runs a business financed with American money found on Sept. 12 that the company's e-mail message system was full of jokes about the attacks. Another recounted how at the Communist Party School (where officials stayed up late to watch satellite television feeds of the destruction and showed unseemly good cheer), a luncheon for more than 80 top officials echoed with positive comments about the terror attacks. 
All this has to be put in perspective. Most Chinese I talked to were appalled by the attacks, and the United States Embassy in Beijing was showered with messages of sympathy from ordinary Chinese and with cash donations for the victims. Jiang Zemin and other Chinese leaders drafted an immediate message of condolence that they sent to Washington. 
Even in the chat rooms, the initial tone of xing zai le huo (gloating at the pain of others) faded as the death toll grew. 
Yet there is something going on here, something more complex -- and, to me, far more worrying -- than simply schadenfreude at seeing America humbled. It is a rapidly increasing Chinese nationalism.
This nationalism has deep roots in China and results in part from the battering that the country suffered at foreign hands over the last 200 years. But the latest surge in nationalism is the result in particular of "patriotic" campaigns planned by President Jiang since 1990 as a way of knitting together the country, of providing a new "glue" for China to replace the discredited ideology of Communism.
I spent a couple of days at Beijing University talking freely to the nation's best and brightest. This in itself, along with the relatively free debate in Internet chat rooms, is a sign of real political progress in China. 
When I lived here in the late 1980's and early 1990's, there was no outlet like the Internet to express one's views, and I could talk to university students only after escaping the goons who routinely tailed me. This time I had no tails to shake.
Yet what I found heartbreaking is that this new openness and political maturity in China is accompanied by a dangerous sign of political immaturity: this booming, aggrieved, chip-on-the-shoulder nationalism among many ordinary people, much more so than even a decade ago.
Why is this a risk? Think of Japan, where nationalism combined with an economic boom to help lead to the Asian half of World War II. Or of Germany, where a similar combination helped cause World War I. Or even -- this is an example Americans tend not to recall -- the way nationalism and new-found strength in the United States led Washington to provoke the Spanish-American War. 
Elsewhere in the world, we were far too late in recognizing the way movements in Iran, Saudi Arabia and Pakistan arose to preach intolerance and hatred. In China it is still early enough to reshape this nationalist tide.

HEADLINE: An Enron Legacy: Lower Reported Profits 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
"FAIRLY" is the forgotten word of American accounting. But the Enron debacle threatens to make it a very contentious word as scared auditors suddenly decide that they should rein in corporations.
 The auditor's letter in every annual report certifies that the statements therein "present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position" of the company, "in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America." 
 Enron was not the only company to push the rules, to be "aggressive in its transaction structuring," as an Arthur Andersen partner put it in one memo. Many auditors have been willing to sign off on anything that could be shoehorned into the letter of the rules, whatever their spirit, and have been willing to overlook rule violations if the amounts involved could be deemed immaterial.
There is a historical pattern in such things, one that was recognized by the economist Charles P. Kindleberger in his classic 1978 book "Manias, Panics and Crashes." "The propensities to swindle and be swindled run parallel to the propensity to speculate during a boom," he wrote. After the revelation of the fraud, and the collapse of the boom, he added, "the curtain rises on revulsion."
There is no proof of fraud at Enron, but the revulsion is clear. "All the accountants with the Big Five will be tougher," Mr. Kindleberger forecast in a telephone interview yesterday. "There is a lot of turmoil going to occur in financial accounting."
"I would," he added, "love to be young enough to write a chapter on Enron. But I am slowing down." He is 91.
Just as the 1929 crash led to the establishment of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the current S.E.C. chairman, Harvey L. Pitt, vows to come up with a new body to discipline accountants. His proposal yesterday sounds promising. 
But in one way, it does not matter. Talk about sending accountants and executives to prison -- people who no doubt view themselves as upright, law-abiding citizens -- is concentrating attention among their peers.
"The ease with which an accountant, or a Wall Street analyst, will allow you to be creative is likely to change ahead of legal changes and industry governance changes, simply because they don't want to be in anything similar" to Enron, said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
The issue is not just fraud. In recent decades, operating earnings, as reported by companies, have consistently risen much more rapidly than net income, as losses were treated as extraordinary. And net income rose faster than corporate profits as reported in the government's national income accounts. Creative accounting by one company was quickly imitated by others.
If that changes enough, the overall growth of reported earnings could fall. Auditors will probably make lots of little decisions that, together, will force corporate America to report lower profits than it would have without the reaction to this scandal. Rules will become tougher as loopholes abused by Enron are closed. Even when companies are allowed to report dubious profits, they may be forced to disclose what they did. Investors will react.
Cynics will rightly say that there have been other accounting scandals and that nothing of the kind happened. But this one has shaken accountants more than any other. Change is coming, and the result is likely to be more conservative financial reporting. When accountants use the word "fairly," they may really mean it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles P. Kindleberger (Basic Books)

HEADLINE: Unemployment Shoots Up In December 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New York City shot up last month to 7.4 percent from 6.9 percent as more than 10,000 jobs disappeared from the city's battered economy, government officials said yesterday.
 The December decline brought the job losses since the attack on the World Trade Center to more than 100,000 -- a record-breaking drop for a three-month period that surpassed even the steep decline that began in November of 1990, according to William C. Thompson Jr., the New York City comptroller. 
 Even so, economists generally breathed a sigh of relief when the data was released yesterday. "The numbers aren't good, but they could have been a lot worse," said Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist at The New York Stat, a newsletter. 
Some forecasters had worried that the pace of job losses might not slow after November, when about 20,000 jobs disappeared from the city. In October, the first month in which the data reflected the effects of Sept. 11, roughly 69,000 jobs were lost in the city, although some of them were simply moved across the river to Jersey City.
"While there are still declines in the city, it is certainly a moderation of what we had seen in the previous couple of months," said James A. Parrott, chief economist at the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research organization. 
But he suggested that the unemployment rate, which has jumped by more than one percentage point since September, may well continue to rise; about a third more people applied for unemployment benefits in the last month than in the same period last year.
Getting a grip on exactly how many jobs have been lost in any month, or even since September, is hard, because of what economists call seasonal factors (for example, stores usually hire extra sales help in the months before Christmas). Private economists and city officials use various methods to adjust for these factors, while the New York State Department of Labor does not make any seasonal adjustments to jobs data except on a statewide level.
On an unadjusted basis, New York City actually gained more than 7,000 jobs in December, typically a banner month for tourism and retail-related employment. But in December 2000, the city gained more than 22,000 jobs.
After adjusting for seasonal factors -- which means trying to figure out what kind of hiring should have happened in more normal circumstances -- the number of jobs in the city fell in December. Several private economists estimated the drop at about 11,000, while Mr. Thompson's office put it at 13,500.
But there were bright spots, or at least brightish spots. James P. Brown, the Labor Department's specialist in the New York City economy, said he was pleased that there were signs that stores, bars, restaurants and hotels had hired some people in December. The upturn "was quite subdued by our usual standards, but it was there," he said. "I'm pleased to see any gain."
Airline-related employment, which has fallen by more than 21 percent in the last 12 months, continued to decline.
Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said that the December job declines in the city were more in line with those that occurred nationally than in the previous months, which suggests that the worst of the economic aftermath of the trade center disaster may be over. Of course, the national economy is in recession, but the biggest problems are still in manufacturing, which makes up only a small portion of the city's economic and employment base.
In fact, a report released on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve Board found that economic activity "showed further signs of rebounding" in the New York region, while things continued to go downhill in areas like Dallas and San Francisco.
One negative sign in New York City was a continued decline in employment on Wall Street, which over the last year has shed almost 22,000 jobs, many of them in the last three months. High-paid Wall Street workers pay a lot of taxes, spend a lot of money in stores and restaurants, and keep a lot of other people employed, whether they are computer consultants or golf pros or taxi drivers.
And while the number of jobs in the securities industry fell by slightly more than a thousand in December, the real decline was probably larger, because some Wall Street workers returned to Lower Manhattan last month from New Jersey, Mr. Brown said.

HEADLINE: Japan Slows Down, but Not Its Road Builders 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SHIMIZU, Japan 

 BODY:
With massive white concrete pylons rising from a small farming valley, the New Tomei Expressway is emerging as Japan's answer to Germany's autobahn. Engineers are attacking mountains, straightening curves, smoothing inclines, and placing 60 percent of the highway on bridges or in tunnels, all in an effort to allow drivers to speed along at nearly 90 miles an hour. 
 The problem is, in 21st-century Japan, building new highways has the air of looking at the world through a rear-view mirror. 
 With Florida-style demographics and a European-type rail network, it is unlikely that hordes of aging Japanese are going to jump behind the wheel for a high-speed cruise. Since 1990, vehicle sales here have dropped by nearly a quarter. 
"It is absolutely, 100 percent unnecessary," said Hideki Kato, president of Japan Initiative, a Tokyo research agency. 
So as construction advances at a cost of $1 million for every six yards, this six-lane luxury highway may stand as a monument to Japan's late-20th-century addiction to concrete. 
Highway construction here once enjoyed wide popular support as a way to spread Tokyo's wealth and to reduce rural isolation and poverty in this California-sized nation. But in recent years, road construction projects have taken on the air of government make-work programs, intended to disguise Japan's growing unemployment. 
In fact, Japan has spent trillions of dollars in the 1990's in an effort to build its way back to economic growth. But instead it finds itself today deep in recession and saddled with daunting construction bills -- the world's largest government debt and an annual deficit that increased fivefold in the last decade. 
In Japan's new budget, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has succeeded in cutting highway spending, using money saved to seed future growth -- computers in schools, job training for laid-off workers, health care for the elderly, and child care to allow women who are now at home to join the paid work force.
A recent Nihon Keizai Shimbun poll showed that 77 percent of Japanese citizens, tired of the "construction state," supported the prime minister's effort to privatize the Japan Highway Public Corporation, the nation's major road builder.
"Those who are asking the government to build expressways are limited to the heads of local governments and presidents of construction companies," Nobuteru Ishihara, minister for administrative and regulatory reforms, said to applause at one of 50 government-sponsored town meetings held across Japan last fall. 
Still, those are powerful government bureaucracies and private lobbyists, whose voices, along with rural constituents, have carried clout with the governing Liberal Democrats throughout their half-century in power. 
One conspicuous no-show at the town meetings was Chikage Ogi, Japan's construction minister. At her ministry, employees still sing the Utopia Song, an agency anthem that rhapsodizes about "asphalt blanketing the mountains and valleys."
Pro-construction politicians, known as the "road tribe," have been resisting the budget cuts. All three research councils of the Liberal Democratic Party want to keep in place a plan to spend $160 billion over the coming years to increase Japan's 4,321-mile expressway network by two-thirds. 
This is so even though truck traffic along the old Tomei expressway has actually declined since 1995, with the erosion of Japan's manufacturing base. The New Tomei would double the number of lanes along the same route. 
"In all the prefectures, all of the Diet members and all the governors are very enthusiastically supporting construction of the second Tomei," said Tadatsune Kajimoto, director of a new industrial park, where noted that companies, in anticipation of the new roadway, had already moved in. "If the government doesn't keep its promises, it is very irresponsible." 
Ryotaro Nishigaya, an orange grower here, agreed, saying, "Talk about freezing construction is outrageous." The father of four adult children, he predicted that driving would increase in Japan, saying, "Each household could have three to five cars."
Others said traffic would increase if the government cut tolls, currently $30 for drive of 80 or so miles from here to Tokyo's western suburbs. 
Still, critics say, Japan is littered with public works projects built with little concern about profitability. From heroes of development, construction company presidents have became villains of economic stagnation, and are accused today of building bridges and bullet trains to nowhere.
"We are starting to look like medieval Spain, wasting our money on useless things," grumbled Hideaki Mizuno, an investment banker in Tokyo. "We need to use market mechanisms to allocate money."
That would be a change from the recent past. During the 1990's, construction employment increased by 17 percent, while construction investment fell by 12.5 percent, according to a study by the Research Institute of Construction and Economy, a private Tokyo research group. 
Alex Kerr, author of "Dogs and Demons, Tales from the Dark Side of Japan" (Hill and Wang 2001), writes that Japan will spend "three to four times more than what the United States, with 20 times the land area and more than double the population, will spend on public construction in the same period." 
He cited statistics indicating that Japan lays about 30 times as much concrete per square foot as the United States.
The explanation is relatively simple for Taro Kono, a member of Parliament whose suburban district west of Tokyo is crossed by the existing Tomei expressway: "There are politicians who need the construction industry, for money and votes."
Mr. Kono said he was one of only two Liberal Democratic members opposed to the New Tomei. Of 243 party members in the lower house, he said, the only other opponent "is the prime minister." 
Despite the public support he enjoys, Prime Minister Koizumi managed only mixed results in his recent showdown with Parliament over highway spending.
In the 2002 budget, he succeeded in abolishing the government's annual direct payment to the Highway Corporation, $2.3 billion last year, and cutting public works spending by 10.7 percent, as part of a plan to reduce it by one-quarter over the next five years.
But the prime minister did not win backing for a 30-year limit on repaying the Highway Corporation's debt, which would have ended much new highway construction, including the New Tomei. Estimates of the corporation's debt range from $150 billion to $220 billion. 
A panel is to be appointed to set a deadline and a method for privatizing the corporation and three other public road-building corporations.
Skeptics call this a defeat for Mr. Koizumi. Others say this was the path taken 15 years ago with the successful privatization of Japan National Railways.

(Stuart Isett/Gamma, for The New York Times) Map of Japan highlighting Tomei Expressway: The Tomei Expressway is costing $1 million for every six yards.

HEADLINE: In Famously Tolerant City, Impatience With Homeless 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
After three hours of begging for change in a chilly, wind-swept fog, all Tricia T. could show for it was a pair of stiff hands, purple and gnarled from the cold, and 75 cents.
 Bad luck and worse health -- colon cancer -- have left her, at 58, completely broke, having lost her job as a telemarketer eight months ago and her apartment not long afterward. After her clothes and shoes were repeatedly stolen in a city shelter, she began panhandling on a street median to raise money for a $40-a-night hotel room. 
 Ms. T. (who said she did not want her last name in the newspaper out of humiliation at her condition), said the spare change that drivers handed her was the only public assistance she received. 
"I don't know what I'd do," she said, her eyes tearing up behind thick glasses, "if I didn't have this option." 
She may soon find out.
A proposed ordinance designed to curb panhandling would ban loitering on median strips, with violators subject to a $500 fine and six months in jail.
The proposal is one of many that legislators in this city known for its tolerance have recently introduced that point to a growing impatience with San Francisco's highly visible population of people living on the streets. 
Other proposals would create a special telephone line for people to report quality-of-life infractions like loitering, and an ordinance that would ban sleeping in public. 
"I'm walking past people who are sick in the streets," said Tony Hall, a city supervisor who suggested the ban on sleeping and relieving oneself in public (which require that the city double its shelter beds, to 3,500, and open about 100 public toilets). "It's getting to me and it's getting to other people."
Mr. Hall's sentiment resounds in cities across the country. But advocates for homeless people say that at a time when a bad economy and a tight housing market are creating record levels of homelessness, more and more cities are responding by cracking down on the consequences of homelessness -- the sleeping, urinating and shopping-cart-hauling habits of homeless people -- rather than by addressing the causes.
"Nationally, a big reason driving the phenomenon of the criminalization of homelessness is concern about the visibility of that population, especially with respect to how they affect businesses and tourism," said Maria Foscarinis, executive director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, an advocacy organization based in Washington.
The law center, in conjunction with the National Coalition for the Homeless, released a report on Tuesday declaring San Francisco, New York and Atlanta as the "top three meanest cities," when it comes to treatment of homeless people. 
The cities on the list all have ordinances that make the everyday activities of many homeless people subject to a jail term, Ms. Foscarinis said.
"There are legitimate concerns about having large numbers of people living in public," she said. "What we take issue with is what you do about it. Do you respond with passing laws or do you respond by providing an alternative to people living in public?"
In San Francisco, the most expensive city in the country, homeless people lugging trash bags with everything they own haunt downtown doorways and alleys, and the issue of homelessness generates daily headlines and unending debate. At least three successive mayors (in 16 years) have vowed to clear the streets of homeless people. None have promised to solve homelessness; the current mayor, Willie L. Brown Jr., has called it "intractable." 
The city has consistently made the advocacy organizations' "meanest cities" list, as one of the first to outlaw aggressive panhandling and soliciting money near A.T.M.'s, and to sweep people from the streets despite having few other options to offer them. But George Smith, director of the Mayor's Office on Homelessness, said the city had never driven homeless people away, as other cities have done.
"There are places that give homeless people one-way tickets out of town," Mr. Smith said. "So I don't know what they mean by 'mean.' All I know is that we've struggled in San Francisco about how to serve people who need help."
Certainly, everyone agrees, there are at least as many homeless people on the streets as ever. The city counts more than 7,300 people living in the streets or in emergency housing, but doubles that number when including those people who live in transitional housing and other impermanent housing, the definition used by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
In 1999, the city issued more than 42,000 citations to homeless people for infractions like sleeping in a park after hours or camping in public, according to the national report. Even so, calls for the city to do more have grown louder, with local television news shows and newspapers issuing special reports on the problems of street people.
In response, three months ago the city stepped up its practice of rousing sleeping people from doorways. The Department of Public Works now sends crews fanning through the streets, waking homeless people and scrubbing down their sidewalk sleeping place with disinfectant, so they have no choice but to move.
Gavin Newsom, a supervisor widely expected to run for mayor next year, recently offered several proposals that he said were designed to solve a problem that had "become out of control."
They include a new department of homelessness to replace the city's current hodgepodge system, a centralized method of processing single homeless people who enter the city's social service system, modeled after New York City's, and a database for tracking them, as well as ordinances banning loitering on street medians or in public garages.
"It's time for tough love, accountability and outcomes," said Mr. Newsom, who received favorable editorials and scores of approving e-mail messages after floating his ideas a few weeks ago.
Mr. Smith said a remedy he had seen in Chicago and New York that he might seek to use here involved centers that address specific areas of need.
The idea recognizes that there are different categories of homeless people, with different needs and capabilities, he said. So a mother and her children would be served differently than a single drug abuser, for example.
Such an ambitious idea is a long way from execution. And advocates for homeless people here say San Francisco should be wary of using New York, where a record high 29,400 homeless people live in city shelters and hotel rooms, as a model for ending homelessness.
"I don't see New York having solved homelessness," said Paul Boden, executive director of the San Francisco Coalition on Homelessness.
Mr. Boden has consistently found himself locking horns with the mayor and other politicians over their push to outlaw behavior associated with homeless people.
"A lot of stuff that's really frustrating," he said of the latest proposed ordinances, "is that we've seen all of this stuff before. We're enacting legislation that's used for media bites, as opposed to legislation that addresses the problem. It turns the debate around homelessness into this nasty debate about urinating and defecating and shooting up in the streets instead of 'How can we help the problem?' "
Harry Skinner, a 51-year-old Vietnam veteran who panhandles on a busy median strip, said he was surprised at all the recent attention given to people like himself.
"I sit here 12 hours and most people look right through me," Mr. Skinner said. "I've been thinking that maybe I'm really invisible."

HEADLINE: McGreevey Administration Hints at Tax Rebate Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Faced with a steep budget deficit, the administration of New Jersey's new governor, James E. McGreevey, is considering whether to repeal or reduce a property tax rebate program that paid the average homeowner $500 last year, state officials said today.
 Mr. McGreevey, who said during his election campaign that he did not intend to raise taxes, took office two days ago and immediately began searching for ways to close the $2.8 billion shortfall the state faces in the fiscal year that ends June 30. Today he announced that he had formed a commission of business leaders to search for ways to trim the budget. 
 But even the layoff of thousands of state workers and deep program cuts will not be enough to balance the state's books, and Mr. McGreevey today left open the possibility that some taxes could be increased.
"Literally every option is on the table with the exception of increasing sales and income taxes," he said. "Our first charge is reducing the size of government and changing the way New Jersey does business."
Mr. McGreevey was reluctant to discuss specific measures being considered. But possibilities include raising corporate taxes and scaling back the New Jersey Saver program, which offers property tax rebates and is scheduled to cost the state $1 billion this year. 
Anthony R. Coscia, who was named chairman of the Budget Efficiency Savings Team Commission, also avoided discussing any detailed numbers. But when pressed about the property tax rebate, he said "at $1 billion, it is obviously a target."
Taxes are a volatile issue and Republicans were quick to pounce on it. They accused Mr. McGreevey of reversing his campaign promise and compared him to former Gov. Jim Florio, another Democrat, who was run out of office after pushing a $2.8 billion tax increase through the Legislature in 1990. 
Throughout the campaign, Mr. McGreevey resisted a challenge from his Republican opponent, Bret D. Schundler, to sign a no-new-taxes pledge. In its final weeks, however, Mr. McGreevey said repeatedly that he would not increase taxes, though he stopped short of making the kind of blanket antitax pledge Mr. Schundler had sought.
John O. Bennett, the Republican co-president of the Senate, said he was "deeply concerned" that the governor appeared to be backing away from his pledge not to raise taxes. "We know now why Governor McGreevey failed to mention property taxes in his inaugural address," Mr. Bennett said. "He plans to slash property tax relief for working families throughout New Jersey." 
Mr. McGreevey and his staff now say that he was referring to the income and sales taxes. His spokesman, Paul Aronsohn, insisted that today's statements did not contradict the governor's campaign promises.
But Republicans characterized the statement as an about-face.
"We have learned the hard way that increasing taxes during an economic downturn is a recipe for disaster," Mr. Bennett said.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Are Lower 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
The number of new claims for jobless benefits fell unexpectedly last week to the lowest level in more than five months, the Labor Department said today, a sign the economy might be pulling out of recession. A separate report by the Commerce Department showed a drop in the construction of homes and apartments in December. 
 "The worst of the layoffs and the labor market weakness is behind us," said Tim McGee, chief strategist at UFJ Bank in New York. "There was an overreaction after Sept. 11, and businesses need to start going in the other direction." 
 Initial jobless claims decreased 14,000 in the week ended Saturday, to a seasonally adjusted 384,000. The number of applications has not been as low since the last week of July.
A Labor Department spokesman said seasonal adjustments had anticipated a larger increase in applications last week. Because the increase was 140,000 instead of the 160,000 expected, there was a decline in the claims reported. And the total number of unadjusted claims was 776,035, the highest in 11 years.
The four-week moving average of jobless claims, a less volatile indicator, ebbed to 411,000 from 411,250 a week earlier.
Housing starts fell 3.4 percent last month, to 1.57 million units at an annual pace, as builders undertook fewer new apartments. Economists had expected a 2.1 percent decline. The number of building permits increased 3.6 percent, to a 1.653 million annual pace. Work on single-family houses increased 3.6 percent. A total of 1.603 million homes were started last year, up 2.2 percent from 2000.
Also today, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its index of manufacturing rose to 14.7 this month, the first positive reading since November 2000.

HEADLINE: 3 Airlines Post Weaker Results 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Southwest Airlines posted a decrease in fourth-quarter profit today, while Northwest Airlines and the US Airways Group reported wider losses as the recession and Sept. 11 attacks kept travelers off planes.
 Southwest, the largest low-fare carrier, said profit fell 59 percent, to $63.5 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with $154.7 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
Northwest said its loss widened to $216 million, or $2.55 a share, from $69 million, or 84 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The loss at US Airways grew to a record $1.01 billion, or $14.89 a share, from $101 million, or $1.50 a share. 
 Southwest was the only major United States airline not to cut jobs or flights after the attacks.
"Southwest is probably going to pick up passengers and routes over the next 12 months while everybody else is going to be bleeding and shutting down routes," said Nick Redfield, an analyst for Banc One Investment Advisors. 
Sales at Southwest fell 16 percent, to $1.24 billion, while Northwest's slid 27 percent, to $1.99 billion. US Airways' sales declined 34 percent, to $1.57 billion.
Shares of Southwest rose 39 cents, to $17.90, while Northwest dropped 25 cents, to $23.05, and US Airways lost 41 cents, to $5.20. 
Southwest, which is based in Dallas, received government aid of $67 million before taxes. The airline lowered its average fare 8.4 percent, to $79.99, to win back passengers, and its fourth-quarter traffic slipped 0.5 percent from a year earlier.
Southwest's capacity rose 6.4 percent as other carriers scaled back as much as 26 percent. Yield, or average fare per mile, fell 15 percent. Costs per available seat mile fell 7.2 percent on lower jet fuel prices and travel agent commissions.

HEADLINE: A Bird That's on a Lot of Hit Lists 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CEDARVILLE, Mich., Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Rob Burger wants to stomp the eggs under his feet. Brian Harrison would like to round up 300 hunters and pump shotgun shells into the nests. Mark Clymer is ready to bypass the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and call in the Department of Defense.
 "I'd pull troops and carriers out of Afghanistan and napalm the rookeries," declared Mr. Clymer, 47, whose business card identifies him as a "problem solver" for computer and environmental systems. "For years, they've done fighter runs over the Great Lakes to practice bombing. Why not the real thing?" 
 The enemy in this tourist-dependent town in Michigan's Upper Peninsula is the double-crested cormorant, a gamefish-gobbling bird the residents blame for decimating the perch population and, along with it, the local economy. Since the cormorant became a protected species in 1972, the number of the birds in the Great Lakes has exploded, to more than 100,000 mating pairs from fewer than 100 pairs, overtaking geese as the birds fishermen love to hate. 
As for the perch caught, surveys by the Michigan Department of Natural Resources show that the number dropped to 20,000 last year from 145,000 in 1986.
After years of complaints from communities like this one on Lake Huron -- and from others from upstate New York to Southern California to the fish farms along the Mississippi River -- the federal government is offering to allow states and Indian tribes help reduce the cormorant population across the country by about 10 percent. But many here deride the proposal, contained in a draft environmental impact statement expected to be completed by the summer, as too little, too late. They suggest instead that 10 percent be the portion that survives.
Some say the fish and wildlife agency must take responsibility for, and finance, a coordinated national effort to control the birds they call vermin. Others want an open season on the bird (killing one now is punishable by jail time and a hefty fine). 
"I look at wildlife management as a way of manipulating population to benefit something that's valuable to people," said Gaylord Alexander, a fishery biologist who retired after 40 years with the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. "Rather than raising a million cormorants to sit out on these islands and annoy people, you could produce about 20 million more pounds of desirable game fish."
Ridiculed in the Old Testament as unfit for eating, likened to the Devil in Milton's "Paradise Lost," the cormorant has been hated throughout history. A 14th-century painting shows archers in Venice trying to shoot the birds in the back. 
The black, ducklike foragers, numbering about two million in North America, swallows about 1.5 pounds of fish each day and live for several years after they begin mating at age 3. Critics say their feces contaminate water and leave parasites that cause swimmer's itch. Their nesting grounds, including several of the 36 Les Cheneaux Islands that dot Lake Huron, deteriorate into fetid graveyards of skeletal conifers. 
Even the cormorant's defenders have a hard time sounding enthusiastic.
"They're kind of sinister looking," admitted Shauna Hanisch, the fish and wildlife agency's project manager on the environmental impact statement, which is open for public comments until Feb. 28. "A lot of people would say they have no use."
But Bette Stallman, a wildlife scientist at the Humane Society of America, said cormorants had simply become scapegoats for more complicated problems plaguing the nation's waters, including overfishing and pollution. Ms. Stallman noted, "Nature isn't always beautiful." 
Here in Cedarville, a town with one flashing-red stoplight, there is no doubt about the cormorant's guilt. They are blamed for reducing the number of fishing resorts here to 15 today from 56 in 1960. The only upside people see to the cormorants is dropping golf handicaps as old-time fishermen reluctantly switch hobbies.
Mr. Harrison, owner of the Great Outdoors sporting goods store, said his bait supplier once sold 30,000 wigglers a week in town. Now the order is down to 1,000, he said, and there are plenty of leftovers.
The cash register was quiet at the store this morning, but regulars sipped coffee in worn armchairs, as they do each day. The men here argue over everything -- from whose wife treats him best to the benefits of collectivism versus individualism. The group keeps a foot-thick Webster's on hand to settle disputes like last week's conundrum of whether "unthaw" is a word (yes, according to the 1957 unabridged).
The one thing they agree on is cormorants: killing them, as many as possible, as soon as possible.
"I'm not a hunter," said Mr. Burger, 34, a chef and contractor. "I tend to be a kind person -- this is the only thing that stirs me like this." 
"I thought this would be my dream residence," said Mr. Burger, who spent summers here as a boy and moved up full time several years ago, in part to share his beloved perch with his young sons. "I built a big house. Now I have to drive five hours to catch a fish."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Donations Continue to Rise as Another Record Falls

BYLINE:  KARI HASKELL 

 BODY:
After a dramatic upswing in donations, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund set a record on Tuesday, surpassing the $8.03 million collected in last year's campaign, also a record. By Wednesday, contributions reached an even higher record -- $8,309,809.99.
 "We are genuinely gratified that readers are so attentive to the growing needs of people in distress," said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund. The total number of gifts given to the fund has also risen, to 10,655 from 10,108 at this point last year. 
 A remarkable change in the 2001-2002 campaign is the number of online contributions made this year, Mr. Rosenthal said.
Tuesday's total included $250,000 given in December through CharityWave.com, an online donation service. With just a click of the mouse and a credit card, 1,215 people used the service to give to the fund, 157 percent more than the number of people who had used it at the same point last year.
The 2000-2001 campaign was the first time contributions could be made online; previously they were made only through the mail or on the phone. For this year's campaign, CharityWave.com raised its $500 contribution limit to $5,000. No transaction fee is charged for donations under $500, said Cristine Cronin, the director of CharityWave.
"There was a seismic shift of people turning to the Internet after 9/11," Ms. Cronin said. "People overcame their fears about the giving through the Internet by putting aside their security and privacy issues -- people just made a leap of faith." Donations in memory or in honor of loved ones have been popular, because CharityWave sends e-mails notifying the identified party, Ms. Cronin said.
Regardless of which method was used, contributions over the past few weeks have pushed the fund's giving record past last year's.
Beverly and David Hannon of Anamosa, Iowa, sent $20 to the Neediest Cases Fund. Ms. Hannon, a mother of six, said that instead of holiday presents, each family member requested a contribution to a charity. She made a total of 20 contributions to different charities in their names.
"After 9/11, Bush asked for people to spend," Ms. Hannon said. "Give to those who really need it, and their spending will stimulate the economy."
Ms. Hannon read about the fund on The New York Times Web site, nytimes.com. "The Neediest covers a lot of groups," said Ms. Hannon, referring to the seven organizations that fund supports. "It really appealed to me."
Andrea Norris, an art director at the University of Kansas, sent in $100. She said that the articles published about the city's poor in The New York Times each year were the key reason she gave to the fund.
"When I think of New York, it is my idea of the center of the country," Ms. Norris said.
"I grew up with The New York Times," said Ms. Norris, who added that she has never lived in the city. "When I saw that the Neediest was under, I decided to send a check."
Catherine Watson gave $200 this year, her first time gift to the fund.
"I primarily give to animal and environmental charities," said Ms. Watson, a writer for The Star Tribune of Minneapolis. "Like many people, I felt more connected to New York after 9/11."
Martin Friedlander, a native New Yorker who now lives in California, agreed. He donated $500. "I wanted to give to an organization, and where it was needed," he said. "New York is a great city with a lot of people in great need of help."

6 Killed by Palestinian At an Israeli Party
A Palestinian walked into a crowded reception hall in Hadera, Israel, and opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle, killing 6 people and wounding at least 25, witnesses and the police said. A group linked to Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement took responsibility for the attack. Early today, Israeli forces bombed a Palestinian government building in Tulkarm and tanks were also reported rolling through the West Bank city of Ramallah, where Israel has effectively confined Mr. Arafat since early last month. Toward a Stronger Silk
Scientists at a Canadian biotechnology company and United States Army researchers have spliced spider genes into cells from cows and hamsters and induced the cells to churn out a silk comparable to that produced by spiders. Pound for pound, spider silk is stronger than steel but also light, elastic and recyclable. A15

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: PC Sales Fell In 2001 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 In spite of unexpectedly strong personal computers purchases during the holidays, the worldwide and American PC markets declined in 2001 for only the second time, according to two market researchers. Gartner Dataquest said computer vendors sold 128 million PC's worldwide last year, a 4.6 percent decline from 2000, and 44 million units in the United States, an 11.1 percent drop, because of the poor economy and a saturated market. 
In the fourth quarter, PC shipments fell 6.7 percent from the period in 2000, but rose 16.9 percent from the dreary third quarter, according to the International Data Corporation. Businesses continued to delay computer upgrades, but improving confidence in the economy and price cuts prompted consumers to buy more PC's than anticipated last quarter. Unit sales declined by double digits last year for every PC vendor expect Dell Computer, whose sales rose 18.3 percent, enabling it to take over the worldwide lead from Compaq Computer early in 2001. Chris Gaither (NYT)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Gloomy Economic Assessment 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Japanese central bank said yesterday that the economy was "broadly worsening," the same wording that it used to describe conditions a month ago. Despite the glum assessment, the report for January represented the first time in seven months that the bank did not downgrade its view of the economy. 
Personal consumption, exports and business investments were all weakening, it said. In another report, the Finance Ministry said Japan's current account surplus, a crucial indicator of the nation's trade, rose 19.4 percent in November, compared with the month in the previous year, for the third consecutive increase. When releasing the figures yesterday, the ministry said the surplus in the current account rose to 1.1 trillion yen ($8.3 billion) in November. The ministry cautioned that the surplus could shrink in coming months, especially if the United States economy deteriorated and demand for Japanese goods fell.

HEADLINE: Airbus Plans $530 Million In Cost Cuts 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Feeling the pinch of weakening demand for aircraft after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Airbus Industrie said today that it would cut costs by $530 million this year through early retirement of about 1,200 employees and other measures. Executives said that by eliminating overtime and part-time work, the company would reduce its labor costs the equivalent of 4,800 more full-time jobs without resorting to layoffs. 
 Airbus's approach contrasts sharply with that of its American rival Boeing, which has announced 30,000 layoffs in its commercial aircraft business. Noel Forgeard, president and chief executive of Airbus, said the company expected orders to pick up again in 2003, but "if the volume goes further down, we could consider layoffs." 
 Airbus and Boeing are locked in ever more bitter competition as they confront a cyclical plunge in the market that Mr. Forgeard says is "not unprecedented, even if the cause of the crisis is new and especially worrying for our industry." Like Boeing, he said, Airbus will aggressively seek military contracts, waters that the company has hardly tested before now, to offset the plunge in civilian sales.
John J. Leahy, senior vice president for sales at Airbus, said he expected airlines to order a total of only 300 to 350 large civilian airliners from Airbus and Boeing this year, down from 546 in 2001. 
Mr. Forgeard said he and Mr. Leahy would visit major airline customers in the spring to size up the effect of the plunge in air travel on their aircraft purchasing plans. Even if orders come in at the bottom of the forecast range, Mr. Forgeard said, Airbus will deliver 300 new aircraft in 2002 that were ordered in earlier years. 
Airbus and Boeing are the only remaining Western makers of jetliners, and Boeing remains larger, with 68,000 employees after its announced cutbacks; Airbus expects to employ 44,500 people at the end of 2002, according to Gustav Humbert, its chief operating officer. 
Boeing delivered 527 planes last year, 62 percent of the total, but its leadership is clearly threatened. Airbus said it booked more new orders, for a greater dollar value, than Boeing did in 2001. Its backlog of 1,575 orders is 218 more than Boeing has reported.
"This means that in future $2 out of $3 spent to take large commercial aircraft will go to Airbus," Mr. Forgeard said.
Mr. Forgeard said that customers canceled orders for 101 aircraft last year, but that 90 percent of the cancellations came from three defunct or troubled carriers -- T.W.A., Swissair and Sabena. 
Taking account of those cancellations, Airbus said it booked a net 374 new orders last year, worth $37.3 billion, or 62 percent of the total market by value. It delivered 325 aircraft worth $20.5 billion, up from 311 in 2000.
Airbus began life as a loose consortium of European aerospace contractors, but it gelled last year into a unified company, 80 percent owned by the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company and 20 percent by BAE Systems of Britain. Shares in both companies rose on today's news.
Mr. Leahy said airlines could not expect substantial price cuts on jets because prices are linked to production costs. But Mr. Forgeard said that Airbus relied at times on aircraft leasing companies, which account for up to 30 percent of Airbus sales, to provide financing to potential customers. Airbus reduced its debt by $300 million in 2001, he said, giving it more scope to negotiate financing packages.
Airbus's first major military contract is for construction of a new transport, the A400M, to replace aging models like the Lockheed C-130 Hercules. Mr. Forgeard sees potential markets for Airbus-built military refueling tankers, electronic warfare and maritime patrol craft. But he said the company would be up against fierce competition from Boeing, which he said was able to make subsidized military sales abroad because of generous treatment by the Pentagon.
He cited a recent decision by Congress to allow the Air Force to replace aging tankers by leasing 100 Boeing 767's for 10 years at $20 million a year each. Airbus, which had no chance to bid for the contract, Mr. Forgeard said, could have beaten that price by 40 percent. 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 31, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in World Business on Jan. 18 about cost-cutting at Airbus Industrie misstated the number of orders for new jets the company received in 2001, after taking cancellations into account. It was 274, not 374.
