HEADLINE: Little Has Changed, Except the Population 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
FOR nearly two centuries, the small town of Sherman has lived a relatively anonymous existence, and that's the way residents not only like it but strive to keep it.
 After all, this is a community where neighbors still check on one another to make sure they are O.K. The firemen's ball is one of the biggest social events of the year, and a stranger with an honest face may be asked to mind a store if an employee needs to step outside. 
 It's this Norman Rockwell flavor along with a good school system and relatively cheaper land and lower taxes that has long made residents treasure their town. But in the past decade, those same qualities have also been responsible for more than 1,000 people moving here, earning Sherman the distinction of being the fastest growing town in the state. 
Not everyone is happy about it. 
While Connecticut cities like Hartford may be struggling to make a name for themselves and maintain or increase their population, residents of this northern Fairfield County community would rather no one had heard of the town.
"It's like that good restaurant that you find down around the corner," First Selectman Arthur von Plachecki explained. "You don't want everyone to know about it so when you want to go there for dinner you can get a reservation."
In fact, Mr. von Plachecki, who contributed to the population boom by moving here in 1993, hesitated to be interviewed for this article.
"It's our kind of secret little corner of the world," he said. "I really didn't want everyone to know about it."
According to the United States Census, it may be too late for that. From 1990 to 2000, Sherman saw its population surge from 2,809 to 3,827, an increase of 1,018, or 36.2 percent. Colchester was the second fastest growing town, with its population rising 32.5 percent.
What's interesting is that Sherman is an out-of-the-way community. The closest urban center, Danbury, is about 20 miles away, or about a half-hour drive, depending on the traffic and time of day. But while it may seem remote, Sherman's expanding population is symbolic of a trend that is sweeping the state, according to Robert G. Cromley, director of the Center for Geographic Information and Analysis at the University of Connecticut. 
"That's where all the growth is occurring, is out of the way places," Mr. Cromley said.
Mr. Cromley said an analysis of the census data shows people are looking to move from the cities and inner ring suburbs to the fringe of metropolitan areas, where they can find more space and cheaper land. It's becoming easier to do because most families have multiple cars, he said.
"With everybody working and everybody having more freedom of movement, it's allowing the population to move farther and farther out," he said. "And people are choosing lifestyles that are more kind of rustic, so to speak."
Though it does not lack sophistication, Sherman certainly fits the image of a quaint New England community with its historic 19th century downtown village. 
Tucked between the New York border and the northern shore of Candlewood Lake, the town, which celebrates its bicentennial this year, has road signs that warn motorists of bridle path crossings and monthly jazz vespers at a local church are advertised by a homemade sign that is plopped down on a stretch of grass at the town's main intersection.
There are horse farms and stone walls and waterfront communities that offer sweeping views of Candlewood Lake. And, as Katie Harrison, a real estate agent, put it," Sherman has "one of everything."
There's one traffic light. One bank. One grocery store. One gas station and one school. There are two churches in town, and, she added, "There's definitely more than one town gossip."
The town is so small that when a reporter recently tried to interview a cashier at the historical society's gift shop, the employee said, "Do you have two seconds? Great. You're in charge," before running across the street to use the bathroom.
And when a neighbor of Janet Goldberg, a retired social worker who moved here last year from Pelham Manor, N.Y., hadn't seen Ms. Goldberg in a while, the neighbor called to make sure she was O.K.
"When does that happen?" Ms. Goldberg asked. "I think that's wonderful."
It's that sense of community that convinced Mr. von Plachecki to settle there. A self-described corporate nomad, Mr. von Plachecki moved to Sherman from southern California after his company, Aetna, transferred him to Westchester County. He has since retired, but he and his wife decided to remain in Sherman.
"We have lived here longer than anywhere we have lived in 40 years of being married," he said. 
"I think it's the people," he explained of his decision to stay. "I think that it's one of the few places left that still has a real sense of helping your neighbor, of volunteerism, of being concerned with what's going on with the community."
While that may have been the reason why Mr. von Plachecki moved here, it was the town's low crime rate, median household prices and school system among other things that prompted Connecticut Magazine to name Sherman the best small town in Connecticut three times in the past six years. The rating was based on a comparison of communities with populations that are less than 4,700.
According to the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development, the median sales price for a home in Sherman in 1999, the most recent year available, was $266,250, compared with $565,000 in Darien and $580,000 in Westport, two other Fairfield County towns. In the same year, Sherman residents were less likely to be a victim of a crime. The crime rate there was 10 per 1,000 residents compared with 14 in Darien and 24 in Westport. Darien topped all three towns in the results of the Connecticut Master Test given to eighth graders in the fall of 1999, but the other two towns were close behind and all were well above the state average.
Ms. Harrison and her business partner, Kathy Fazzone, said the publicity from the magazine helped attract attention to Sherman.
"That seemed to bring in a lot of young families," Ms. Fazzone said. 
Suddenly the town, which has long been a popular summer and weekend retreat, became an outer ring suburb. 
The Sherman School, which serves grades K-8, has had its enrollment nearly double in the past 10 years, jumping from 255 to 480, said Daniel J. Murphy, the school's principal.
The growth meant the town had to do a much-needed $10 million school addition and renovation, which included a new library media center, more classrooms, a computer lab, full-size cafeteria and kitchen, Mr. Murphy said. 
The popularity of Sherman also has put pressure on longtime landowners like Richard and Bill McGoldrick, brothers who have received inquiries from developers. The McGoldrick's are third generation Sherman farmers, who specialize in beef and hay. Between them, they own 150 acres. 
"It's kind of heart breaking to see how much development there is," said Richard McGoldrick, 64, who has lived in Sherman his entire life. "We're trying our best to keep it from developing any of our property but we just hope we can hold out."
His 70-year-old brother, Bill, who worked for J.P. Morgan before he retired in 1989 and returned to Sherman to help with the farm, gave 35 acres of his land to a local land trust this year. He said he hopes to give more in the future. 
And the growth has meant that the town has lost some of its close-knit feel, longtime residents said. 
When John O'Connor moved here in 1961, if a "strange car went through town, everybody knew," he said.
These days, people actually complain about traffic. Route 37, which runs through the historic center of town, has become so busy that Anda J. Styler, an acrylic painter and resident, said she no longer goes there to paint because "there's a million people driving by." 
Yet the town still seems rural to newcomers like Mrs. Goldberg. Her husband, who was raised in Brooklyn, is still trying to adjust to things like the absence of street lights. 
"He's never lived anywhere in his whole life where you couldn't walk out the door and see at night," she said, laughing.
That's just one aspect of living in a rural community. And, as Michael Crawford, a selectman, said, "If you like small towns, you'll love Sherman."
Just do the town residents a favor. Don't tell anybody about it.

Still, for Fairfield County, housing prices are reasonable. (Photographs by Don Heiny for The New York Times)(pg. 4); It doesn't look like a boom town, but that's what Sherman is. The last census reported that its population rose 36 percent, the largest jump in the state. HEADLINE: Newsday Leads Trend Toward Thin Papers 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

DATELINE: MELVILLE 

 BODY:
FOR Newsday, Long Island's hometown newspaper, 2002 got off to a lean start.
 The paper began the new year by shrinking from three sections to two on weekdays, eliminating 48 pages of news content each week. Last week, hundreds of employees received buyout offers intended to cut 50 to 100 jobs. 
 Industry analysts say that papers across the country are suffering from reduced advertising revenues in the current economic downturn -- the worst advertising drop for newspapers since the Great Depression -- and are being forced to make cuts. But analysts say no other paper of Newsday's size and stature has cut back as far. 
"We've seen some nipping and tucking, with papers folding some sections into others," said Douglas M. Arthur, a newspaper industry analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But I can't think of any top-10 newspaper making that significant a reduction in coverage."
No one suggests that the changes are a sign of impending doom for Newsday, which is read by more than 577,000 people daily and more than 675,000 on Sundays, making it the eighth-largest newspaper in the country. Newsday, which has won 16 Pulitzer Prizes, is widely regarded as one of the nation's best newspapers and acts as a powerful civic institution on Long Island, which has 2 counties, 13 towns, 2 cities, 95 incorporated villages and no real center.
But the recent changes have rattled workers worried about their jobs and readers concerned about the paper's quality.
Veteran employees are mulling their options, and younger, more recently hired workers fear that they may be subject to layoffs if not enough people opt for buyouts.
"Sure, people are worried," said Dennis A. Grabhorn, the president of Local 406 of the Graphic Communications International Union, which represents most of Newsday's employees. "Right now, nobody knows what the future holds." 
Newsday eliminated 50 jobs last year, part of about 1,400 positions that were cut throughout the Tribune Company, which acquired Newsday when it bought the paper's owner, the Times Mirror Company, in June 2000.
The Tribune Company, the nation's third-largest media corporation, also owns The Chicago Tribune, The Los Angeles Times, 8 other daily newspapers and 23 television stations, including WPIX, Channel 11 in New York. Knight Ridder, the nation's second-largest newspaper chain, reduced the work force at its 32 daily newspapers, including The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer, by about 2,000 people.
The New York Times Company, which owns this newspaper, The Boston Globe and 16 other papers and 8 television stations, cut its work force by about 1,200 last year, including about 400 positions at The Times itself.
"Earnings are down, and companies are responding rather aggressively across the country," said John Morton, a Maryland-based newspaper and media industry analyst. "What will be interesting to see is if there is a recovery, will they restore what they cut?"
Stuart Vincent, a spokesman for Newsday, said the paper hoped to see pages return eventually but had not determined if it would ever try to revive the three-part format. "Our publisher has said all along that the newspaper industry is cyclical, and right now we're at the bottom of the cycle," he said. "It's just a question of when it will come back."
Raymond A. Jansen, the publisher, and Anthony Marro, the editor, declined to be interviewed for this article, but in an article published in Newsday last month about the cuts, Mr. Jansen was quoted as saying, "To keep the company healthy we have to shrink." He added that even though there would be fewer sections and pages, the quality of the paper would remain high. "I don't think it will be that noticeable," he said.
But some readers were not persuaded. One of them, Michael Kaminer, wrote an angry letter to the paper and said Mr. Jansen's comment that the reductions would not be "that noticeable" was "an insult to the intelligence of your readers."
In an interview, Mr. Kaminer, the owner of a public-relations company in Manhattan, said the elimination of two sections -- one on Wednesdays about computers and electronics, the other on Thursdays, a guide to live music and the regional club scene -- was very apparent to him as a reader.
"A lot of the things in these Part 3 sections were what made people like me really enjoy reading the paper," he said, adding that he already missed a column on interesting Web sites and articles by music and dance critics.
"When you travel, you see that a lot of papers elsewhere all seem to carry wire copy and then run just a few local things that really give the paper and the place some character," Mr. Kaminer said. "I don't think Newsday is anywhere near be coming that, but I hate to think that might be where it's headed."
In addition to eliminating the Wednesday and Thursday sections entirely, Newsday has slimmed down what used to run in Monday's Business Report, Tuesday's Discovery section on science, medicine and health, and Friday's Real Estate section, and folded what remains into Part 2, the traditional features section of the paper. Capsule movie reviews have been eliminated from the weekly television guide, and stock tables on most weekdays have been reduced to one page from the previous four to five pages. The Saturday stock tables, reporting on Friday's markets, were eliminated in 1996.
Mr. Vincent said the 48-page reduction would affect all of the paper, including local, state, national and foreign coverage, and sports, business and entertainment news. He said there would be significant savings on paper and delivery costs, but he did not give a specific amount. When there were three sections, the second and third sections were printed and delivered to dealers first, and the trucks would make a second run to deliver the front section. Now the entire paper will be delivered in one run.
Robert M. Johnson, the publisher of Newsday from 1985 to 1994 and now the chairman of Bowne & Company, a Manhattan printing company, said he could understand the decision to eliminate the third section of the paper. The section was added in 1997, when the boom times of the 1990's translated into heavier advertising. Some of the cutbacks, like the technology coverage, mirror cuts other papers have made as technology advertising has fallen sharply.
"If they never attracted the advertising support they wanted, I could see cutting back there," Mr. Johnson said of the third section. "On the other hand, I think cutting back on the stock listings and on other general coverage is a real mistake. That makes the paper less complete and makes it a less valuable newspaper."
Being able to find stock listings and broad coverage of news in Newsday, he said, makes it easier to persuade readers that they need no other newspaper. "Cutting that many pages is a far more fundamental decision than just cutting staff," he said. "It changes the look and feel of the newspaper. And I'm disappointed as a reader."
Newsday is no stranger to upheaval. In 1995, the Times Mirror Company shut down New York Newsday, the paper's foray into the New York City market. About 800 jobs were lost then, but Newsday maintained a city edition and a newsroom in Queens.
While the latest cuts are no doubt prompted by the listless economy, several Newsday reporters said there was a general feeling that the cuts would have been less severe if the Tribune Company had not been the corporate owner. The Tribune Company has a reputation for guarding the bottom line with greater zeal than Newsday's former owner, Times Mirror, and last year's cutbacks at Newsday, which resulted in early retirement for about 50 workers, were part of a corporatewide effort. Last November, the company also announced salary cuts for top executives at all of its businesses and a wage freeze for 18,000 nonunion employees.
Fred Bruning, a reporter for Part 2 and a vice president of Local 406, said that although the impending buyouts might be advantageous for some employees, the loss of those workers would be felt by those who stay. "Because the Tribune feels a need to reduce staff, there will be some very familiar faces and valuable people who are apt not to be here," he said. "And the operation as a whole is diminished by that." 
Gary Weitman, a spokesman for the Tribune Company, said that while there was no formal freeze, hiring would be limited to critical functions. He would not say whether 2002 might bring layoffs but instead reiterated a statement the company made when it announced the salary reductions and freezes in November.
"We said then that the Tribune would further reduce corporate expenses and that all of the company's business units would implement further cost-saving measures," he said. "We have a reputation for being a very efficient company, and we've always prided ourselves on that."
He added that Newsday was the only Tribune paper so far to eliminate sections.
The Tribune Company reported last month that its revenues for the first 11 months of 2001 were $4.8 billion, down 7 percent from $5.1 billion during the same period in 2000.
Some media experts said that despite the loss of some coverage in Newsday, they are heartened by the paper's recent efforts to expand its reach by entering into partnerships with WPIX-TV, Channel 11; News 12 Long Island, the Cablevision station; and WALK-FM. In all three cases, reporters from Newsday produce broadcast segments as well as articles that will be reported in the next day's paper.
Abby Kenigsberg, a journalism professor at Nassau Community College, said she saw these efforts as Newsday's attempt to make the paper into a recognizable brand in a variety of media, a move that was part of a bigger trend nationally.
"If less money is coming in, then you have to reassess your services," she said. "Like all other communications companies, they're pulling back, but at the same time, they're expanding into other technologies, including the Internet."
Ms. Kenigsberg noted that some of the features that have been cut from the newspaper, like music and television listings and a real estate advice column, would be available on Newsday's Web site. "So they're not dumping information," she said. "They're just putting it in a way that's more cost-effective, and they're gently redirecting the reader."
Robert W. Greene, a retired Newsday assistant managing editor who is now the chairman of the journalism department at Hofstra University, said that while some of the changes might be jarring to readers, most would adjust, just as they had in past reconfigurations. "The newspaper business is always contracting and expanding," he said.
Mr. Vincent, the Newsday spokesman, said the cutbacks would not affect the effort to increase circulation and improve coverage in its New York City edition, which is sold primarily in Queens. The paper announced plans to bolster that edition last year and increased the staff for that edition from 45 to 60 people.
Mr. Greene said it was important that Newsday had no plans to pull back in the city. "So even if they're contracting in one area, they're still poised to make a move in another if the same contraction is hurting The Daily News or The Post," he said.
Newsday's franchise on Long Island remained intact, he added.
"Newsday will always be a profitable newspaper because it has an absolute monopoly over three million people," Mr. Greene said. "It's their regional newspaper. It'll always be there."

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about economies at Newsday referred incorrectly to reductions in the newspaper's stock tables. The decision was announced by the paper in December; it has not yet been carried out.

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 9

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
Buying a First Home: How the Times Have Changed

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
WHEN Laura and Philip Carey purchased their first home last year, their motivations were much the same as those of average first-time home buyers in Long Island of about 30 years ago: own a house where they could raise a family in a good school district. But three decades have brought significant differences in the pursuit of that dream, starting with the purchase price. 
 Unlike many married women in the 1970's, Laura Carey, who is 37, will continue working after her baby is born in April so she can help to pay for the $320,000 four-bedroom colonial in South Huntington. The price is considered average for Long Island but is affordable to the Careys only if both of them work. And the Careys are at least 10 years older than the typical first-time home buyer of the 1960's and 1970's. 
 "We had both been scrimping and saving for a house for years, and family members helped us," said Mrs. Carey, an administrator for a software company in Melville. Her husband works in the floor-covering business in Manhattan. The 36-year-old house was way over their budget, she said, but it had just been totally renovated and had a brand-new kitchen and a fireplace. 
"It had everything we didn't think we could afford," she said. "Any other house we looked at in that price range would have required at least $50,000 of fixing before I could be happy." 
In the mid-1960's, Trudy and Adam Gaus, who were then in their 20's, were able to purchase their $22,500 three-bedroom cedar-shaked ranch house in Hauppauge on Mr. Gaus's $12,000-a-year engineer's salary. The newly built house had a full basement, a den with a fireplace, an eat-in-kitchen and a dining room. Mrs. Gaus gave up her job as an art teacher and stayed at home to raise her two sons. This year, she said, a similar house in the neighborhood sold for $350,000. 
Specialists in Long Island's demography say the profile of the average first-time home buyer has drastically changed since the late 1960's.
"Back then, the value of a house was twice that of the median income and was affordable on one salary," said Roy Fedelem, principal planner at the Suffolk County Planning Department.
"Between 1980 and 1990, all that changed -- the house prices tripled," he said. "While the income went up as well, it wasn't enough, and that's when we had a problem. A family with a median income could no longer afford a median-income house on one salary." 
In November 2001, the average house in Nassau County closed for $337,724, and in Suffolk for $268,836, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors.
Katy Anastasio, the principal of Anastasio Associates in Huntington, who sold the Careys their house, said many houses selling for about the average price today require extensive repairs.
"Amazingly enough, what is often considered an average house price on Long Island today is between $300,000 and $500,000, because upscale has increased to $750,000 to over a million," she said. "Many of those buying for $400,000 and $500,000 are first-time buyers in a category once reserved for second-time home buyers who were moving up."
Pearl Kamer, chief economist of the Long Island Association, a Commack-based business group, said "a gradual shift in the economy to white-collar service" over the past 30 years has added to the changing profile of the first-time home buyer.
Since the downsizing of the defense industries on Long Island in the late 1980's and early 1990's, she said, there are fewer blue collar workers in manufacturing jobs and more in white collar service jobs, encompassing a wide range of positions, including high-salary financial, advertising and technology jobs; business owners; and teachers.
In November, out of a total of 1,250,000 jobs on Long Island, 108,000 or about 10 percent, were in manufacturing, Dr. Kamer said, adding that "30 years ago it was 25 percent." 
The lifestyle changes that come with two working family members are reflected in the typical house being built, said Robert Wieboldt, executive vice president of the 600-member Long Island Builders Institute in Islandia.
According to national statistics provided by the National Home Builders Association, a trade organization based in Washington, today's homes are larger and have more amenities than ever before.
While Long Island follows national trends in home building, it tends to be more traditional in design, primarily staying with the colonial format or ranch style, Mr. Wieboldt said. 
According to the association, the average square footage of a new single-family house has increased about 50 percent nationwide since 1970, to 2,265 square feet from 1,500. Also, houses built with two or more stories have increased to 52 percent from 17 percent; two or more bathrooms to 54 percent from 15 percent; one or more fireplaces to 59 percent from 36 percent; and central air-conditioning to 85 percent from 36 percent. Houses built with brick or wood siding decreased to 35 percent from about 70 percent, while vinyl or aluminum siding increased to 40 percent from 8 percent. 
"The mind-set was different years ago," said Dorothy Herman, president of Melville-based Prudential Long Island, which has 37 offices on Long Island. "Construction, rather than cosmetics, was more important. Unlike today's buyers, they wanted finished basements and brick houses, and they weren't as concerned about closet space. People were willing to buy something, add to it and fix it over the years to the way they wanted it. They would buy, raise a family, save their pennies and maybe add that extra bathroom."
Today there is more immediacy. "First-home buyers don't want to wait," she said, "and they are more into aesthetics, high ceilings, entertainment space, home offices and saunas in the master baths."
Twenty years ago homeowners entertained in their finished basements; today they want entertainment centers. It used to be important to live near Main Street, she said, while today that doesn't matter.
According to a consumer survey "What 21st Century Home Buyers Want," conducted by the home building association, walk-in pantries and linen closets top the list of desired features today. A dining room and laundry room are musts, but a separate living room is not as important as a family room. High ceilings -- at least 9 feet rather than the traditional 7 or 8 feet -- are important on the first floor.
The homes of the future will look much like today's new homes but will have more amenities and features making them safer, more comfortable and energy-efficient, builders say. 
Projecting from current consumer demand, builders expect that by 2010 the average house will have the master bedroom and laundry room on the main floor; a flexible interior design with space that could easily be converted for a variety of purposes, including a home office; security systems; modular wiring systems for high-speed data access; multiple telephone lines; and building materials and products that require less maintenance. 
Thirty years ago most people buying a house of Long Island came from an apartment in Brooklyn or Queens, Ms. Herman said. "Those buying today," she added, "already came from a big house and don't want to sacrifice and wait 20 years to have what their parents had."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Laura and Phil Carey's house in South Huntington had just been renovated when they bought it last year. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Despite Worst U.S. Vacancies in 30 Years; 
Flat Year Seen For Hotels Here

 BODY:
The hotel occupancy rate in New York City fell 10.6 percentage points last year, averaging 73.3 percent, and is expected to remain near that level this year, according to a study by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. 
 Hotel operators have been cutting prices to attract customers, so the average daily price in New York City fell to $191.70 in 2001 compared with $222.37 in 2000. 
Any increase in occupancy this year will probably come at the expense of prices, officials of the firm said. 
 Nationwide, according to the study, hotel occupancy is expected to decline again this year, falling to the lowest level since 1971. Last year the nationwide average occupancy rate fell to 60.3 percent from 63.7 percent in 2000. This year the firm expects the decline to continue to an average occupancy rate of 59.6 percent, the lowest level in more than three decades. 
According to the national forecast, no segment of the hotel industry will grow in occupancy until 2003, when an increase in demand and only a 0.8 percent growth in the supply of hotel rooms is expected to push the occupancy rate up to an average of 60.8 percent.
The firm said the leading factors weighing on occupancy rates were a decline in travel caused by the recession, the increasing inconvenience of air travel, the increased possibility of airline delays and fears over the safety of traveling.

HEADLINE: Pumped-Up Gyms Stretch and Flex 

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN 

 BODY:
HANGING on to a pull-up bar while she struggled to do 15 sets of leg lifts, Michelle Croce, 30, admitted that belonging to the Saw Mill Club in Mount Kisco was not cheap. 
 "There are other clubs to join, but this one has everything," she said recently. Because she goes to the club three times a week, and working out is so important to her, Miss Croce, a nurse in White Plains, said that only a major financial disaster would make her consider dropping her precious health club membership. 
 In this recession, that's exactly what anxious health club owners in Westchester are desperate to hear. Indeed, they'd like to persuade every member to continue paying for a place to get fit, arguing that it is not a luxury, but a necessity -- one that shouldn't be sacrificed. 
"People will go to health clubs even when things are bad, because they still want to look good and feel good," said Jerry Janda, editor of Club Industry, a trade magazine for health club operators. "Clubs have become not only a place to work out, but a place to be seen and to socialize." Bill Beck, general manager of Club Fit in Briarcliff, agreed. "People see us as part of their lives, like brushing their teeth," he said. "It's one of those things you can't do without."
Many health clubs are betting on just that notion. 
Health club operators in Westchester are investing millions of dollars in their businesses, even in a rocky economy. They're renovating old clubs as well as building new ones, while facing increasing competition from one another and from nonprofit clubs, most notably Y.M.C.A.'s. The result is a heated competition for members, which has engendered some belligerent sniping among neighboring clubs and impassioned criticism of the tax-free status of the county's upscale Y.M.C.A.'s. 
The focus of the fitness clubs' business plans is changing from recruiting to retention as club owners are learning that they can make more money by keeping old members than by attracting a never-ending supply of new customers. They're luring their loyal members into paying additional fees for children's programs and sports leagues, summer camp, private and group lessons, personal trainers and massages, and into spending at on-site cafes and pro shops. And they have row upon row of popular aerobics machines, like the elliptical trainer that allows users to climb stairs with a gliding motion.
During the next few months, the first Westchester branch of Synergy Fitness will open in Hartsdale, at a cost of $1.5 million. The chain, with headquarters in Manhattan, is ranked the 31st largest in the country, according to Club Industry, which publishes an annual rating of the top 100 largest clubs nationwide. A Curves health club opened last year in Sleepy Hollow; with 21 branches in the county, it's the fastest growing health club franchise in the country. 
This spring, a $2.5 million Solaris, a privately owned tennis and health club with a fifth branch in Hawthorne, will open its new field house in Yorktown. Across the river, a $3 million branch of New York Sports Club will open next month at the Palisades Mall in West Nyack, the sixth Westchester-area club owned by Town Sports International, with headquarters in Manhattan, which is ranked third largest nationwide.
These are just a few of about 51 commercial health clubs in Westchester, which have approximately 65,000 local members, according to Harvey Lauer, president of American Sports Data, a sports and fitness firm in Hartsdale. In addition, nearly 25,000 people belong to local Y's, according to statistics released in 2000 by the national Y.M.C.A. 
SUCCESSFUL clubs are also putting millions of dollars into renovating and improving their existing complexes. 
"We're open 364 days a year, 18 hours a day, and things get used," said Rick Beusman, owner of the Saw Mill Club. The club is closed Christmas. "You have to keep improving and replacing equipment, because people like variety and change. The years in which we don't do capital improvements are unusual.".
The club just spent $500,000 to upgrade the men's locker room and to make other improvements. Club Fit, in Briarcliff, completed a $9 million construction project there last year, adding a new pool, a children's wing, a spinning and wellness studio and a larger fitness space, presumably to pull ahead of its main competitor, the Saw Mill Club.
Competing capital improvements aside, health club owners engage in some rather vigorous backbiting. One owner asserted that his high fees limit memberships, thereby avoiding the crowded, impersonal conditions of clubs that focus more on recruiting new members than on providing quality service. An employee at one club criticized the quality of the tennis court surface at another's. An owner pointed out that at her competitor's place, members are so overwhelmed by the noise and chaos that they never get to use the overpriced club.
Whichever health club is best, most are not cheap.
Fees at local health clubs range from an annual cost of less than $1,000 for a family at most local Y.M.C.A.'s to a premium price of more than $3,300 a year for a family at the Saw Mill Club in Mount Kisco. The cost to join many of the commercial clubs is difficult to pin down, in part because they don't reveal the information readily, and also because there is usually a one-time initiation fee, along with a monthly charge. Both fees are subject to seasonal sales and bargaining, and monthly fees vary based on usage. 
For example, nannies may join the Saw Mill Club for an extra fee, over and above the family fee; at Club Fit, nannies can join without an enrollment fee and for less than a full membership, but only if they're under 25. Children under 5 are free at the Saw Mill Club, as long as there are no older children in the family, but Club Fit requires a family membership for all children under 18, regardless of age. 
Almost all members permit clubs to debit member fees automatically by electronic fund transfer. So if members fail to keep careful track of their monthly credit card charges, they may have no idea how much they spend each year on their health club membership.
Bruce Cooperstein, a chiropractor in Katonah, has a family membership at the Saw Mill Club, but he's not sure exactly what he pays each month. "There's a set fee for the four of us, but my children charge things like lunch, so I think it usually costs us between $250 and $300 a month," he said.
Affluent families who don't need to keep close track of their health club bills probably won't be affected by an economic downturn, said Mr. Janda of Club Industry. But for members of clubs where price matters, like Y.M.C.A.'s, he said, it's a different story. 
Y.M.C.A. directors are careful to point out that fitness is only a small part of what they do. In fact, Ravenell Williams, director of the Y.M.C.A. in Tarrytown, was shocked at the idea that the Y.M.C.A. might be considered a health club.
"That's like calling a church a temple," he said. "We both do religion, but our philosophy and goals are completely different."
Still, several local Y's, including those in Tarrytown and Rye, have invested millions in recent renovations and additions to their current fitness centers, only to see contributions fall drastically since Sept. 11.
"Charitable giving is on the decline, down around 40 percent for the year," said Robert W. Lap, president of the Central and Northern Westchester Y.M.C.A. At a time when Mr. Lap is trying to raise more than $4 million to build a new building in Somers, this is no small matter. 
"I'm not sure we can make it up," he said.
The possibility of a new upscale Y in Somers has nearby owners of commercial clubs bursting with resentment.
Owners of several nearby clubs are incensed that the tax advantages the Y.M.C.A. enjoys will allow the Y's to underprice membership fees and to steal the fitness market from commercial clubs.
"In upscale communities, the Y.M.C.A.'s are misusing their tax-exempt status to compete aggressively in the adult fitness industry," said Kevin Buckley, a government relations manager for the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association, a trade organization, voicing the near-unanimous anger of his commercial members.
But Mr. Lap, president of the Y.M.C.A. that wants to build the new buiilding in Somers, refused to get embroiled in the controversy, pointing out that none of the club owners had criticized him directly. 
"In Somers, we're responding to community need," he said. "There's never been a Y.M.C.A. telling a health club owner what he can and can't do, but I'm not sure that's true in reverse."
While the mission of the Y.M.C.A. is to serve the community, a health club is in business to make money. 
Bally Fitness nationwide had revenues of more than $1 billion in 2000, according to Club Industry's Top 100 list. Town Sports International, which owns New York Sports Clubs, had revenues of $225 million in 2000, and even the comparatively minuscule Saw Mill Club had revenues of $11.5 million that year.
Not every health club in Westchester meets with instant success. 
A new Dolphin Fitness Club, the third in the county, has been set to open in Sleepy Hollow for a year, said Mayor Philip Zegarelli of Sleepy Hollow. The space is full of exercise machines and recruiters there have been accepting money from potential members, "coming on in a very aggressive manner," Mr. Zegarelli said. But the village refused to give the club a certificate of occupancy, because the club failed to meet town regulations, he said. The space didn't have heat and "they illegally tapped into our water lines," Mr. Zegarelli said.
So far, between 25 and 30 people have sued for refunds in Small Claims Court, having paid either $299 for a one-year membership or $329 for two years, said Larry Cassidy, a Sleepy Hollow village clerk. 
Murray Wichard, general manager of Dolphin Fitness, said the club is completing construction and is hoping to get final approval from the village and will open soon. 
The key to making fitness profitable, owners agree, is not to throw a constant stream of never-ending new customers onto the treadmill, but to instill club loyalty and encourage members to spend vigorously while working out.
"The clubs that retain the most members generate the most revenue and are more stable in the long term," said Bill Howland, director of research at International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association. "Repeat customers are less expensive than new customers." It costs about $150 to acquire every new member, he said, including sales commissions, advertising, mailings and orientation packages.
Mr. Beusman of the Saw Mill Club believes that when it comes to members, less is more. "We're not interested in high numbers," Mr. Beusman said. "We're interested in long-term members."
Mr. Beusman estimated that about 40 percent of his profits come from revenues other than member dues, including a children's preschool program and summer camp, children's parties, full-scale tennis and aquatics programs for children and adults and personal training. He also gets a percentage of the profits from his cafe and pro-shop concessions.
At Club Fit, which owns a cafe and a club store that sells exercise-related items like gel seats for spinning bikes, about 30 percent of the revenue comes from sources other than membership fees, Mr. Beck said.
IT'S not surprising, then, that club owners see dollar signs on every massage table and in each child-care corner, because they have to use their space to earn the most dollars per square foot. To a club owner, tennis courts are not good, because they require a large space for too few paying players. Juice bars are good, because they need a small room but hold many paying customers.
Children's teams are ideal, because paying customers pay surcharges to use the facilities during otherwise little-used daytime space, and instill club loyalty, dozens of families at a time.
The strategy works on Helen Pillsbury, 39, an internist in Mount Kisco. Dr. Pillsbury works out several times a week and her two daughters are loyal swimmers on the Saw Mill Club team. The girls practice two or three times a week, and their Brazilian au pair also works out at the club, for at least two hours a day.
As for dropping their club membership, at this point it's unthinkable, said their father, Andy Pillsbury, 39. 
"The girls have gotten pretty adamant about wanting to swim," Mr. Pillsbury said, adding, "We'd face a lot of pressure from them if we wanted to quit."

Clubs Lure the Whole Family With Lessons, Teams and Parties
MANY health clubs in Westchester find their own particular marketing niche. At Curves and Lucille Roberts, for instance, it's women only. At the New York Sports Club and Gold's Gym in White Plains, it's basic, no-frills adult fitness.
A few clubs in the county focus exclusively on attracting and serving families, including babies, toddlers and teenagers. 
Nationwide, slightly more than half of health clubs offer children's programs, according to a survey conducted by the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association in 2000. 
These fitness centers have adopted the Y.M.C.A.'s motto, "We build strong kids," and then taken it a giant step further. 
In several of Westchester's clubs, children can learn not only swimming and tennis, but also lacrosse and volleyball, yoga and kung fu, and even Hawaiian dancing, complete with split bamboo sticks, feather gourds and Hawaiian drums, all the better to entice parents to renew their memberships.
Like the nationally known Y.M.C.A. swim programs, most family-oriented commercial clubs offer swimming lessons for children, beginning at 6 months old.
At the Saw Mill Club in Mount Kisco, there are group and private swim classes for infants, toddlers and school-age children, as well as a competitive swim team for children of all ages. 
The club also offers children's tennis classes and a competitive tennis team. It holds daily preschool sessions, two hours a day, as well as an after-school club for older children. There are vacation mini-camps and an all-day summer camp. The club offers youth fitness classes for preteenagers, basketball clinics, birthday parties and will even hold Sweet 16 parties and bar mitzvahs.
Both the Club Fit in Briarcliff and the one in Jefferson Valley, offer similar programs, along with creative dance, kung fu and yoga classes for children. 
They also offer teenage fitness sessions, Hawaiian dancing, junior spinning and junior kick-boxing classes.
At the Total Fitness Center in Scarsdale, there are weight machines specifically designed for use by children between the ages of 5 and 10.
"We do a lot of athletic training for children," said the owner, Dave Friedman, who also offers yoga and karate classes for children.
Solaris in Yorktown, plans to begin indoor soccer, field hockey, lacrosse and volleyball leagues for children when it opens its new field house in March. There will also be sports camps in tennis, soccer, volleyball and basketball, during the school year and in the summer, said its owner, Elizabeth Gagliardi. 
"Kids here are so sports-oriented, there's a real need for it at the club," she said, "especially during the winter when they can't go outside."
 CARIN RUBENSTEIN

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Westchester Symphony Is Silenced

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
IT was an amateur orchestra and then a professional orchestra and more recently a troubled orchestra. Now it is a defunct orchestra. The Westchester Symphony Orchestra, which began in 1924 as the White Plains Symphony Orchestra, announced this week that it would cease operations. There will be no requiem. The last two scheduled concerts have been cancelled. 
 "We need $50,000, like, yesterday," said Stephanie Friedman, a Scarsdale resident and the symphony's acting director, a position she took last summer after its former management structure came unglued. Mrs. Friedman had been serving as the group's publicist when Suzanne Meszoly, its executive director, left abruptly. The orchestra's operating budget for the fall 2001-spring 2002 season was $100,000; they were unable to raise it. The symphony then postponed its first concert of the season and embarked on a recovery effort, including an attempt to become more pop-oriented. It didn't help. 
 The orchestra also cut its numbers, performing this year as a chamber group rather than the full symphony it has been in the past. Subscribers have dwindled to 350, each of whom paid $400 a season for a pair of tickets to four concerts. "We're trying to get other arts organizations to honor the tickets," Mrs. Friedman said. She mentioned the Westchester Philharmonic as a possibility.
For its first six decades, the symphony was an ensemble of local amateurs who would take breast-feeding breaks during rehearsals or dash out early to watch their children in sports. They played in local high schools and other small venues, as much for their own enjoyment as for anyone else. In the last 20 years, though, the Westchester Symphony moved toward professionalism and unionization. 
Under the guidance of two musical directors -- first Martin Canellakis, then Anthony Aibel -- out went many of the amateurs and in came open auditions, wages, sponsorship (from organizations including the Westchester Arts Council, the Altman Foundation, the New York State Council on the Arts and the Eugene Grant Family Foundation). There were noted guest appearances and a taste of the big time: a performance in Alice Tully Hall, a television appearance and favorable reviews. 
Now there is only the memory of the final note of Beethoven's Fourth, the last piece the group performed as a full symphony.
"It's a sad time," said Mrs. Friedman. 
Elaine C. Carroll, executive director of the Westchester Philharmonic, the county's other notable orchestra, echoed her regret. "The performing arts are vital to the community, and any loss is a loss for Westchester," she said. 
Many factors contributed to the downfall, according to people involved with the orchestra. There was the soured economy and Sept. 11, which made it harder to get corporate sponsorship. And the crowds that came had aged; younger people in Westchester, like younger people elsewhere, are not drawn in significant numbers to classical music. There was stiff competition in the classical repertory from the 18-year-old Westchester Philharmonic, which has nearly five times the subscriber base. The Performing Arts Center of Purchase College has been the home stage for both. 
Some say the board should have been more active. Others say the management was disorganized. But the Westchester Symphony is only the latest casualty in a troubled time for the arts; symphonies from Toronto to St. Louis are also struggling.
"It's really a matter of everything," said Shirley Fuchsberg of Rye, who is chairwoman of the board. The last few years, she said, "have been worse and worse and since September, it's been like a nightmare." 
Mrs. Fuchsberg first came to see the symphony after being invited by a friend 28 years ago. "Sometimes when you're at a certain place at a certain time, something just gets to you," she said. "This symphony just got into my imagination." She served as president before her current position. 
Alice Model, a Larchmont resident, plays the viola and has been a member of the symphony since 1964. She survived the purge of amateurs. She has served as president and also as a board member. She has probably played her last professionally, she said. "I'm 65 and I'm not a member of the union like the other orchestra members, so I'm not looking for work," she said. "I'll just play chamber music with my friends." 
Margaret Swinchoski, the principal flutist and a former personnel manager of the symphony, said the group's demise was "just another nail in the coffin of my career." Asked why the symphony failed, she said: ""I think they had to work harder on funding." 
Anthony Aibel, who became the musical director in 1992 at 22, straight out of the Juilliard School, said: "Good things come to an end. It was a wonderful, magical run."
Mr. Aibel, who lives in the New York City, now wants to dedicate himself to making classical music more tenable to younger generations. "We live in a visual age," he said. "More needs to be done to integrate the arts of film, theater and classical music." He wants to hold concerts for young people in small venues so they can sit up front and he can talk to them during the performances about the music. 
Mr. Aibel is ready to move on. "Diversify is pretty much my middle name," he said. But Mrs. Fuchsberg can't quite bring herself to accept that the symphony's long run is over. "At the end of the year, maybe we'll see what's happening," she said. "I don't know anything definite, but it's certainly on my mind to do that." But she continued: "There were just so many forces against us. There was nothing we could do."

HEADLINE: Loans That Turn a Home Into a Cash Flow 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
A DOZEN years after their introduction, reverse mortgages remain little known, and perhaps less understood. Only an estimated 60,000 to 75,000 of the loans, available to people 62 years of age or older who own and live in their own house, town house or condominium, have been made. But a number of financial institutions, seeing a marketing opportunity based on the sharply increasing number of Americans who are living longer, are vigorously expanding their reverse-mortgage programs.
 The reverse mortgage requires no financial, credit or medical reports, yet promises to put tax-free money into the hands of its borrowers. And borrowers can remain in their home without having to repay any of the loan until they sell, move out or die. 
 In addition, when they do repay, the repayment amount cannot exceed the value of the borrower's home at the time the loan is repaid. If the value of the home exceeds the amount of the loan, what is left reverts to the owner or the owner's estate. 
Depending on the reverse mortgage they choose, borrowers can receive their loans in a lump sum, in monthly payments for as long as they live in their home, from a line of credit or from a combination of a line of credit and monthly payments. 
The most popular choice is the line of credit, because it offers the borrower considerable flexibility and because interest is charged only as the money is actually borrowed, according to Bronwyn Belling, the project manager of the Reverse Mortgage Program for the AARP Foundation, an arm of what was formerly known as the American Association of Retired Persons. In addition, Mrs. Belling said, the untapped balance available usually increases by the same rate as the interest that is being charged on the loan balance; if the untapped balance is $100,000 and the interest rate being charged is 10 percent, that $100,000 line of credit would become $110,000 after a year, assuming that no part of it had been drawn out. Joyce Kuhn, assistant vice president and loan officer at Connecticut's Ridgefield Bank, said that at her bank, reverse mortgage borrowers typically want access to a line of credit along with monthly payments.
Reverse mortgages are loans that, like other types of mortgages, are secured by the borrower's house or condominium. (Co-ops are not eligible for such loans, because they are technically owned by a corporation in which the homeowner holds shares.) 
The loans have ceilings, and the full value of the home is never available to the borrower. The major factors in setting the amount that can be borrowed include the home's appraised value and the age of the borrower (or, if there is more than one owner, of the youngest borrower) -- a 75-year-old will be able to receive a higher proportion of the home's value than a 65-year-old will.
Another factor in determining how much money can be borrowed is the current interest rate -- the lower interest rates are when the loan closes, the bigger the loan amount will be. Loans can be taken out in a lump sum or over time, and the interest is added to the amount that must be repaid by the homeowner when the home is sold or vacated, or by the estate when the homeowner dies.
The location also affects the ceiling on the amount of money that can be taken out of a home, because the Federal Housing Administration sets maximum amounts on a county-by-county basis around the country for the most popular type of reverse mortgage, the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage. The maximum amount for a single-family house is $261,609 in both Westchester County, N.Y., and Bergen County, N.J., and $237,500 in Fairfield County, Conn.
But there are reasons to look carefully at the details of the loans. Many people spurn reverse mortgages, loan specialists say, because of their high origination fees and closing costs. 
For example, a reverse mortgage loan on a house in the metropolitan area valued at $200,000 would net a 65-year-old borrower about $90,000 and a 75-year-old borrower about $113,000, according to Vanessa White, a vice president at BNY Mortgage in West Paterson, N.J. However, total closing costs for each borrower would be about $10,400. That consists of 2 percent of the value of the property (in this case $4,000) for a one-time mortgage insurance premium payable to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, another 2 percent for the lender's origination fee and about $2,400 for the array of closing costs, including title search, appraisal, recording fee and attorneys' fees.
That $10,400 is approximately double the average closing cost nationwide on a conventional mortgage for a $175,000 house, according to Phil Colling, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association.
The higher fees are in part a reflection of the limited availability of reverse mortgages, lenders say, and the additional time required to complete the paperwork for relatively uncommon loans. 
The reverse mortgage costs may be financed as part of the loan, which would reduce the borrower's out-of-pocket expenses but also lower the net amount available to the borrower. 
Those steep costs are one reason the reverse mortgage loan is not generally suitable for short-term financing. Gary Schatsky, a Manhattan financial adviser and lawyer, said that in his opinion reverse mortgages are so costly that "they should not be the first, second or third choice of most people." But, he conceded, "they're tremendous for people to be able to access their equity if they have no other money to live off." 
AND there are psychological problems as well. Many people shun reverse mortgages, lenders say, because they cannot bear the thought of in effect trading in the house that would otherwise go to their children. But Mrs. Kuhn said that as many as 40 percent of the inquiries Ridgefield Bank receives for information about reverse mortgages are from adult children, many of whom are more concerned about their parents' well-being than about inheriting their house. 
While still decidedly a niche product, reverse mortgages are becoming better known largely because the major lenders in the category include subsidiaries of Wells Fargo & Company, Lehman Brothers and the Bank of New York. In addition, the National Reverse Mortgage Lenders Association, a nonprofit trade organization in Washington that promotes the product, has made a concerted effort in recent years to get the word out. Convinced that reverse mortgages will grow in popularity over time, lenders are making reverse mortgages in more parts of the country and are seeking to make them less mysterious.
"It's a product that's greatly misunderstood by many consumers and not all that well known to lenders and bankers, but it will be soon," said Jeffrey D. Moulton, a national marketing manager for Wells Fargo Home Mortgage, based in Des Moines.
Wells Fargo made reverse mortgages available last year at 1,200 of its 1,500 offices and more than doubled its reverse mortgage sales force, adding more than a dozen sales representatives throughout the Northeast, including its first one in Westchester County. As a result, the bank's reverse mortgage sales volume exceeded $300 million in 2001, just about double the previous year. 
The BNY Mortgage Company, an affiliate of the Bank of New York, was among the first to offer reverse mortgages in the New York metropolitan area. Its reverse mortgage loans have increased an average of 50 percent a year in recent years, according to Mrs. White. Last year the company made 432 reverse mortgage loans in the area, she said, including 286 in New York City.
The Financial Freedom Senior Funding Corporation, the Lehman subsidiary, entered into a partnership 15 months ago with the CUNA Mutual Mortgage Corporation, the biggest national mortgage lender in the credit union system, to make reverse mortgages available for credit union members and their families.
The fact that reverse mortgages are a mere trickle compared with the estimated 12-million-plus conventional mortgages originated last year and valued at more than $2 trillion, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association, does not appear to discourage reverse mortgage lenders. 
"The way we look at it, we had a good year," said Mr. Moulton of Wells Fargo, "but we really haven't started yet." 
Moreover, reverse mortgage lenders say there has been a pronounced increase in recent months of the proportion of customers who are affluent. The main reasons, Mrs. White said, are that many people have been wary of cashing in their stock as their portfolios have sharply dropped in value in the last two or three years and many others who had been living off high interest payments and generous dividends until a year or two ago suddenly found themselves with anemic yields. As a result, some have turned to reverse mortgages.
Another reason people with money are turning to reverse mortgages, according to Jim Mahoney, the chief executive of Financial Freedom Senior Funding, whose company offers both a Home Equity Conversion Mortgage and a proprietary reverse mortgage that, unlike those insured by the F.H.A., has no loan limit, is that the loans are tax-free and the interest on them is tax deductible when they are repaid. Noting that Financial Freedom has extended loans for up to $2 million on a home valued at $6 million, he added, "Many high-end borrowers are not looking at the economic benefits as much as the security that comes with having a lifetime income."
Rudolph Clark, 76, a retired real estate salesman who lives in Brooklyn, is not one of those investors, but after taking his own reverse mortgage last March to pay bills, he is enthusiastic about the product.
The brownstone Mr. Clark bought in 1955 for $10,800 had sharply increased in value over the decades, with some nearby houses selling for seven figures. But last year he found himself $85,000 in arrears on his real estate taxes, with no means of paying them other than selling his house. Or so he thought. But after vaguely remembering having heard about reverse mortgages a few years ago and after attending a counseling session with a reverse mortgage specialist, as required by the Federal Housing Administration, he opted for the reverse mortgage. 
"I was attracted to it by not having to pay a monthly mortgage and by having money to pay my taxes," he said of the $147,000 loan that he received through Mrs. White.
His loan, the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage (known as HECM and pronounced "heck-em") is overwhelmingly the most popular of the reverse mortgages, according to reverse-mortgage specialists, because it is available nationwide, insured by the Federal Housing Administration and usually provides the most money for the least total cost.
OTHER prominent reverse mortgages are the Home Keeper mortgage offered by the Federal National Mortgage Association ("Fannie Mae") and mortgages offered by Financial Freedom Senior Funding. Financial Freedom's proprietary Cash Account reverse loan is not subject to the limits on equity that can be tapped, as is the case with F.H.A.-insured loans. 
Mr. Clark paid his taxes in full with his loan and still has money for general expenses and home improvements. "This is where I've spent much of my life and where I still want to spend it until the end of the journey," Mr. Clark said. And because of the sense of security that his reverse mortgage has provided in what he refers to as his "twilight years," he is adamant in believing that reverse mortgages could do the same for many other older people who are cash poor but own a home. 
"That's why it's necessary that they be made aware of reverse mortgages," he added. "I've known people who sold their house or lost it just because they had no way of knowing about reverse mortgages."
As the AARP points out in its 68-page consumer guide to reverse mortgages ("Home Made Money," available by calling 800 209-8085), until recently there were two main ways to get cash from one's home: by selling it and then having to move, or by borrowing against the home and then making monthly loan repayments. Reverse mortgages, the guide says, offer "a third way of getting money from your home that does not require you to leave it or to make regular loan repayments."
But the booklet also points out that deciding on the kind of loan can be very complex. That is why the AARP encourages potential borrowers to attend free counseling by reverse mortgage specialists.
Nancy Bentley, one such counselor in East Hartford, Conn., said that counseling sessions usually run about an hour, but that potential borrowers often require a couple of sessions before their concerns and questions have been addressed. Mrs. Bentley added that about 75 percent of the would-be borrowers wind up taking reverse mortgages, but, lenders say, usually not until almost a year afterward. 
"Reverse mortgages are one of those things that haven't caught on yet," said Bob Ceilly, a 67-year-old real estate broker in Brightwaters on Long Island, who took out a $128,000 reverse mortgage from Wells Fargo three months ago to fix up his century-old house. He is having a new kitchen installed, after which he plans to add two bathrooms and a new heating system. 
"I've spoken to several people, including attorney friends of mine, about reverse mortgages," Mr. Ceilly said, "because I think it's a great concept. But their reaction was usually, 'Duh!' " 
He would get no such response from Sally Knakal, also on Long Island. She thinks so highly of reverse mortgages that she is on her second. She took out her first one seven years ago, when she became a widow at 62 and most of her wealth was in the equity in her house. Younger borrowers receive less money from reverse mortgages than do older borrowers, based on actuarial life expectancy tables, and Mrs. Knakal found herself running low on money sooner than expected. 
Then about a year ago she learned of the Financial Freedom Cash Account. It provides a line of credit that is not subject to the F.H.A. limit, from which consumers can borrow for as long as they occupy their home. The minimum draw is $500 and the unused portion increases by 5 percent annually until maturity.
Like Mr. Ceilly, Mrs. Knakal intends to improve her house, beginning with a new driveway this spring. 
Sam Taylor, a 73-year-old consulting engineer in Darien, Conn., also acquired a reverse mortgage from Financial Freedom, opting for a line of credit to support his business, which he runs out of his home.
"Since I have a great deal of equity tied up in my home," Mr. Taylor said, "I decided I'd like to have use of some of that money." 
WEALTH and income play no role for borrowers obtaining reverse mortgages. Instead, the amount of cash borrowers can get from an F.H.A.-insured reverse mortgage is subject to the market value of the property and loan limits that vary by county and usually change at least once a year. This year, for example, the average reverse mortgage insured by the F.H.A. nationwide is $144,336 for a single family house, but the limit is $392,413 in Alaska, Guam, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands. 
Those limits apply whether the borrower's house is worth $150,000 or $1 million. But Mr. Mahoney, who is also co-chairman of the National Reverse Lenders Association, said there is an effort by the association and the industry to have a uniform nationwide limit, rather than county by county. That will require the approval by HUD and an act of Congress, and Mr. Mahoney said the proposal appears to have bipartisan support.
Reverse mortgages are complex products, and specialists caution those interested to compare carefully the costs and benefits of various loans.
Almost like a mantra the AARP booklet warns again and again to compare, compare, compare. "It's the surest way to evaluate a reverse mortgage," said Ken Scholen, a specialist in reverse mortgages who wrote the AARP booklet. In it, he warns: 
"Most likely no one you know has ever taken out a reverse mortgage. So there's probably no one you can turn to who has first-hand experience as a reverse mortgage borrower. And very few professional advisers have any experience with these loans, either."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
The Power to Help

BYLINE:  By STAN KOSIEROWSKI; Stan Kosierowski is president and chief executive of PSEG Energy Technologies in Edison.

 BODY:
GIVEN our tight economy, heightened national security concerns and renewed anxiety about our supply of oil, it's time that we in the Northeast became serious about conserving electricity. Conservation is a meaningful act, just when many of us are looking for something of lasting good to do for our country. Investment in more efficient electrical equipment in our homes, offices and factories benefits us, individually and collectively, for the long term. 
 In fact, few individual acts could be more in our long-term national interest. Though oil prices have dropped 30 percent over the past several months, we all know the saving is temporary. With oil prices, what goes down, goes up. By contrast, the payoff for investing in more efficient lighting and in heating and cooling equipment is permanent. 
 First, let's see what investment in saving electricity does for the pocketbook. Let's assume that all of us from Virginia to Massachusetts -- homeowners, businesspeople and factory managers -- modernized our lighting and heating and cooling systems. Based on real experience, we each would immediately cut our electric bills an average of 25 percent. At that rate we'd recoup any investments within two years from lower electric bills -- or sooner still with utility and state rebates factored in. For the region as a whole, the aggregate annual saving would be measured in the hundreds of millions of dollars. 
Reducing electrical use by that same 25 percent in each home, office and plant would cut regional power consumption by a whopping 133 million kilowatt hours. That could be enough to enable us to shut down dozens of power plants and cut our oil imports from Saudi Arabia by more than half. Greater energy self-sufficiency translates directly to greater national security and maneuvering room in global diplomacy. 
Another winner is the environment. That same 25 percent regional saving in electricity would reduce sulfur and other emissions by thousands of tons a year as well, easing the global warming threat and improving the air we breathe. 
Too often we nod approvingly at new rebate programs for investing in energy-saving lighting but don't take advantage of them. We perk up at news of a new more energy-efficient heater or air-conditioner, but we don't pursue it. It is estimated that 90 percent of the Northeast Corridor's homeowners and 70 percent of its businesses could very readily achieve that 25 percent saving simply by taking action. 
Rebate offers are better than ever right now, and the paperwork is simple, sometimes even nonexistent. Some large contractors will give a rebate up front and collect from utilities or states themselves. Couple state or utility rebates with the variety of deals available from responsible contractors, and modernization can wind up costing nothing. 
Municipalities and parking garages can benefit too. At 8 watts apiece rather than 68, LED bulbs in traffic lights save our cities $1,200 a year over incandescent bulbs per intersection. They'll also last 10 times longer, reducing accidents caused by burned-out traffic signals or changing bulbs at rush hour. "Energy harvesting" controls in parking garages turn lights off during daylight and on at dusk. Occupancy sensors turn on the lights only when people are using the space. 
The United States remains the biggest electricity consumer in the world, and we depend on that electricity for our prosperity and standard of living. Every kilowatt we conserve reduces our vulnerability to a California-type scenario right here. The Atlantic Corridor from Virginia to Massachusetts accounts for 16 percent of nation's energy consumption, and about as much as all of Europe and South America combined. 
The United States imports about 40 percent of the oil necessary to generate electricity. Unfortunately as we have learned recently, much of that oil comes from countries that may not be the steadfast suppliers we once believed them to be. 
Utilities or electrical contractors will gladly provide a free survey and recommendations. Even in the unlikely event that none of your electrical equipment needs modernizing, they can make present equipment run better longer. That in itself would likely cut your energy bill by 5 percent or more. 
When's the best time to modernize? It's best to get it done before next summer's cooling season, when electrical demand peaks. 
Electric power conservation is the right thing to do, and the right time to do it is now.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
Pulling Ailing Schools Up by the Bootstraps

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, the science curriculum was drastically changed at the Whittier Elementary School in Camden to allow the students to roll up their sleeves and become explorers.
 They began growing beans and writing in their journals about plant growth, keeping birds and fish in some classrooms to observe their habits and doing yet more laboratory work, said Marilyn Allen, the principal at Whittier in one of the nation's poorest districts. 
 To show the way, teachers were encouraged to take graduate science courses and bring their knowledge back to the classroom; the after-school program emphasized science and social studies.
This year, the payoff came.
Whittier's state test scores showed that 62 percent of the 50 students who took the test were advanced in science and 38 percent were proficient. What was most astounding was that the scores were not far off from those in affluent districts like Princeton, where at Riverside Elementary School 66 percent scored advanced in science and at Community Park Elementary about 64 percent were advanced. 
"We used the philosophy 'Let me do it and I'll learn it,' " said Mrs. Allen. "It has a lot to do with the enthusiasm of our teachers."
In language arts literacy, 80 percent of Whittier's fourth-grade students scored proficient; 89 percent scored proficient or advanced in math.
Not all the state's disadvantaged districts did nearly as well as Whittier. For the most part, students in affluent suburbs scored higher than those in poorer areas, and scores for black and Hispanic students lagged behind those of their white and Asian counterparts.
The assessments -- which began being administered to 4th-, 8th- and 11th-grade students three years ago to determine if the state's five-year-old curriculum standards were being met -- have been the subject of criticism and debate among educators.
Critics say students are tested too frequently and that the scores do not mean a great deal because an out-of-state company grades the tests -- and many of the graders are not teachers. At times the scores have been sent back for re-evaluation.
Nonetheless, the tests have prompted districts throughout the state to revamp their curriculums, particularly in writing, and fourth-grade students now spend a lot of time doing exercises similar to those they will be tested on in the spring.
So far, scores have gone up every year as teachers have changed to conform to the material on the tests. For instance, of the 103,000 fourth grade students who took the tests last April and 2001, about 79 percent scored proficient or advanced proficient in language arts, as against 55.1 percent the previous year; 66 percent of them were proficient or advanced in math and 87 percent in science.
A breakdown by race showed that 88 percent of the state's white students and 91 percent of all Asian students scored advanced or proficient in language arts literacy as against 55 percent of black students and 65 percent of all Hispanics. There was a similar gap in math, with 78 percent of white students and 85 percent of Asian student passing, versus 35 percent of black students and 48 percent of Hispanics.
But Dr. Michael Smith, an associate professor of education at Rutgers University, cautioned that the statistics merely reflected the students' economic status.
"So often race and class correlated," Dr. Smith said. "We are not recognizing the impact of the economic status. Kids whose home cultures are more like school culture have an advantage."
At time the writing prompts can also put students from poor, urban backgrounds at a disadvantage, he said. 
For example, Dr. Smith said that one test he came across in his research used a story about an elderly man on a farm who has a telescope he had never used.
"It's white, rural and elderly," Dr. Smith said. "What's the point of entry there for some students?"
While Dr. Smith applauded the state curriculum standards, he suggested making some changes, like eliminating the timed tests, because of his contention that some students are put at a disadvantage.
Bucking the trends, some schools in Abbott districts -- the state's poorest -- like Whittier showed marked improvement in the latest tests.
For instance, Grace Giglio, the principal at at No. 16 Elementary School in Paterson, said she was "elated" when she received the scores. In language arts literacy, 87.9 percent of the almost 40 students taking the test scored proficient or advanced, a 55 percent gain over the previous year. In math, 91 percent scored proficient or advanced.
"We had a tremendous amount of community support and staff development," Ms. Giglio said, noting that community volunteers donated computers and participated in tutoring and mentoring programs.
In addition to training the full-time teachers, substitutes also received instruction.
Ms. Giglio, who has a proficiency in math, spent time in the classrooms and helped institute a Quiz Bowl in the fourth grade in which students competed in math, literature and science.
Southampton School No. 2 in Burlington County -- situated in a diverse community with a largely blue-collar population, also saw great improvement in its scores, with 97 percent of the 94 students scoring proficient or advanced in language arts literacy, said Sharon Danfield, who has been principal for the past four years. Of that group, 23 percent scored in the advanced category.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Geraldine Livingston at Whittier Elementary School in Camden, where 62 percent of students were rated "advanced" in science. (Tim Shafer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Latin American Markets 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Argentina's Crisis: It's Not Just Money" (Week in Review, Jan. 13): The rise of anti-free-market populism in Latin America certainly does not bode well for the United States' foreign policy objectives. But blaming capitalism for the economic woes in Argentina and elsewhere is a mistake since no country in Latin America, except possibly Chile, has yet fully embraced real free-market reform. 
 The type of partial reforms that plague Latin America, in which some markets are partly liberalized without the benefits of needed institutional change, are similar to the problems in Russia and Eastern Europe. Despite an economic collapse Russia chose not to retreat, but to actually accelerate its reform efforts, and Russia's economy is set to grow at close to 8 percent this year alone. The anti-free-market, protectionist policies being advocated by Argentina's new president only threaten further economic collapse.

JOHN D. SULLIVAN
Executive Director, Center for
International Private Enterprise
Washington, Jan. 14, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
